https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106698,2022,Law and Policy of European Integration,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. M Glavina', 'dr. M Markakis, MJur DPhil (Ox)', 'prof.dr. F Amtenbrink']",,"Inhoud

<body>The course imparts in-depth knowledge on European Union law, including the law of the fundamental freedoms, EU institutional and procedural law, EU competition law (including EU state aid law), the law of the Economic and Monetary Union, and the law of external trade relations. In order to stretch the understanding of EU law beyond the borders of ‘black-letter law’, the course examines the policies underlying European integration and how these have an impact in shaping the European Union’s legal system. European integration is characterised by three main elements: the implementation of the mechanism of market integration rather than the unification of sovereign states
column2: the focus on individuals rather than states
column3: and the utilisation of law as a tool to achieve compliance. This course analyses the different stages of the development of European integration against the background of these three elements, thereby tracing the evolution of EU law from the foundation of the European Economic Community to today’s European Union.

column1: The course first focuses on the mechanics of European integration and how the instruments of market integration interact with each other. The relationship between negative integration, eliminating national barriers to trade, and positive integration, establishing harmonised standards covering the geographical scope of the internal market, is analysed. Moreover, it will be demonstrated how the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) has exerted pressure on Member States to agree on legislating at European level instead of defending national standards in all instances.

With regard to the position of the individual in European integration, the course elaborates on the concept of ‘market citizenship’, which was created with the aim to transform the national citizen (who is primarily affiliated to a Member State) into a market citizen (who is primarily defined by her/his activities in the EU internal market). Emphasis is placed on the individual rights in the EU Treaties, their direct effect within the legal orders of the Member States, and their supremacy over conflicting national law. In this way, the course highlights how the individual has become the agent of European Union law thereby ensuring its uniform application throughout the entire EU.

By combining these elements, the course provides for a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of European integration: the empowerment of the individual (market citizenship) through directly applicable EU rights (integration through law), resulting in setting aside conflicting national law (negative integration), which carries the risk of a ‘race to the bottom’ in terms of protection standards that can only be prevented by uniform legislation at European level (positive integration).
Finally, the course focuses on two present-day developments in EU law with major implications for future European integration: the concept of Union citizenship
column2: and the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). The Union citizenship extends market citizenship to non-economic activities. The course assesses the potential of Union citizenship to repeat the integration reached by market citizenship with regard to non-economic policy fields. The introduction to EMU focuses on the interplay between a supranational monetary union and an intergovernmental economic union, where Member States’ policies are coordinated by means other than legislating. The question is whether the success of the internal market integration, where Member States were forced by the pressure exerted by negative integration, can be repeated with regard to the integration of economic, fiscal and taxation policies.

column1: Werkvormen/Instructional method: The course will be held in interactive lectures. Furthermore, in order to enhance the understanding of the EU’s legal system, the knowledge acquired in the course is deepened in seminars, in which students will develop written pleadings on real EU law cases representing the applicant’s, the defendant’s and the EU’s legal point of view on the case. In this manner, a dialogue between different perspectives on important EU legal questions will be triggered and a sense for academic debates arising from different perspectives will be developed.

This course aims to provide an in-depth understanding of the legal framework of European economic integration and the economic, sociological and political rationale underlying it. Completion of the course will enable students to apply EU law in various legal fields.

Toetsing/Test: The overall grade is composed of written assignments (in form of written pleadings that would be submitted to the Court of Justice of the European Union) and a final written exam. The assignments count towards 40% of the final mark, and the exam counts towards 60% of the final mark. The final exam is a 3-hour written examination, which takes place at the end of the course. It consists of two parts. The first part consists of short theoretical / essay-type questions, whilst the second part consists of two case studies. Last year, the exam took the form of a take-home, open-book exam.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105716,2022,Law in Action,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['CN Focacci', 'mr.dr. NL Holvast', 'prof.dr. E Kantorowicz - Reznichenko', 'prof.dr. PTM Desmet']",,"Inhoud

How can we accurately predict judicial decisions? How can we test the effects of different sanction regimes on compliance with the law? How can policy makers know the effects of legal rules on people’s behavior – e.g., do longer prison sentences reduce crime? All these questions can be addressed by employing different empirical methods to law.

Over the years, legal scholarship witnessed a rise in the incorporation of insights and methods from social sciences like sociology, economics and psychology. Interviews, case studies, surveys, experiments and statistics are no longer uncommon in legal research and have become the main ingredients of a new field of legal research - Empirical Legal Studies (ELS). For practicing lawyers and policy makers too, the importance of empirical data is continuously rising.
• Get acquainted with the field of ELS
• Learn how to formulate empirical legal research questions themselves.
• Become familiar with various methods that can be used to systematically investigate such questions (qualitative, quantitative, including new information technologies).
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Be introduced to important empirical findings in the legal domain: law &amp
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Learn from invited experts about the practical application of ELS in national and international policy-making.&nbsp

No prior knowledge of law, empirical methodology or statistics is required. The focus is on the design and application of empirical methods, statistical analysis will not be covered. The course is suitable for law students, but also for social sciences students who want to learn how empirical methods are applied in the legal context and by policy makers.
<body>By the end of this minor, students will be able to:
• Understand the relevance and importance of empirical methods to law and policy.
• Describe which empirical methods are available to answer these questions.
• Identify the strengths and weaknesses of these methods.
• Become acquainted with important findings obtained with different empirical research methods.
• Understand how empirical methods can be applied in legal practice.
• Pinpoint how policy makers today apply empirical research in policy making at the national and international level.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106683,2022,Law of the Sea,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['prof.dr. E Hey'],,Inhoud
<body><span style=""background-color:#fafafa""><span style=""color:black"">The course Law of the Sea is a compulsory course for participants in the Master Maritime &amp
column2: Transport Law. The course focuses on the body of public international law that governs ocean uses, such as navigation and fishing. During the course the extent of coastal state and flag state jurisdiction in different maritime areas, such as the territorial sea and the exclusive economic zone, will be an important focus of attention. Other topics that will be treated include international institutions, delimitation of ocean boundaries, dispute settlement, marine resources management and the protection of the marine environment.

column1: The course will be taught in the active academic learning mode and consists of 12 interactive sessions, spread over 6 weeks. Participants have to attend class. In other words, classes are compulsory. Participants are expected to actively prepare for class, submit assignments and actively participate in class, assignments include individual and group work.

After having completed the course successfully, students will be able to independently describe, analyze and assess problems associated with ocean governance in legally relevant ways and will be able to apply the law of the sea to such problems. They will also be able to independently and critically reflect on the role of the law of the sea in ocean governance in an interdisciplinary context, taking into account a variety of perspectives, including South-North perspectives, and present their findings in written and oral format.

<body><span style=""background-color:#fafafa""><span style=""color:black"">This course is dedicated to the life cycle of a ship. First, the legal definition of a ‘ship’ is discussed, followed by an introduction into shipbuilding and ship purchase contracts.&nbsp
column2: Then, the course looks into the different conventions that regulate the operation of a ship (SOLAS, STCW, MARPOL, MLC, etc.), maritime liens and mortgages. The course also looks into ship arrests, summary relief proceedings and forced sales of ships. In addition, a guest lecturer will give the students an introduction to the tax law aspects of shipping.&nbsp
column3: Finally, the course looks into the scrapping and recycling of ships.

column1: The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. The course will be examined on the basis of a written exam consisting of essay-type questions and case studies.

To provide students with an overview and understanding of the various legal issues and practical problems which are related to the ownership and operation of ships, from the acquisition of a newbuild or second-hand vessel over the rules and regulations governing the operation of a ship to its final scrapping or recycling.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107337,2022,Law, Economics and Organizations",Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,"Inhoud

column2: Economics studies the economic effects of legal rules and legal institutions and their evolution over time. This course focuses on the most fundamental legal institution of our times: the business corporation, that is, a firm with “legal personality”. It unveils its origin, historical evolution and functions in a modern economy and explains the reach of an economic theory of legal entities.

column1: This course brings the students to the cutting edge of research in Business Law &amp
column2: Economics. The course starts with an analysis of property rights and their importance for industrial organization and the theory of the firm. It then explores the economics of corporations, their essential differences with respect to unincorporated firms and the problem of dissolution through bankruptcy. The course focuses in particular on four features of the corporations, which have “proprietary rights” nature and are attached to the corporation’s qualification as a “legal entity”. Building on the economic theory of the firm, this course illustrates a theory of why some firms incorporate, what this means for property and contracts and for the market in general.

column1: The course builds on very recent contributions in legal scholarship, finance and economics.

<body>This course presents an economic theory of legal entities and unpacks the fundamental features of the corporation (a firm with legal entity status) examining their origins, evolution and functions in modern western economy. The most used and innovative theories are examined in detail and students will learn how to work with them. The material treated during the course is meant to give the students a perspective on current research trends and hot topics. This course is highly complementary to courses in corporate finance, contract theory, political economy and industrial organization.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104728,2022,Leadership & Coaching,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. DAJA Derks - Theunissen'],,Inhoud

Leiderschap is een groot thema in de literatuur. Veel onderzoekers hebben gekeken naar leiderschapsstijlen en strategieën. Ook de interactie met de werknemers die een leidinggevende aanstuurt, de zogenaamde volgens, is niet onderbelicht gebleven. Werkt elke strategie in dezelfde mate voor elke werknemer? Aangezien veel academisch geschoolden straks in een leidinggevende positie terecht komen, is het ook voor de praktijk zeer zinvol om hier bij stil te staan.
<span style=""color:black"">Een ander hoofdthema binnen dit blok is coaching. Als er één aandachtsgebied binnen het werkveld van de A&amp
column2: O psychologie enorm toegenomen is, is het coaching wel. Coaching vindt zijn oorsprong in de sportwereld en is overgewaaid naar het bedrijfsleven. Het beroep coach is niet beschermd, wat inhoudt dat iedereen zich coach mag noemen. Echter, de psychologische benadering van coaching komt voort uit psychologische theorieën en onderzoek. Belangrijke vragen zijn wat coaching precies inhoudt en hoe het kan bijdragen aan betere prestaties van werknemers. Is het coachen van een individuele werknemer zinvol, of worden er betere resultaten bereikt als er op teamniveau gecoacht wordt?

column1: Verder worden studenten in dit blok uitgedaagd om kritisch te denken en om hun theoretische kennis toe te passen op situaties en casussen uit de praktijk.
Het blok is gestructureerd rond twee grote thema’s: leiderschap en coaching.
Dit blok is een verdieping binnen de arbeids- en organisatiepsychologie. Doel van dit blok is kennis te verwerven van psychologische theorie&euml

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106529,2022,Leadership Communication: Strategies and Trends,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['drs. T Huisman'],,"Inhoud

Leadership in today’s hyper-mediatized society is facing ever greater and dynamic challenges. In addition to mastering the traditional strategic areas of a business or organization, leaders of today and tomorrow also need to be excellent communicators in the face of their dramatically changing role, with implications for organization culture too.
Here are some of the big changes that are fundamentally reshaping all organizations.

column2: Technological changes creating deep and lasting disruptions everywhere, with impacts on businesses, society and all stakeholders.
Regulatory zeal or other governmental influence is of increasing importance.
Highly volatile and complex external context, where system thinking and understanding the ‘unthinkables’ will be required.
Ever more scrutiny by NGOs and other stakeholders.
At the same time, the trust is declining for all institutions: business, governments, NGOs and media.
Media and social media drive ultra- transparency but also fake news!
In this age of disruptions and fast moving changes, leadership communications require greater focus on resilience and changes in organization culture

column1: This course will examine how leaders can turn risks into opportunity by strengthening their understanding of these issues, the role of stakeholder management and how they can deploy strategic communication embracing the new media to achieve this.</body>
Students have acquired knowledge and understanding of:

column4: Different academic perspectives on how multi-facetted societal and economic developments influence the demands of Leadership at micro and macro level.
Multi-dimensional thinking on new Leadership capabilities and the Communication imperative.
The new communication imperative for leadership, organisational culture and what this means in practice.
Analyze system thinking, the role of ‘unthinkables’ and how this affects leadership.
Understand different communications dimensions of today’s leadership capabilities.
Critically review the use of different Communications methods that can be deployed by Leadership and implications for organization culture.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108837,2022,Leadership Development and Training,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. C Zhou'],,"Inhoud

In modern organizations, employees are continuously expected to learn and improve themselves to cope with frequent changes. Leadership skill is one of the core aspects to develop for career advancement. The aim of this course is to establish a solid foundation of the key principles of leadership development based in the state of the science. The focus will be on both developing your own leadership potential and your ability to develop other’s leadership.

Together we will reflect on insights from leadership research, explore different approaches to leadership development such as 360-degree feedback, coaching, mentoring, and learning from experience. There will also be debates on “hot” topics in the field. For example, is adventure-based/outdoor training effective? Does mindfulness training help leadership development? Is online coaching going to work?

You are expected to actively participate during the lectures both in discussions and through in-class exercises. In addition to active in-class participation, you are expected to complete a number of assignments outside of the classroom, both individually and in small groups. There are also weekly short quizzes to consolidate and provide feedback to your learning.&nbsp
<li>Gain better insight into one's own leadership capacity and areas for personal growth and development through reflections
<li>Develop critical thinking of research and practices in leadership development and training
<li>Understand the systematic function and needs of training and development in organizations
• Evaluate and discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different leadership developmental and training initiatives.

The prominent leadership scholar James MacGregor Burns famously stated that leadership is one of the most observed but least understood phenomena on earth. The popularity of leadership can indeed hardly be overstated. For example, the term ‘leader’ results in almost one billion hits on Google and about 3 million on Google Scholar. Although leadership is a powerful term it is also often weakly conceptualised. In this course, we aim to move beyond this by discussing the notion of leadership in depth. We will study among other things the historical development of important leadership theories, discuss the differences and similarities of leadership in the public and private sector and show various methods to study leadership. When doing this, we will use insights from various disciplines, such as psychology, sociology, public administration, business administration. In this way, we increase our understanding of leadership so that students and professors can study it and practitioners can use these insights in their work.
<body>After the course, students are able to:
<li>understand and describe the various leadership approaches used in the last five decades
<li>understand and describe the similarities and differences between leadership in the public and private domain
<li>define and critically reflect on core leadership concepts (e.g. transformational leadership, transactional leadership, leader member exchange theory, attachment theory, and ethical leadership)
<li>describe and critically reflect on the relevance of emotions and power relations that make leadership possible and impossible in practice
<li>describe and critically reflect on the reasons for change and change management
<li>understand and describe what leaders can do to facilitate change

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104694,2022,Leadership and HRM in International Organisations,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. A Albareda Sanz', 'dr. NJL Cannaerts']",,"Inhoud

The B1 course on organization and management has explained the essence of organizations, the relation between context and organization and the important role of management in shaping and guiding organizations. This course builds on this knowledge by discussing the role of leadership and strategic HRM within (international) organizations. This is based on the assumption that people (whether leaders or employees) are an important resource of organizations.

The course starts with the introduction of the major concepts and theories about leadership and HRM and the way they affect the functioning of organizations. Next, these concepts will be applied specifically to international organizations. Arguably, to be successful, international organizations need effective leaders who are able to get the best of the people working for these organizations, taking into account diverse contexts.
During the assignments, students will apply the concepts and theories and will be challenged to evaluate leadership and HRM in a specific international organization.
<body>After passing the course, students are able to
• Define major concepts from the leadership and HRM literature.
• Summarize major theories about leadership and HRM.
• Understand the relationship between leadership and HRM.
• Apply scientific approaches and theories about leadership and HRM to international organisations and cases.
• Critically reflect upon leadership and HRM in international organisations.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106634,2022,Leading Organisational Change,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. HGH van Dierendonck'],,"Inhoud

In 21st century organisations, the only constant seems to be change. Especially organisations that link to the global market are multifaceted, difficult to fully grasp and hard to manage. This course focuses on the challenges that organisational change brings with specific attention for the critical elements that drive behavioural change throughout an organisation.&nbsp
column2: It takes a multilevel perspective, starting with how the executive leaders play an essential role in foreseeing and establishing positive change, to getting the people within an organization on board, and the building of teams that can take change to the next level.&nbsp
column3: Specific attention will be given to dealing with resistance, building resilience and the political skills needed to create strategic alignment throughout an organisation.

column1: • Critically evaluate the role and impact of leaders and individuals on organisational change
• Develop context- and people-sensitive solutions to organisational change.
• Discuss how to initiate and manage sustainable organisational development.
• Analyse information using critical thinking to drive change processes.
• Explain the importance of having a full comprehensive view on change leadership with a long-term perspective.
• Insight into core aspects to develop an organization grounded in continuous learning

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107873,2022,Leading People, Teams, and Organisations for Excellence",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. IJ Hoever', 'dr. L van Bunderen, PhD', 'dr. M Meier-Barthold']",,"Inhoud

<body>Organisations are complex social entities which are only successful if the people within them thrive and perform to their full potential. Leaders and managers play a critical role in helping individuals to reach this potential, to successfully collaborate to achieve a common purpose, and to leverage and respect the skills, insights, and experiences of a diverse range of employees. Fulfilling this role requires knowledge about how to shape behaviour and promote performance in organisations and practical skills to implement them. Through this course, we will therefore explore the core question of how to encourage people to thrive and deliver excellence for organisations from three different angles. These angles are captured in three themes:

• Building successful teams: In the first theme, we focus on how individuals can productively collaborate in teams, which are a key building block of modern workplaces. Successful teams are critical for business success, but how can we help teams to function at their best?

• Leading others: In the second theme, we focus on how leaders can motivate, direct, and influence the behaviour of their followers. Leaders play a key role in helping employees realize their potential. At the same time leaders can be the source of demotivation and conflict. An understanding of how leadership can help people thrive and where it can go wrong is essential for effective organisational functioning.

• Managing diversity in the workplace: The third theme puts the management of diverse workforces centre stage to explore how we can build organisations in which a variety of employees thrive and perform. Managing today’s increasingly diverse workforce presents organisations with a challenge that is both complex and potentially rewarding. This theme discusses key theories of diversity and offers insights into best practices in diversity management in order to help you realize the benefits and avoid the pitfalls of diversity.

The central purpose of this course is to give students insights into critical questions regarding teamwork, leadership, and diversity management within organisations. Specifically, the course covers three broad learning goals (listed below). Each of these learning goals covers the three content areas of the course: building successful teams, leading others, and managing diversity.

column2: comprehension: After following this course, students should be able to understand and explain the major theories about, and factors that contribute to effective team dynamics, leadership, and diversity management.

problem solving: After following this course, students should be able to use the aforementioned theories and research findings to critically analyse and solve practical problems concerning team dynamics, leadership, and diversity management. This involves the ability to:

column1: • Select and find relevant theories and research findings for a given problem or challenge.
• Use these theories and research findings to understand the causes and contingencies of the problem or challenge.
• Develop recommendations and solutions based on the theory and the particular circumstances of the challenge or problem.

column2: self-development: After following this course, students should be able to identify the strengths and weaknesses in their own functioning as team members and leaders in settings characterised by various levels of diversity. This involves the ability to:

column1: • Reflect on one’s own behaviours, biases, and functioning.
• Develop concrete plans of how to further improve.
• Put these plans into action and reflect upon their success.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104757,2022,Learning analytics & the design of online learning,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. BB de Koning', 'dr. HK Tabbers', 'G Martins Van Jaarsveld']",,"Inhoud

One fascinating aspect of online learning environments is that learners will leave digital traces of their behavior. On the individual level this raises ethical questions about privacy, and it requires rules and regulations to provide learners with control over which information will and will not be shared. On the group level however, anonymized trace data provide a rich source of information for all stakeholders involved in organizing, designing, and providing online education or training.

In this practical you will get hands-on experience in this field of ‘learner analytics’: the use of digital trace data for analyzing learners’ online behavior. We will especially focus on the role of learning analytics for evaluating and optimizing the design of a specific online learning environment. You will be provided with actual trace data from an existing learning environment, and you will not only be analyzing these data, but also you will also have to come up with a redesign plan based on this analysis.</body>
• Being able to analyze learner analytics data with the purpose of testing hypotheses on (un)intended learner behavior.
• Being Being able to translate these findings into a plan for redesign of the learning environment.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107879,2022,Learning by Doing: consulting social entrepreneurs,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['prof.dr. LCPM Meijs', 'PSM van Overbeeke, MSc']",,"Inhoud

In this minor, you will work as consultants to (Rotterdam and surrounding area based) social entrepreneurs and non-profit organizations. This course is intended to strengthen the skills and specific knowledge of students and provides a very practical experience. Instead of working with fictitious cases, you will be working with real, existing organizations. This will allow you to apply the knowledge that you have gained thus far to a real-life situation. In addition, the work you will be doing is intended to benefit both your client organization and the larger community. Interesting cases are pre-selected by the instructors, but we are open for any suggestions from students.
<li style=""text-align:justify""><em>become familiar with important issues and theories involving consultancy, social entrepreneurship, and the non-profit sector
<li style=""text-align:justify""><em>develop skills in the application of theoretical concepts to real-life situations
<li style=""text-align:justify""><em>gain experience with actual issues that arise in the course of a consultancy project

<li style=""text-align:justify""><em>be guided through: your first meeting with the client, how to write a consultancy contract and report, the actual process of consultancy, and how to present your recommendations to your client
<li style=""text-align:justify""><em>gain experience in finding, evaluating and applying relevant literature to the specific situation of a client organization
• develop and strengthen your creativity, teamwork, project, communication, research, writing, intervision, and presentation skills.
<div>After the course you will be able to:
• describe important issues and theories involving consultancy, social entrepreneurship, and the non-profit sector
• apply theoretical concepts to real-life situations
• manage actual issues that arise in the course of a consultancy project
• find, evaluate and apply relevant literature to the specific situation of a client organization
• manage the different steps in a consultancy process and produce a consultancy report

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107884,2022,Learning from big data,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. S Gabel', 'prof.dr. G Liberali']",,"Inhoud

Every day, millions of consumers voice their opinions in product-review websites, blogs, and chat rooms. They spontaneously produce massive amounts of user-generated content (UGC), most of which is textual and freely available for analysis. At the same time, online and offline retailers collect rich data sets that contain valuable information about the purchases of individual customers. In this era of big data, the availability of new, larger, and more diversified data sets creates exciting opportunities for marketing researchers and practitioners.

However, the characteristics of big data (volume, velocity, variety) also pose challenges for modelers. With so much data available, it can be hard to determine what information is correct or how to separate signal from noise. For example, how can you extract information about market structure and consumer preferences from purchase data? To make this even more difficult, UGC data are often unstructured and textual. Do you know how to analyze UGC data? And how do you go from insights to marketing decisions?

All that is needed to address these challenges is the right set of tools and the training that helps you to use the tools correctly. This course first teaches how to formalize marketing problems as statistical models. It then shows how to solve marketing problems by complementing classical econometric techniques with modern machine learning (ML) methods. You will find tools and conceptual frameworks needed to identify and exploit the opportunities that big data sources create.

The course has three modules, each containing lectures and hands-on activities. In the first module (“Mine your Own Business in Blogs, Reviews and Tweets”), we will work with various types of UGC, with a strong emphasis on textual data. We will discuss and use tools to help you automate the detection of both content and sentiment from texts produced by consumers. The second module (“Purchase Prediction with Boosted Trees”) focuses on the application of supervised ML methods to predictive and prescriptive marketing problems. The module also introduces important theoretical and practical principles for designing and implementing ML pipelines. In the third module (“Neural Networks–From Market Structure Analysis to Prescriptive Marketing”), we will use representation learning and deep learning techniques to model market structures in retailing applications and leverage insights for prescriptive marketing applications. There is one major “module assignment” to be handed in at the end of each module. In the assignments you will apply the methods, templates, and scripts seen during the lectures.

This course will push you to develop new analytical skills and to be creative when devising solutions and interpreting your results to understand the consumer behavior that generated the data you are analyzing. In addition, you will not only apply existing modeling libraries but also implement models and algorithms (almost) from scratch. After completing this course, you will be able to judge how modern machine learning methods (ML) complement (or even replace) traditional statistical methods for data analysis and decision-making. The course is designed to prepare you for solving real-world marketing problems using modern quantitative methods and is a good preparation for a ML/data science job in marketing or a PhD in quantitative marketing.
After this course, you will be able to:
Formulate marketing decisions as machine learning tasks.
Build well-structured and robust machine learning data/model pipelines.
Extract relevant insights on consumer preferences and behavior from user-generated content (UGC).
Analyze real-world loyalty card data to solve prescriptive marketing problems.
Collaborate efficiently when working on data science projects in teams.
Infer machine learning best practices from academic literature.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104852,2022,Legal Psychology,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['MS de Roos'],,"Inhoud

<body>Legal psychology aims to apply scientific psychological knowledge to the legal arena, particularly to criminal procedure. Hence, legal psychologists seek to study the behaviour of police, districts attorney, defence lawyer, judge, and jury. These parties may also ask legal psychologists explicitly for assistance. By and large, legal psychologists study the evidence used in court. In this course, various pieces of evidence, such as, witness statements including identifications, and suspect statements will be reviewed.</body>

<body>The main goal of this course is to offer an introduction of legal psychology to the student. The following topics will be introduced during this course: Witness testimony, suspect testimony, lie detection. Besides these specific topics, it is important to gain insight in legal psychology as a discipline, and to appreciate the position of the psychologist in the criminal procedure.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105714,2022,Legal Technology,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr.mr. CA Zweistra', 'prof.dr. EF Stamhuis, LLM']",,"Inhoud

De minor is gericht op juristen, VMO-rechtenstudenten en staat ook open voor studenten fiscaal recht. In de minor maak je kennis met Legal Technology. Je leert Legal Technology begrijpen en gebruiken. Ook ontwikkel je een kritische houding vanuit een ethisch-juridisch kader. Daarmee kun je een bijdrage leveren aan de ontwikkeling en maatschappelijke en organisatorische inpassing van (Legal) Technology. We richten ons op juristen en fiscalisten die zichzelf zien acteren in traditionele (toga) beroepen, maar ook op de nieuwe juridische beroepen zoals: legal data-analyst en Legal Tech-developer.

Binnen de minor leer je te werken aan een oplossing van een real life vraagstuk dat ziet op access-to-justice voor de doelgroep de sociale advocatuur. De centrale ontwerpvraag die je krijgt is of dat doel bereikt kan worden met een Legal Technology én of dat deze tech-oplossing wenselijk is, gegeven de belangen van de doelgroep. Voorts leer je welke ethische aspecten hierbij komen kijken. Gaandeweg maak je kennis met de brede context van Legal Technology. Bij het ontwikkelen van de oplossing volg je een vorm van (Legal) Design Thinking. Het onderwijs vindt plaats via Expert Presentaties, werkcolleges en clinics. Er is een start- en een slotbijeenkomst met de stakeholders. Daarnaast zijn er momenten met externe partijen ingepland, zodat je jouw plan tegen hen kunt aanhouden. De clinics zijn gekoppeld aan de ontwerpfases van Design Thinking en bedoeld om vaardigheden op te doen die nodig zijn voor de ontwikkeling van de Legal Technology.

Je maakt kennis met kansrijke Legal Technology waarbij we specifieke aandacht geven aan verschillende AI-toepassingen, omdat uit die hoek de grote doorbraken worden verwacht in Legal Technology. Je leert de juridisch relevante werking van de technologie te begrijpen, als ook de grenzen en mogelijkheden van technologie.

In de minor vertrekken we vanuit het idee dat (Legal) Technology in staat is ethische en juridische uitgangspunten binnen het recht te transformeren. Technologie zet een nieuwe standaard voor ethiek, voor het recht maar ook voor traditionele werkwijzen binnen het recht. Het is een belangrijk onderdeel van de minor om studenten te laten reflecteren op de standaarden die (Legal) Technology zet zodat ze als jurist kunnen bijdragen aan een verantwoord gebruik, ontwikkeling en inpassing van (Legal) Technology. Ook zul je gaan ontdekken hoe Legal Technology jouw beroepsbeoefening zal transformeren en hoe jij daarop kunt anticiperen door nieuwe vaardigheden op te doen en traditionele vaardigheden te versterken.

Via engagerende onderwijsmethoden, schrijfopdrachten en interactieve clinics bereid jij je voor op de uiteindelijke opdracht die in de slotfase in groepen gerealiseerd moet worden. Die opdracht betreft de ontwikkeling van een oplossing die access-to-justice moet vergroten en/of borgen, eventueel via de ontwikkeling van een Legal Technology. Er is een slotbijeenkomst waarin het voorlopig ontwerp van de oplossing wordt gepresenteerd en een eindopdracht waarin na ontvangst van feedback van stakeholders (‘sluit de oplossing aan op de behoefte van de doelgroep?’) het definitief ontwerp wordt ingediend.

De minor geeft studenten het technologische, ethische en juridische kader om als jurist relevant te blijven in relatie tot disruptieve technologische ontwikkelingen binnen het vakgebied van de jurist.

Leerdoel 1: De student kan na afloop van de minor verschillende toepassingen van Artificiële Intelligentie (AI) en andere kerntechnologieën zoals blockchain in de juridische beroepsuitoefening herkennen en de juridisch relevante werking daarvan beschrijven. &nbsp

Leerdoel 2: De student kan na afloop van de minor identificeren wat de impact is van technologische ontwikkelingen en ontwerpoplossingen op fundamentele ethische en juridische uitgangspunten en hierop reflecteren.

Leerdoel 3: De student kan na afloop van de minor kritisch reflecteren op de positie van de jurist ten opzichte van disruptieve technologische ontwikkelingen en hoe deze de plaats van de jurist wijzigen [Wat is de eigen plaats van de jurist in relatie tot technologische ontwikkelingen in het werkveld van de jurist?].
Leerdoel 4: De student heeft na afloop van de minor inzicht in de effecten van verschillende technologische toepassingen op het professioneel handelen in diverse juridische subdisciplines.
Leerdoel 5: De student kan na afloop van de minor beschrijven op welke manier ethische en juridische uitgangspunten het ontwerp en inpassing van Legal Tech kunnen begeleiden.&nbsp

Leerdoel 6: De student kan na afloop van de minor in samenwerking met anderen een reëel probleem ten aanzien van access-to-justice in kaart brengen en de mogelijke [technologische] oplossingen aandragen met behulp van een te volgen gestandaardiseerde methode [Design Thinking].
Leerdoel 7: De student kan na afloop van de minor actief participeren in de stappen voor het oplossen van vraagstukken in de minor: Analyseren, discussiëren en presenteren.

The aim of the Life Support course is to give you a basic training in acute medicine and to experience ‘real’ working situations with help of some specially trained actors. The emphasis of the course is on the quick recognition of acute situations, clear communication, and adequate handling. We talk about how situations differ between inside and outside of the hospital, and between first-aid and professional medical care personnel.
During the course, the term ‘victim’ is frequently used. This term indicates a person who has an acute, (non-)life threatening disorder in her/his physical or mental health.&nbsp
column2: And who, in her/his own opinion or that of others, needs help. The common theme throughout the course is the ABCDE approach. This protocol is used internationally for the structured assessment and care of an acutely ill or wounded patient. In this course, the basic principles of this protocol will be taught. You will also learn e.g. how to assess the safety of a situation, call for help and perform CPR with or without the help an automated external defibrillator (AED).</body>

column1: <body>Following this programme, the student is able to:
<li>Assess the vital functions according to the ABCDE protocol and provide adequate treatment to disorders of the vital functions
<li>Carry out adequate resuscitation according to NRR guidelines when faced with circulatory arrest
<li>Provide adequate First Aid to accident victims (including treatment of wounds and bites

Literary movements and - styles do not emerge in a vacuum but are closely related to their proponent’s relation to the literary tradition, their reaction to their social context and their attitudes towards the future. There is, in other words, a politics of literature as much as a literature of politics. From the Romantic poet Percy Bysshe Shelly to contemporary hip-hop icon Kendrick Lamar, literary artists have been unambiguously preoccupied with questions of power, resistance and agency. Taking the emergence of ‘modern’ literature around 1800 as a starting point, this course will trace some of the relations between literature and politics up until the present. Rather than privileging one type of politics of literature over the other, students will engage with multifarious constellations of literature and politics through different theoretical orientations, historical contexts and literary genres. Each week will be centred around a particular theme (e.g. Literary Autonomy, The Politics of Literary Form, Literature and Community). We will read theoretical texts in conjunction with literary texts, from graphic novels to radical poetry and from feminist auto-fiction to utopian afrosci-fi. Ultimately, this course aims to provide students with the conceptual and analytical tools to reflect on and reimagine the possible relations between literature and politics.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107949,2022,Logic, Information, and Communication",Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,"['dr. F Van De Putte', 'dr. S Wintein']",,"Inhoud

What is information? Can we measure the amount of information conveyed by a message, or the (average) informativeness of a given source? Can we somehow capture the intuition that the more informative a source is, the more questions it answers? What does it mean to become informed about a certain state of affairs – what is informational content? When is information genuinely new or plainly redundant? If I have information about your information, then what can I infer from it – what is the logic of such higher-order information? And what do each of us individually have to know, for us as a group to know something? What are the effects of communication on the information states of those individuals and groups who are involved in such communication? Can information or informative questions be self-referential or even self-contradictory?

These questions involve numerous theoretical concepts and distinctions but are also of great importance for how we study communication, information, and cognition in practice. The primary aim of this course is to familiarize the student with standard theoretical perspectives on information, with some elementary models from philosophical logic that help to make them precise, and with important philosophical criticisms and shortcomings of the standard perspectives.

The course consists of a traditional, lecture-based part (70%) that introduces the above-mentioned topics and concepts, and a second part (30%) in which the students get to do some research on those topics, focusing on one journal article or book chapter, and with the primary aim of understanding the relation between such specific work and the overall theme of the course.
An overview of the course’s content (with one module per lecture week) is available on canvas.</body>

• Explain and illustrate key distinctions and notions in the philosophy of information: quantitative vs. qualitative measures of information, syntactic versus semantic theories of information, factivity, entropy, redundancy.

• Use tools and notions from propositional logic to explain in what sense information is “new” compared to a given body of information or when two pieces of information are “compatible”, and to model simple informational updates in terms of truth tables.
• Explain and apply the basic methodology and insights from the theory of belief revision.
• Use tools and notions from modal logic to reason about higher-order and group information.

• Create and solve knight-knave riddles and explain how doing so relates to the mathematical theory of communication, in particular to query problems and strategies, expected query length, Huffman coding, and data compression.

• Explain, via the frameworks of assertoric semantics, howself-referential questions can be invoked to solve knight-knave riddles and query problems more efficiently and relate such questions to the Liar paradox, which
column2: shows that our firmest intutions concerning truth are inreconcilable with classical logic.

column1: • Explain and criticize some received philosophical views on assertion, in particular on those theories according to which assertion is characterized by a constitutive norm such as truth, knowledge or justified belief.
• Read and critically appraise original work in the philosophy of information, philosophy of language, and/or philosophical logic, and present it to peers and lecturers
• Use original work in the philosophy of information, philosophy of language, and/or philosophical logic to develop an original opinion on a specific issue relevant for the course.
Entrance Requirements: enrolled in Philosophy OR Philosophy of a Scientific Discipline + succesful completion of either “Inleiding Logica” or “Foundations of Philosophy”.

Mergers and Acquisitions are regular occurrences in the corporate world. Firms are acquiring other organizations for different strategic purposes: To diversify, to scale up, or to eliminate competition. They often present highly disruptive events for parties both within and outside the focal organizations. However, given their high degree of risk and complexity, mergers and acquisitions frequently fail to realize their intended objectives. In this course we review the most important research findings on M&
column2: A and discuss frameworks, theories, and case examples. We start by revisiting the foundations of corporate strategy and discuss the central but elusive role of synergies therein. We cover the decision-making stage related to buying and selling businesses and the implementation stage related to integration and separation. We focus on the different actors involved in these processes and examine their motives. We delve into the most frequent challenges and potential ways of mitigation. Adopting a behavioral lens, we focus on common biases, such as the overestimation of synergy potential and the underestimation of implementation complexity. We discuss the role of M&amp
column3: A in the long-term evolution of the corporate portfolio and the management of acquisition programs. We then zoom out to review the history of M&amp
column4: A and its impact on consumers and society at large. We explore the phenomenon of merger waves and bandwagon behavior, and finally examine the role of activist investors and private equity firms in connection with M&amp

Students that would like to gain some practical experience during the Master program, can do so by means of an internship. Students can use one of the elective blocks to do a full time internship.&nbsp

Instead of an elective a so-called business project can be carried out. This business project will be shorter than a regular internship. The advantage is that such a project can be carried out during one of the three elective blocks. A student can come up with a business project at a company of his or her choice. At the end of the internship the student will hand in a report.&nbsp

The business project can be related to the thesis. However, this is not a requirement. Please not that even the two are linked, the business project will be assessed separately from the thesis itself and should contain another focus than the thesis. Please consult your thesis coach in case you want to combine your internship with you thesis.&nbsp
<u>THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR MI STUDENTS ONLY. IN OTHER WORDS</u>: in order to graduate you MUST complete at least two MI programme electives!</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105442,2022,Machine Learning,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. A Alfons', 'dr. MH Akyuz', 'MFO Welz', 'prof.dr. DJC van Dijk']",,"Inhoud

While traditional statistical and econometric methods often rely on strict model assumptions, methods from statistical learning and machine learning can provide more flexibility. This flexibility is achieved by a nonparametric nature of machine learning techniques, but also through so-called hyperparameters, which have to be tuned via validation procedures.

The focus of this course is to develop a theoretical understanding of the discussed methodology. In addition, possible applications in different fields of economics, finance, and operations research will be illustrated by discussing recent journal articles and working papers. Students will gain deeper insights through mathematical exercises, as well as practical experience with applying the techniques in R or Python through hands-on exercises.
• Understanding the workings of fundamental supervised and unsupervised machine learning techniques
• Gaining deeper insights into the statistical theory behind the methods
• Applying the methods in R or Python
• Evaluating the performance of the methods in a systematic way
- Format: in-person lectures (possibly recorded) with additional short videos instead of full video lectures
- Content: while the six major topics remain unchanged, there are some changes with respect to which techniques are discussed for each topic
<body>Two intermediate reports and a final exam.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106098,2022,Machine Learning & Learning Algorithms,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. PB Cornelius', 'dr. PC Schoonees']",,"Inhoud

Machine learning is a key driver of the success of data-driven decision-making in business. It enables practitioners to learn from experience, as encoded in data, to understand business-relevant processes or to predict the future. It is an essential tool in the modern data scientist's toolbox.

This course provides a hands-on introduction to the concepts, principles and key algorithms for supervised and unsupervised machine learning. You will learn how these algorithms work and practice applying them to solve business problems. Attention will also be paid to principles, concepts and best practices which are required to apply these methods judiciously in practice, such as generalization, overfitting, resampling methods and evaluation metrics. The supervised and unsupervised machine learning algorithms covered will include decision trees, random forests, neural networks, cluster analysis and gradient boosting machines.

column2: Learning Algorithms is a core course in the MScBA Business Analytics &
column3: Management programme. It builds on knowledge obtained in the pre-modules and other core courses, with specific emphasis on statistics and programming. It provides knowledge and skills which will be leveraged to varying degrees by the elective courses.

column1: After taking this course, students will be able to:
• Discuss key concepts and principles of machine learning, such as the data mining process, generalization, overfitting, model assessment methods and metrics, and the bias-variance trade-off
• Understand and compare several fundamental supervised and unsupervised machine learning algorithms
• Apply these machine learning algorithms to business problems and their accompanying data sets in a principled way using R
• Demonstrate critical thinking when assessing the merits of machine learning projects

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108151,2022,Macroeconomics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['AG Andrei, MSc', 'dr. P Darnihamedani', 'I Rajabzadeh']",,"Inhoud

This elective course aims to broaden students’ perspectives and knowledge about Macroeconomics. Macroeconomic conditions not only affect us all in our daily lives, but business managers need to have a basic understanding of macroeconomics for a more comprehensive view of the market conditions, to be better equipped to respond to major macroeconomic events such as sudden increases in interest rates, or inflation, or even sudden resource scarcity (see the disruptions resulting from the war started by Russia in Ukraine). Incorporating a basic understanding of macroeconomic factors and how the economic environment affects the business one, may give managers a significant competitive advantage by either helping them seize new opportunities or avoid costly errors. As individuals, we care about how inflation affects our abilities to pay for goods and services, how interest rates influence our access to financial resources, or how labor market conditions or technological developments affect our abilities to obtain specific jobs.

The range of topics covers the evolution of Macroeconomics and its theories, global instabilities, and their implications. This elective incorporates theory, practical applications, and economic puzzles, all relevant in a dynamic world. We start with identifying the primary schools of thought in the field, which is essential to anyone struggling to understand why macroeconomists so often issue divergent opinions on the same event (e.g., global economic crises). We then continue with an applied perspective on the classical key Macroeconomic indicators and look at the short-run and medium-run. In addition to learning about the key indicators in their theoretical form, students will get a chance to see how these work in practice by playing a game (the Econland simulation). Finally, major economic crises of the past century are reviewed, in addition to discussing the macroeconomic impact of phenomena such as crypto-currencies and political instabilities in critical world regions. This course extends the knowledge gained during the first-year Economics course
column2: it aims to give students a broader perspective on the wider environment in which companies develop and execute their strategies.

column1: <body>After following this course, the student is able to:
• Describe and compare the different schools of thought in Macroeconomics.
• Understand the dynamics of an economy, more specifically, concepts of monetary and fiscal policy, aggregate demand, and aggregate supply.
• Evaluate an economy’s state and recognize the potential for improving the country’s economic health.
• Assess the impact/potential impact of macroeconomic factors/conditions/decisions on population approval ratings and implications for businesses
• Critically assess the potential impact of unpredicted events (see covid-19 &

Macroeconomics is the study of the economy as a whole, rather than of individual markets. It studies how aggregate-economy indicators, such as GDP, inflation and unemployment, behave, in particular how they react to economic shocks and policy decisions. Two areas of macroeconomics stand out: the study of the causes and consequences of short-run fluctuations in national income (the business cycle), and that of the determinants of long-run economic growth. In this course, we will develop simple macroeconomic models that allow us to analyse the behaviour of the main macroeconomic aggregates in the short, medium, and long run. We will see how these models and their predictions can be used to understand real-world debates.

<div>In this course, we will develop a simple macroeconomic model that allows us to analyse the evolution of the main macroeconomic aggregates in the short, medium and long run. We will also critically discuss policy debates, so that we directly observe how economic theory can be used to understand the real world.&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107340,2022,Macroeconomics II (Macroeconomic Policy),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud

The course builds on Macroeconomics I and applies dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models to the analysis of monetary and fiscal policy. It consists of four main parts. In the first part, we compare the inequality implications of a complete markets and a standard incomplete markets model when households face idiosyncratic income risk. Afterwards, we develop a basic competitive equilibrium framework which serves as the main building block for the course. The second part focuses on the role of fiscal policy. Here, effects of government spending, the role of public debt, and optimal taxation under commitment will be discussed. The third part introduces money into the framework and derives principles for optimal monetary policy under perfectly flexible prices. Further, the issues of monetary policy implementation and the determination of the price level will be addressed. The last part extends monetary policy analysis to the case where prices are imperfectly flexible. Within this framework optimal monetary policy under commitment and discretion will be examined.
Learning goals for this course: students should have learned to
1. understand the link between insurance and individual consumption
2. solve dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models
3. show whether a long-run equilibrium exists and is unique, and derive conditions for a unique and stable set of policy functions
4. formally compute optimal tax and monetary policies in general equilibrium models
5. understand the economic mechanism why a certain policy is optimal</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107341,2022,Macroeconomics III (Frictions and Resource Allocation),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['EJ Bartelsman'],,Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. E.J. Bartelsman (VU) and Prof. P. Gautier (VU)

Key macro indicators— unemployment, GDP, and productivity growth— may not follow the optimal paths determined in a frictionless economy. Recent models are much more careful in dealing with frictions agents face in reality, such as entry and exit fees, delays in finding transaction partners, information asymmetries, and limited contract enforcement. In this course, we explore the implications of heterogeneous agents facing various frictions that frustrate the allocation of resources in labor, capital and product markets.

By studying these models, students not only learn key aspects of three important topics in macroeconomics, namely labor market developments, business cycle analysis, and long-run growth, but also key building blocks that are useful by themselves.

We briefly discuss empirical regularities observed in the data regarding labor markets, firm demographics and productivity growth. After highlighting the difficulties of standard models to explain these regularities, we explore recent modifications. We start the labor market and discuss different ways to model how agents search, match, and bargain over prices. More specific examples are wage posting, Nash bargaining, and directed search. Next we turn to growth models of heterogeneous firms and study the implications of frictions for static and dynamic efficiency. Special attention will be paid to frictions in capital investment.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107281,2022,Making Traditions in Everyday Life,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. HC Dibbits', 'dr. I Gusc', 'L Zurné, MA']",,"Inhoud

In this class, we investigate the making of traditions in both informal and formal settings. The focus will be on everyday material culture. Both in the academic field as in the wider heritage domain, there has been a growing interest in the culture of everyday life and ordinary things. Historians and ethnologists study the generational transmission and appropriation of repertoires of everyday culture, and many museums develop exhibitions on everyday practices, displaying ordinary objects. The findings of historical and ethnological research, exhibition projects and educational programmes will be confronted with each other and discussed in a broader cultural context, with the aim of coming to a better understanding of different forms of tradition making.
• Students can analyse processes of tradition making in various contexts (formal and informal, public and private) using ethnological methods and approaches
• Students can critically and analytically relate to academic and professional discourses on the dynamics of everyday culture
• Students can create their own vision on ethical and practical dilemma’s that heritage professionals are confronted with

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107676,2022,Management Accounting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. F Elsinger', 'dr. S Kramer']",,"Inhoud

Management accounting is at the heart of high-quality decision-making. Modern financial managers are not only concerned with how cost data are transformed into accounting information, but more importantly how to use cost accounting information to support decision-making and accomplish organizational goals.

Management accounting is therefore much more than number crunching – ultimately its function is to gather and analyse information to advise strategy and drive sustainable business success. This course provides students with a good exposure to managerial accounting tools and techniques and their practical application to business managers. Students in this course will learn how to combine financial and non-financial data to paint a complete picture of the business and to support several aspects of management. Emphasis will also be given to the emerging role of business analytics to inform business decisions. In addition to accounting and analytical skills, management accounting requires an understanding of the organisation, its business model, its strategic context and its competitive position, as well as being alert to the organisation’s social and environmental responsibilities.

The course should develop the student's understanding, skills, and analytic ability in management accounting to the level where she/he can function effectively as a professional management accountant/financial controller in industry, auditing firms, management consulting, or governmental organizations.
Students successfully completing this course will be able to:

• Classify and understand different types of costs (e.g., product costs vs. period costs, direct vs. indirect costs, and fixed vs. variable cost) and identify various concepts of costs (e.g., opportunity costs, sunk costs, marginal costs, average costs)
• Understand the flow of data in an accounting information system, apply data analytics techniques, and interpret results to answer business questions
• Develop cost functions, execute a cost-volume-profit analysis and apply alternative cost accounting systems
• Describe a typical organization's process of budget administration and compose the different elements of the master budget
• Distinguish between static and flexible budgets, execute variance analysis to assess organizational performance and formulate improvement plans
• Analyse and evaluate the organizational implications of alternative models of responsibility accounting and performance measurement systems
• Select what accounting information is useful to support internal decision making, planning and control

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107145,2022,Management Consultancy & Policy Advice,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. PM Karre', 'SN Blok, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Public Administration experts, both in science and practice, have to contribute to complex societal issues. The knowledge students got in the first two years of their bachelor program enables them to analyse these issues. This module offers them new theoretical, conceptual and practical knowledge and competences to formulate advices and design solutions, to bridge the gap between the current situation (“ist”) and the desired situation (“soll”). Core of the module ‘Organisation and Policy Consultancy” is to enhance these analytical, design-oriented and advising skills of students.

This module builds upon the theoretical approaches presented in the various modules on “Policy” and “Organisation and Management”. Students have to apply their knowledge in policy processes and public organisations, to analyse complex policy and organisational issues and to formulate solution-oriented advices. They develop a repertoire of skills for professional advising. In addition they learn how to assess whether the conditions for successful policy or organizational change are present.
<body>After successfully completing this course, the student is able to:
<li>Describe the relevant aspects of management consultancy and policy advice in the public domain and its contextual factors
<li>Describe current trends in management consultancy and policy advice in the public domain
<li>Formulate the various steps in consultancy and advice processes and select suitable tools
<li>Make a problem analysis / diagnosis of a complex policy or organisational issue
<li>Design a policy advice or an organizational change intervention in a concrete case
<li>Formulate a convincing, valid and practical usable policy advice or management recommendation
<li>Reflect upon the relationship between clients and advisors and the mechanisms and values that constitute this relationship
<li>Reflect upon the quality of advising in the public domain and its dark sides
<li>Reflect upon the ethical dimensions of consultancy and policy advice
• Formulate and assess the conditions for successful adoption and uptake of advices in the public domain.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106620,2022,Management Control,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. E Reusen', 'prof.dr. M van Rinsum']",,"Inhoud

​Management Control Systems (MCS) form the bridge between the organization’s strategy and its operations/services. Their purpose is to align managerial behaviour and decision making with organizational strategic goals. Although financial management tools are typically crucial &nbsp
column2: in an organization’s MCS, the design and use of a MCS does not only require an understanding of accounting techniques. It should also be based on a thorough understanding of how managerial behaviour is influenced by relevant control system elements, such as target setting, performance measurement and monetary incentives. Indeed, as the proper design of MCS is paramount for organizational performance, organizational failure can often be attributed to a poor design or implementation of the organization’s management control system. Past scandals such as the collapse of Enron and the recent crisis in the financial sector can be directly traced back to failures in MCS design. The emphasis of the course is on the analysis and understanding of the drivers of managerial (rational and irrational) decision making in complex organizations rather than on the application of accounting tools often associated with financial management.

column1: The course strongly focuses on the managerial issues faced by CFOs of multinational companies. Meetings are case-based: students discuss (financial) management control topics in close relation to case studies of multinational companies. The assignments/tests will allow students to show their theoretical knowledge, but also their understanding of how to apply it to real-life case situations.
By the end of the course, students should be familiar with:
• Requirements for effective management control systems to induce goal-congruent behaviour
• Elements of a well-designed Management Control System (MCS)
• Fit between the firm’s MCS and its environment
• Psychological and economic views on decision-making in contemporary organisations

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106153,2022,Management Control,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. E Reusen', 'prof.dr. M van Rinsum']",,"Inhoud

Management Control is about influencing the behavior of managers to act in line with the organization’s strategic objectives. In this course, we discuss what alternatives organizations have for ensuring good control, and how organizations should choose among control system alternatives. The main emphasis throughout the course will be on financial results control systems, which provide the dominant form of control in the vast majority of organizations. Topics covered include responsibility structures, target setting (as part of organizations’ planning and budgeting processes), performance measurement and evaluation, and the assignment of various forms of organizational rewards (including performance-dependent compensation).&nbsp

Illustrations based on real-world cases are discussed, demonstrating when particular control systems are effective, and when they lead to dysfunctional managerial behavior. Ample attention is also paid to the fit with the organizational context, such as the strategy, structure, and culture. The latter part of the course extends the key notions of management control from the intra-organizational level to the inter-organizational level, highlighting some of the issues involved in the control of new collaborative settings and configurations, such as joint-ventures and various types of alliances, often involving global alliance partners.&nbsp

Overall, this course is intended to broaden and deepen your conceptual and technical understanding of accounting as it is used for management control purposes. It will help you learn to make business decisions, evaluate organizational performance, or evaluate others (and/or be evaluated) through the use of financial and nonfinancial information. These are essential skills for your future career, be it in the position of managers, management consultants, or specialists in staff functions such as controllers, auditors, or human resource specialists.&nbsp
On completion of this course, students should be able to:
<li>Understand the purpose of a management accounting &amp
column2: control system, and how it relates to strategy implementation

column1: <li>Describe and evaluate different types of controls dependent on the type of organization and its structure
<li>List the crucial characteristics of performance measures and apply the principles of performance measurement
<li>Identify the (dys-)functional effects of performance measurement and reward systems
<li>Evaluate and use different performance measurement and evaluation techniques, such as EVA and BSC
<li>Describe the logic behind contingency theory and exemplify how situational factors might influence the management control system in an organization
<li>Explain the main drivers behind the development and increased importance of inter-organizational relationships and related control issues
<li>Approach management control related questions from different theoretical perspectives, using economic and behavioral theory
• Identify, analyze and provide solutions to management control problems covered in this course.

column1: In this course you will learn how to use data and management science tools and models to make informed decisions in a variety of business contexts. Models are approximations, reflecting the most relevant, but not all, aspects of reality. You will learn to decouple the assumptions from the analysis and develop a well grounded appreciation for the value-adding potential of quantitative thinking but also the need to critically evaluate model outputs.&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107663,2022,Management accounting,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. F Elsinger', 'dr. S Kramer']",,"Inhoud

Management Accounting is een vakgebied dat zich richt op het verzamelen, ordenen, interpreteren, presenteren en gebruiken van cost accounting informatie ten behoeve van de besluitvorming door het management in organisaties.

Management accounting is derhalve veel meer dan louter rekenwerk of “number crunching” – het ultieme doel is de besluitvorming te ondersteunen en duurzame organisatiedoelen te bereiken. Dit vak geeft studenten een goede inleiding tot management accounting tools en technieken en de praktische toepassing hiervan voor moderne financiële managers. Studenten leren in dit vak hoe financiële en niet-financiële informatie te combineren, en op een vertrouwde manier met data-analyse om te gaan. Naast accounting en analytische vaardigheden, vereist management accounting een goed begrip van de organisatie, het businessmodel, de strategische context en positie in de markt, met aandacht voor duurzaam beleid.

De cursus zal het inzicht, de vaardigheden en het analytisch vermogen in management accounting van de student ontwikkelen tot het niveau waar hij/zij effectief kan functioneren als een professionele management accountant/financial controller in het bedrijfsleven, accountantskantoren, management consulting, of overheidsinstellingen</body>
<body>Studenten die dit vak met succes hebben afgerond zijn specifiek in staat om:

• De verschillende typen kosten in organisaties te classificeren (bv. productkosten vs. periodekosten, directe vs. indirecte kosten, vaste vs. variabele kosten) en diverse kostenconcepten te identificeren (bv. opportuniteitskosten, gezonken kosten, marginale kosten, gemiddelde kosten)
• Technieken in data-analyse te begrijpen, toe te passen, en resultaten te interpreteren, ter ondersteuning van de besluitvorming
• Kostenfuncties te ontwikkelen, cost-volume-profit analyses uit te voeren, en alternatieve kostenallocatietechnieken toe te passen
• Het budget proces in een organisatie te beschrijven en de budgetschema’s die samen het master budget vormen op te stellen
• Statische en flexibele budgetten te onderscheiden en variantieanalyses uit te voeren om prestaties te evalueren en verbeterplannen voor te stellen
• Implicaties voor organisaties van alternatieve modellen van responsibility accounting en prestatiemeting te bepalen
• Accounting informatie te selecteren die relevant is om interne plannings-, beleids- en beheersingsbesluiten te nemen

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106499,2022,Management and Leadership in Media Organizations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. S Horst'],,"Inhoud

The current challenges in media organizations and the media industry, such as the ongoing COVID-19 crisis, more generally a growing mediatization of organizations and society, rising competition, and an increasing complexity of organizational issues make managing and leading processes and practices of strategy and change highly relevant.

The course provides an overview of key theories and topics around strategy, management and leadership and works towards their reflective adaptation and implementation in media organizations and other mediated contexts. Students will comprehend and evaluate classical and modern approaches from managing change and strategy to competitive forces, industry analysis, resources and strategy processes and practices.

On this basis, we will discuss the possibilities of managing and leading individuals, teams and organizations through communication in strategic manner. Through diverse activities, students will apply these theories and approaches sensibly and creatively for learning how to develop successful actions in/for practice.
<li>Current concepts, approaches and theories of strategic management and leadership that are relevant for&nbsp
<li>How media organizations and practitioners strategically manage processes and practices around individuals,&nbsp
<li>Identify the need for and function of strategic management and leadership in their context
<li>Apply strategy and leadership approaches and theories reflectively
• Lead social and organizational action through communication.
