This course teaches the fundamentals of managing, leading, and organizing in the media and creative industries and the strategic conduct of organizations that heavily rely on digitally mediated communication and distribution. Amidst fundamental changes in the media and creative industries, we will address, learn, and reflect upon the relevant management and leadership concepts and skills that current and future challenges require.

The course builds a social constructivist understanding of management and organizations, and a practice-theoretical view on strategy, leadership, change, and culture. It integrates both the managing of creativity, projects, innovation and technology, as well as dealing with transformation, uncertainty and risk. We will focus on a variety of industry contexts, such as for example digital gaming, film, music, publishing and streaming platforms.
The course is structured around (1) Theory &amp
column2: Expertise and (2) Transfer, Application and Reflection seminars. Through this structure we will reflectively integrate a variety of advanced discussions into industry and context-specific cases and challenges. Industry experts will share their insights on specific sub-sectors of the media &amp

column1: • The specific character of organization and management in the media and creative industries.
• Current theories, approaches and debates in this field.
• Systematically analyze and critically reflect on fundamental and practical challenges in managing and organizing contemporary media and creative industries firms.
• Find alternatives and solutions for challenges that media and creative companies are facing.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107661,2022,Management van technologie,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['LMM Gross, MSc', 'MJ Iwanczuk-Prost', 'prof.dr. DA Stam', 'SGM Langeveld, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Technologie is al eeuwenlang één van de belangrijkste pijlers van de economie. Zowel in de productiegerichte sectoren als in dienstverlenende bedrijven speelt technologie een belangrijke rol. Zonder technologische vooruitgang verliezen bedrijven concurrentiekracht. Managers staan voor de vraag op welke manier zij optimaal gebruik kunnen maken van technologie. Welke technologie is beschikbaar en welke technologische ontwikkelingen zijn gaande? Welke gevolgen kan technologie hebben voor een bedrijf, een sector en de maatschappij? Welke betekenis heeft technologie voor de strategie van het bedrijf wat betreft de producten/diensten, de productieprocessen, en de kerncompetenties? Kortom, hoe kunnen managers technologieën herkennen en op een juiste wijze inpassen binnen het bedrijf? In dit vak zul je een technologie strategie ontwikkelen voor een high-tech technologie toegepast in een kernproduct van het casebedrijf door technische en bedrijfskundige criteria te combineren.

Het vak staat in het teken van management van “high-tech” technologieën. Je zult kijken naar een specifieke “high-tech” technologie die een essentieel onderdeel is van een product (B2B of B2C) van het bedrijf dat jouw case heeft ingebracht. Deze technologie kan echter verouderen vanwege opkomende nieuwe technologieën. De opkomende technologieën hebben dezelfde functionaliteit als de huidige technologie, maar zouden (in de toekomst) meer waarde kunnen toevoegen aan het product van het bedrijf en zijn klanten. Daarom is het belangrijk om de technologische ontwikkelingen te volgen en te overwegen om voor een opkomende technologie te kiezen om de concurrenten voor te blijven. Hierbij gaat het niet om de vraag hoe aan een marktvraag kan worden voldaan door middel van technologie (“market pull”), maar hoe technologieën kunnen worden benut voor de vernieuwing van de producten/diensten, de productieprocessen, en de kerncompetenties van een bedrijf (“technology push”).

Het is echter niet vanzelfsprekend om over te stappen op een (technologisch gezien) beter alternatief. Het introduceren van een opkomende technologie kan grote effecten hebben op het product, het productieproces, het bedrijf zelf en zijn omgeving. Daarom moeten managers de opkomende en de huidige technologieën zorgvuldig evalueren en met elkaar vergelijken, inclusief hun effecten. De hoofdvraag in dit vak luidt dan ook: moet het bedrijf overstappen op een van de opkomende technologieën?

Het doel van het vak is het schrijven van een strategisch plan voor een bestaand bedrijf (case bedrijf) met een high-tech product waarin een alternatieve technologie kan worden toegepast. Om dit doel te behalen moet je eerst de huidige situatie verkennen (opdracht 1). Daarna zul je geschikte opkomende technologieën analyseren en hun eventuele impact op het bedrijf onderzoeken (opdracht 2). Vervolgens combineer je deze informatie in een voorstel voor een technologie strategie (opdracht 3), welke je zult samenvatten tijdens een presentatie voor je medestudenten.

Het vak kan gerelateerd worden aan SDG Goal 9: Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation. Onderdeel van opdracht 2 en 3 is het in acht nemen van de (maatschappelijke) omgeving bij de implementatie van de opkomende technologieën.
<body>Na het volgen van dit vak, is de student in staat om:&nbsp
<li>Zijn/haar rol in een collaboratieve groep te managen&nbsp
• De impact van een technologie op een organisatie en haar omgeving kritisch te evalueren
• Een strategische aanbeveling te communiceren voor een bedrijf met betrekking tot hun toekomstige gebruik van technologieën

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106119,2022,Managing Business Strategically,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. EA Ubert', 'dr. MG Baaij', 'dr. P Darnihamedani', 'dr. S Liu']",,"Inhoud

Strategic management is a discipline at the forefront of business research and practice. In this advanced course on strategic management, focus is particularly on what is perhaps the most pressing issue for practicing managers: how can I make my firm outperform its competitors? To formulate such value-creating strategies, managers must identify a suitable business model, formulate strategies, identify core capabilities, learn from their and others’ experiences, and develop new ways of outcompeting their rivals. Firms also must increasingly navigate more complex environments such as business ecosystems as well respond to rapid technological innovations, such as for example new digital technologies. Typically, managers must make such choices and formulate their strategies in conditions of uncertainty or ambiguity. To develop such a holistic view on business, students in this course will be exposed to the key aspects and challenges of putting in place a system that delivers and captures value under such conditions.

The emphasis does not lay on identifying the “right” answer. Instead, the focus of this course is on creating a learning environment that stimulates students’ critical engagement with the study material. Teaching methods therefore include a combination of lectures, group assignments, and online quizzes. To develop their knowledge, skills, and attitudes, students will read articles from leading academic and managerial journal as well as analyze business cases. Students must prepare the assigned material prior to each class to be able to be able to contribute to the interactive classroom discussions as well as being able to complete the group assignments. To support students learning experience, the instructor will be available for questions during these assignments.</body>
At the end of this course students will be able
• to describe the value of scientific research for business strategy practice
• to integrate different theoretical perspectives to develop business strategies to realize organizational goals in uncertain and ambiguous environments
<li>to evaluate what capabilities influence firms’ ability to successfully outperform their competitors in dynamic industries
• to formulate potential solutions to a key strategic problem to the satisfaction of a real-world company.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106387,2022,Managing Cultural Heritage,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. DM Horgan', 'dr. TJ Hoebink']",,"Inhoud

<body>By studying relevant literature on cultural heritage management, students will gain knowledge of the intertwining character of heritage, tourism, economy, culture and (local) identity. Subsequently they will be challenged to apply their theoretical knowledge to concrete case studies which will require them to carry out field work on location. The course will highlight the strategies that can be put in place to ensure the better preservation of cultural heritage while stimulating tourism. Literature discussions, interviews and field trips will provide a varied didactic program with a hands-on attitude.</body>

<div>The purpose of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills to apply their theoretical knowledge to concrete real-life cases. Students become familiar with the major trends and challenges in the world of cultural heritage management and how heritage management could go together with place-making and the creation of sustainable tourism. Moreover, students will gain knowledge of the experiences of various actors in the field of cultural heritage management and their insider’s view on current developments.&nbsp
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108834,2022,Managing Diversity,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['RJ Moelijker, MSc']",,"Inhoud

This course will provide insights into the complex topic of diversity in organizations and will examine how diversity can effectively be managed in organizations. At the end of the course, students understand the core diversity theories and empirical research insights, can critically evaluate the operation and effects of diversity across individual, team, and organizational levels, and apply their learnings to real-world diversity challenges by identifying how human resource management (HRM) can contribute to the effective management of diversity in organizations. &nbsp
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Having an understanding of the core diversity theories and most relevant scholarly insights on diversity.&nbsp
• Being able to approach diversity from a holistic perspective considering its complexity operating across levels (individual, team, organization) and contexts.
• Being able to apply diversity theory and research to real-world challenges around the management of diversity.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109110,2022,Managing Innovation Strategically,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. H Fasaei'],,"Inhoud

Increasingly, in today’s fast paced, converging world, sustained innovation is a necessity not only to thrive but also to survive. However, for most firms, the strategies and processes associated with innovation remain vague and are not strategically managed. As a result, most firms are unable to innovate successfully, and thus fail to create meaningful value for their customers.

In this course, we will learn how firms could create and capture meaningful value for their customers. The aim of the course is to provide a set of concepts and theories as well as practical tools and processes that can be used by managers in their organizations to manage innovation more strategically.

The course is taught in a very interactive fashion. Therefore, attendance is essential and your participation matters. The format is intense, but allows you to focus on the subject matter and to have engaging debates in the classroom. Consequently, the course will provide you with an insightful and fun learning environment. Applying the theoretical and practical knowledge is a central aspect of this course. Therefore, it will include several practical examples and cases.

All sessions will be highly interactive, with sufficient room for discussion, group presentations focusing on applying the theory to practical examples, and small group exercises. The approach is strongly participative and based on the co-creation method of learning. Co-creation involves developing deeper relationships between you and me as the facilitator, and between you and other learning partners in the class. Education is perceived as a shared endeavor where learning and teaching are done with you not to you. Co-creation method of teaching and learning is therefore a collaborative, reciprocal process through which all participants have the opportunity to contribute equally, although not necessarily in the same ways, to curricular or pedagogical conceptualization, decision making, implementation, investigation, or analysis. Hence, in the spirit of fruitful in-class discussion, you are expected to come prepared to class by having read the mandatory readings and watched the mandatory videos.

Each week, we will have team assignments to be prepared for the next session. You will be working on the assignment pertinent to the theme and content of the next session during the week, and you will then present your outcome of the assignment in terms of a presentation in the next session, and we will have profound and in-depth debates/discussions about your presentations. This way, we will learn a lot by doing and by engaging in intellectual discussions and debates.

In order to have interesting sessions and to benefit from them to the fullest, you need to come to the class well-prepared. Beside the fact that the nature of the course is intense and highly interactive and an important part of the assessment is based on the peer evaluation of your performance in preparing and delivering the weekly team assignments, there has been always a very high positive correlation between active engagement in team assignment preparations and in-class discussions and debates on the one hand, and final performance in the individual assignment on the other hand. Therefore, ultimate preparation and engagement in all aspects of this course are vital to have an enjoyable journey, benefit from the learning style of the course, and perform well in the assessment parts of the course. Hence, this elective is only suitable for those who have the time and passion to fully dedicate themselves to the course, attend all classes, and engage fully in preparing and delivering the team assignments and the interactive parts of each session.
At the end of this course students will be able to:
• Understand the importance of managing innovation strategically
• Remember, understand and analyze the determinants of managing innovation strategically and its underlying challenges
• Analyze, apply, and evaluate the theories and concepts of the course related to purpose-driven innovation and disruptive innovation to manage innovation strategically

• Analyze and apply the theories and concepts of the course to be able to create innovative experiences and unique opportunities by emotional journey design, and to communicate innovation persuasively through storytelling

• Cultivating -via understating, remembering, analyzing, applying, evaluating, and creating- competencies related to expertise, by gaining invaluable and practical insights about managing innovation strategically
column2: critical thinking, by applying the concepts and models of managing innovation strategically in preparing the team assignments and evaluating various ideas in the debates
column3: collaborating, by cooperating with various individuals with different insights in doing the team assignments and engaging in presentations and debates in class
column4: communicating, by presenting novel ideas and also engaging in debates and discussions
column6: becoming a positive impact agent, by solving problems that make a difference in the society via innovation and leading change by leading purpose-driven innovations

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104818,2022,Managing Interactive Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. IF van Meerkerk', 'dr. MJ Nederhand']",,"Inhoud

<body><span style=""color:#2980b9"">This course focuses on management in the context of interactive governance. Interactive forms of governance are on the rise in many countries due to several societal developments. They refer to processes in which multiple governmental and non-governmental actors interact in formulating or implementing public policy, services and decision-making. In addition to other courses in the Master programs, this course pays specific attention to both government-induced forms of interactive governance (citizen participation, public-private partnerships) and citizen-induced forms of interactive governance (community-based initiatives). The first means that governments organize citizen involvement in complex projects or initiate partnerships with private sector actors
column2: the latter indicates that citizens and communities themselves show self-organizing capacity and initiative for the preparation, implementation and maintenance of public services in different sectors for example: sustainable energy, health and urban development.

column1: Interactive forms of governance offer important potential for enhancing effectiveness, public support, empowerment and democratic quality of policy and decision-making processes, but are also challenging existing ways of working by governments and raise issues of accountability, inclusion and transparency. This course focuses on the potential and challenges of interactive governance and how specific management strategies and process designs could deal with these challenges and how they could enhance the democratic quality and effectiveness of interactive governance.

In a systematic way, the various conditions and barriers for effective and legitimate interactive governance are discussed. Secondly, relevant strategies, behavior and skills of managers are discussed to deal with these barriers. In this regard specific attention is paid to boundary spanning activities and skills in connecting governmental and non-governmental actors. Thirdly, a hands-on and reflective approach is taken. Students are challenged to critically reflect on cases and literature and to formulate practical advice to managers engaged in interactive governance.

Where characteristics and theories of policy and management issues have mainly been discussed at the meso and macro level in previous courses (in Block I), this course focuses specifically on the individual (micro-perspective): connecting and boundary spanning persons in interactive governance. The role of boundary spanners has already been shortly touched upon in the Policy innovation in Complex Systems course. This course takes a closer look at this and examines the barriers and management challenges faced by connecting persons within different forms of interactive governance. The skills, challenges and strategies of connecting persons as well as the effectiveness and legitimacy of their actions are central. The course includes several group assignments and a simulation game in which students learn to give substantiated and concrete advice to managers who deal with interactive governance processes.
After completion of the course students are able to:
- understand the complexity and background of different forms of interactive governance
- apply different perspectives on interactive governance
- formulate critical conditions for effective and legitimate interactive governance
- explain the characteristics of boundary spanners and their role in managing interactive governance
- analyze barriers and management challenges of interactive governance
- formulate practical advice and guidelines for managers dealing with interactive governance processes and projects.
<body>The mandatory book can be purchased as an ebook, at a lower cost, through the publisher: Edward Elgar</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109086,2022,Managing NGOs,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['IM Geers, MSc', 'prof.dr. LCPM Meijs', 'PSM van Overbeeke, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<span style=""font-size:9pt"">Nowadays, in many countries the power of government is fading. Governments have failed to solve social issues and have diminished in scope. In addition, we do not only look to government anymore to solve the social issues of our time, use ally. New parties are playing an increasingly decisive role in the political and social arenas: Non-governmental organizations (NGOs).&nbsp
What is often forgotten as an important&nbsp
column3: in society is the civil society sphere in which philanthropic nongovernmental and non-profit organizations are active. These organizations often focus on societal issues, such as the need for distributing medical care for those who have little access to it, to reduce poverty, reduce emissions, save the whales or advocate for human rights. Many of them are focused upon advocating governments and businesses to take their responsibilities. Others are collaborating with these organizations to gain additional resources. Just like business and governments, the context in which these NPOs and NGOs operate is very diverse (maybe even more diverse!). Just like for-profit organizations, many different types of NPOs and NGOs exist. Just like for-profit organizations, these organizations serve a mission and have their particular strategies. As such, just like for-profit organizations, these organizations need to be managed properly in order to achieve their goals. In this course, you will see however, that the way in which these organizations are managed, is completely different than in the for-profit or governmental sector.&nbsp

column8: Moreover, fieldtrips to NPOs/NGOs will be arranged for you to be able to&nbsp
column10: into what really happens at these organisations.&nbsp

column1: The research notes will prepare you for the lectures and&nbsp

column6: With your group, you will create your own (fictional) NPO/NGO based on a real-life issue of your choice.&nbsp

<li>Understand the functioning and complexity of non-profit, nongovernmental and philanthropic organizations and the civil society
<li>Understand the management aspects of non-profit, nongovernmental or philanthropic&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109224,2022,Managing People towards Flourishing and Happiness,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CISG Lee', 'dr. MA Appels']",,"Inhoud

This is a course on how to create, foster, and manage organizations in which people thrive and perform at their best. It proposes that (and provides evidence why) employee and group flourishing is key to organizational excellence in our quickly changing, complex, and ambiguous world. The challenge in managing from this perspective is how to architect contexts (e.g., jobs, organizational cultures, structures, and processes) that enable employees and groups to thrive? The challenge at a more personal level is how to find and/or create a context in which you yourself can thrive and manage at your best. The course will help students build organizations that are typified by virtuousness, meaningfulness, creativity, collaboration, and a focus on human well-being. Employees of such organizations experience trust, respect, high levels of positive energy, positive spirals of flourishing, and self-fulfillment.
• Learn theories from the field of positive organizational scholarship.
• Critically assess theories from the field of positive organizational scholarship.
• Learn how to enhance a sense of purpose and meaning in a quickly changing world.
• Learn about HR tools to apply theory in organizational practice.
• Understand and know how to work with personal strengths and capabilities.
• Assess the value and evidential value of a strengths approach.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108909,2022,Managing Performance of Manufacturing and Service Systems,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. D Roy'],,"Inhoud
The main topics to be covered include the following ones
• Developing quantitative models and estimating performance measures
If students do not maintain 80% attendance in the lectures, they cannot pass the course.
Companies of all kinds -- manufacturing or services – believe that their customers are most important and valuable assets. Strong customer focus is often identified as the most important
differentiator between the best and the worst companies. Hence, managing customer experience and guaranteeing a certain service level is of paramount importance.

Performance management in manufacturing and service companies is often complex because the performance is affected by coordination requirements among multiple resources and the customer. To understand the objective of this course better, consider “time” as the performance measure reflecting customer experience. For instance, in a manufacturing system, fulfilling a customer order in a timely fashion requires coordination among several resources such as, supplier (providing the raw material), planner (planning the machine capacity), scheduler (scheduling the job), worker (working on machine setup), and machine (processing the job). Therefore, lower is the coordination delays among the resources, better is the performance measure positively affecting the customer experience. Likewise, in a service system such as a restaurant, fulfilling a customer order in a timely fashion requires minimizing coordination delays among the tables (seating the customer), order takers (taking the order), and kitchen resources (preparing the food). Hence, to manage manufacturing and service system performance, there is a growing importance on analyzing the system and estimating the measures that are good indicators of customer experience such as customer “waiting time.”

<div>This course will focus on approaches to estimate the performance measures and design systems for superior performance. The complexities in managing customer performance are further increased because of the sources of uncertainties present in the system such as uncertain number of customer arrivals. The students will also learn approaches to manage system performance in the presence of business uncertainties. Through this course, the students will develop skills in building quantitative models for manufacturing and service systems, which can be analyzed rapidly to provide insights for decision making. We will also try to incorporate behavioural aspects of service and manufacturing operations in the quantitative models. The skills will be developed through a mix of concept lectures, cases, experimenting with software tools, and a course project. &nbsp
column2: Some prior exposure to simulation tools will be helpful to keep pace with the course learnings.

column1: <div>The students will develop analytical thinking and learn to deal with practical issues while executing the course project, develop skills for quick performance analysis of systems, and also learn to develop managerial insights from models, which is an important skill to possess for executing complex on-the-job assignments in manufacturing and service organizations. The concepts discussed in each lecture will build on the learnings from the previous lectures. Hence, the students are advised to prepare thoroughly with the course material. A detailed course outline will be posted on Canvas.&nbsp

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108382,2022,Managing innovation in a new era: web3,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['M van Haaren, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Innovation management is chasing a moving target in a world continuously in motion. To illustrate, the internet, finance, and media industries are experiencing tectonic shifts toward decentralized ownership, permissionless access, tokenization, and trustless mechanisms—giving rise to a new iteration of the World Wide Web. Proponents call it the future of the internet as a natural evolution of web1 (read), web2 (read-write), and web3 (read-write-own). Building on our accumulated theoretical foundations, we will evaluate how multiple lenses are needed to explain fast-changing socio-technical phenomena.

Web3 introduces actors to participate in decentralized autonomous organizations that utilize smart contracts built on blockchain protocols. First, we examine the behavioral foundations that underpin an individual’s inclination towards tokenized networks enabling transparency, ownership, and freedom. Second, we investigate how social and algorithmic forms of organizing aim to solve the universal problems of task division, task allocation, reward distribution, and information provision. Third, these novel forms of organizing rely on an underlying blockchain architecture supporting the development of layer 1-2 platforms, cross-chain bridges, and oracles.

Theoretical and practical examples illustrate the possibilities for innovation that arise from Web3 developments. Finally, students can apply their knowledge by working on an advisory report and leading in-class debates regarding the controversial issues surrounding the future of the internet.</body>
• Understand the fundamental basics of the evolution in managing innovation on the web and humanity's tendency towards goal-directed collaboration.

• Implement the fundamentals of setting up a crypto wallet, designing digital identities, contributing to decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs), exploring learning sessions in the Metaverse, and owning publishable work.
• Analyze past, current, and emerging digital innovations in empowering the Web3 internet-native economy as a form of organization design.

• Evaluate managerially relevant and recent technological developments related to decentralization, tokenization, smart-contract design, and underlying blockchain architecture as solutions towards universal problems of organizing.
• Create an advisory case report on how organizations can assemble towards novel forms of organizing and debate controversies surrounding Web3's innovations.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116861,2022,Managing the Family Business,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. G Criaco'],,"Inhoud
<span style=""font-size:9pt"">Family firms are ubiquitous across space,&nbsp
column3: and industries. Family businesses do not only represent small, private companies. Founders or founding families are important controlling owners of large corporations listed on stock exchanges around the world. Famous examples of family businesses are IKEA, Harley&nbsp
column5: and Heineken. As such, family businesses represent a very important force for the economic and social development anywhere in the world. At the same time, family control raises unique value-creating opportunities as well as challenges for family&nbsp
column6: businesses and their different stakeholders, such as customers, financiers, suppliers, partners, employees, board members and owners.&nbsp

column1: This course introduces students to the widespread, yet complex, phenomenon of family business. It touches upon several important themes, such as strategy development, succession, governance, conflicts, business continuation, and more. The aim of this course is to introduce concepts and practical learning situations which will help the students to make sense of family businesses and to assist them in better understanding and dealing with the unique opportunities and challenges faced by different family business stakeholders.

The course is specially designed for those who are interested in working in family businesses (e.g., as managers and/or owners) or with family businesses (e.g., as advisors or consultants), and for those coming from a family business background themselves. Whatever their future role will be, students will find it useful to understand the uniqueness of these organizations. During the course, the students will develop their own perspective on family business. After the course, the students should be able to apply in practice appropriate models and theories presented during the course, as well as critically examine models and theories regarding family business development.
<span style=""font-size:9pt"">After completion of the course, the student will be able to:&nbsp
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">Understand common characteristics and challenges of family businesses&nbsp
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">Describe and explain the main theories and concepts within the field of family business research and practice&nbsp
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">Analyze and apply family business theories and concepts to different critical situations faced by family businesses&nbsp
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">Critically evaluate the use of concepts and models to understand family businesses&nbsp
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">Reflect upon common challenges faced by family businesses in practice, and develop a way to address these challenges&nbsp
<span style=""font-size:9pt"">In addition to these content-specific objectives, the student will also be able to:&nbsp
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">Demonstrate an ability to work with others in a professional manner while attempting to achieve a common goal&nbsp
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">Demonstrate an ability to think critically by identifying,&nbsp
column3: and providing concrete solutions to complex problems, both in a team and individually&nbsp

<body><span style=""background-color:#fafafa""><span style=""color:black"">This course focuses on the law and practice of marine insurance. Students learn about how ship-owners, charterers and cargo owners may obtain insurance cover against typical marine risks such as loss of or damage to ship’s hull and machinery, cargo damage and third-party liabilities. The course follows a theme-by-theme approach and draws comparisons between how these aspects are dealt with in case of a Hull &amp
column5: I) or a Marine Cargo insurance cover. The course adopts a comparative law&nbsp
column6: perspective. Even though the starting point is the English Marine Insurance Act, this will be contrasted with provisions from civil law jurisdictions such as Title 7.17 of the Dutch Civil Code and from the Principles of European Insurance Contract Law (PEICL). Standard policy wordings such as the Institute Clauses and Club Rules are used as reference points where appropriate. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. Students need to prepare assignment that will be discussed during seminars. The course will be graded based on the assignments (20%) and a written essay exam (80%).

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106719,2022,Maritime Casualties,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. FL Stevens', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele']",,"Inhoud

This course examines the complex legal relations and liabilities which arise when a ship at sea is in distress and/or suffers a maritime casualty. The course gives an overview of the many international legal instruments which (may) apply to various as-pects of a maritime casualty. It addresses the various mechanisms designed to pre-vent maritime casualties and marine pollution from occurring by raising the technical and safety standards of and on board of ships. These mechanisms include Flag- and Port-State Control, the Paris MoU and the role of Classification Societies.

Other subjects covered in depth include the law of Collision, Salvage, General Average, Limitation of Liability of the ship-owner, Civil Liability for Oil Pollution damage and Wreck Removal. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. The course will be examined on the basis of a written exam consisting of essay questions. Several lectures and/or workshops will be taught by guest lecturers from maritime practice.

To provide students with a thorough understanding of the legal consequences of maritime casualties, which is any ship-related incident that may result in liability of the ship owner or of the other parties involved in a maritime adventure. Limitation of liability proceedings, the general average clause, salvage rewards and which international and national laws apply and should the maritime practice take into account.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107343,2022,Market & Systemic Risk Management,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. C Zhou', 'prof.dr. CG de Vries']",,"Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. Casper G. de Vries (EUR) and Prof.

The main objective of this course is to develop a coherent framework for evaluating market risk at the levels of individual asset, portfolios of assets, banks and insurers and the macro economy. The main tool that we exploit in devising this framework is the statistical theory about tail risk from Extreme Value Theory (EVT) in combination with standard concepts from finance and macroeconomics.

In particular, the course offers different methods to manage financial risk with special emphasis on downside risk measures such as Value-at-Risk (VAR), Expected Shortfall (ES), semi-variance, CVaR, Stress tests, worst case scenario analysis, etc. Various statistical techniques are studied for analyzing heavy-tailed distributions, especially their convolution properties. The heavy-tail feature refers to the phenomenon that very bad outcomes occur more frequently than the normal distribution predicts. The techniques are used to estimate and manage downside risk, both at individual asset level and portfolio level. Subsequently, we investigate the EVT for the sake of stress testing and scenario analysis. Given the link between individual risk management and stability of the financial system, we also pay attention to various aspects of risk management from a supervisory point of view. The inherent fragility of the financial system is explained and tools for measuring systemic stability are developed.

Students have to conclude empirical homework as well as addressing theoretical questions. A PC lab session is held to implement the novel techniques, using market data. The rigorous treatment of some of the techniques enables students to independently analyze market and systemic risk.
Lecture 2: Application of Feller’s Theorem to Risk Measures
Lecture 3: Cross Section and Time Dependence
Lecture 6: Applications to Value at Risk, Systemic Risk

In this course, the characteristics and management of markets are described in topics that include the marketing environment, components of the marketing mix, market segmentation, and planning. How do companies decide what products to sell or what services to provide? Is it important when the companies introduce the products/services into the marketplace?
column2: How do they know who will buy the product or use the service? What are some innovative new products/services that you think will experience growth in the next five years? What makes you think that these items will be successful? In completing this course you will explore some of the basic elements of marketing and answer these and other questions as you research and construct marketing functions as they apply to products/services currently on the market. The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three C’s (customers, company and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s) and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four P’s (product offering, pricing, promotion and physical distribution).

<li>Master a set of analytical tools (i.e., frameworks, concepts, models, and techniques) for the evaluation and development of marketing efforts
<li>Understand the practical relevance and use of the theory through exposure to examples of how companies organize their marketing efforts across a variety of business settings
<li>Critically evaluate on organizational/ marketing problems by applying learned theories
• Critically reflect on a number of ethical considerations raised by marketing practices and navigate ethical dilemmas in the marketplace.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108844,2022,Marketing Analytics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. JMT Roos'],,"Inhoud

“Marketing Analytics” refers to a broad range of activities that rely on data to improve marketing decisions. This exciting field continues to grow in its scope and importance as the amount of data available to companies increases. Many large companies now have dedicated business analytics groups, and companies of all sizes are looking to hire marketing managers with a mix of technical and practical knowledge.&nbsp

This course provides students with hands-on experience using many of the tools employed by marketing analysts. The purpose of this hands-on experience is not to develop students into analysts, but rather to help them understand the value and limits of these tools, and to develop the ability to communicate analytical insights to less technical stakeholders.

column2: The course assumes students are already familiar with marketing concepts and terminology presented in the core courses.&nbsp
The course is divided into 12 modules:&nbsp

column1: <li>Course overview, statistics review, and introduction to R&nbsp
<li>The grammar of graphics and exploratory data visualization&nbsp

column2: There are two modules per week. Each module has assigned reading, 1–2 graded assessments, a discussion board, and a live&nbsp
column4: session. The workload should average to about 28 hours per week (each ECTS is equal to 28 hours of study).&nbsp

For some topics, there may be greater emphasis placed on lower-level terms and technical concepts. For others, there may be greater emphasis placed on higher-level interpretation and reflection. Each module contains a page describing the specific learning goals for that module.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106328,2022,Marketing Arts and Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['AC Crotta', 'L Marques', 'MF Rodriguez Rodriguez', 'PM Mogos, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<body>Marketing has become increasingly important as cultural and creative organizations need to generate more income from private sources such as ticket sales or sponsoring. They need to appeal to potential consumers by, e.g., having a clear and appealing identity, communicating and bonding effectively with their audiences, or offering arrangements attracting new audiences. Thus, arts organizations need to prove their relevance time and again in a world where the preferences, expectations and needs of their current and potential audiences are shifting constantly. Marketing is an indispensable tool to shape the relation with the public into a meaningful mutual commitment.</body>

<body>This course will introduce students to the principles of art marketing. On the one hand, students will learn which characteristics of potential audience members determine their interest in the arts and how this interest may be increased. On the other hand, students are introduced to marketing strategies employed by cultural organizations and the rationale behind them.</body>

A limited group of 20-25 students will be selected to follow an additional course that runs across the 3rd and 4th block of their studies. During the sessions, faculty members and marketing practitioners will discuss relevant and current themes in marketing, such as branding and social media.

Researchers within the department will present their own and others’ latest research in these areas and discuss it with the students. Practitioners and alumni will be invited to some of the sessions to give the programme a more applied flavour. The programme will also feature company visits. The sessions will be highly interactive and require a strong preparation consisting of reading and summarizing relevant literature. Cooperation will be sought with external partners, who will discuss the topics from their practical perspective.

Participation will be limited to the best students in the MSc programme of Marketing Management. The selection process will be based on a ranking based on all core courses (Blocks 1 and 2, weighted by ECTS).</body>

The honours class in Marketing Management puts excellent marketing students in close contact with the latest advancements in marketing science and practice. The course is designed to complement the MSc course portfolio by offering more in-depth training in selected areas of particular interest. The programme is also designed to facilitate the transition from marketing student to marketing practitioner by offering ample networking opportunities and contacts with executives and companies.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106055,2022,Marketing Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr.ir. GH van Bruggen'],,"Inhoud

The goal of this course is to introduce students to the marketing domain. Key questions that will be addressed during this course are: “What is marketing and the marketing concept?” and “How do companies create value?” Each session will consist of a blend of lecturing and (case) discussions. Students are expected to come well-prepared to classes and actively participate in the discussions.

As said, the course will be taught via a blend of (online) lectures and (case) discussions. During the lectures, concepts, frameworks, and theories will be presented and discussed, using practical examples to illustrate the ideas and highlight application and implementational issues.&nbsp

Marketing management is not a “hard science”. There are, however, a number of theories and concepts that you need to master in order to understand and manage marketing. You will be asked to demonstrate your competences in an exam that consists of a series of open/ essay type questions. The exam will be “open-book” and will cover all the materials that have been discussed during lectures and made available through Canvas. Furthermore, all course readings (these will be made available through the university library before the course starts) will be exam material as well. Please check SIN Online for the exact timing of the exam and the resit.
The minimum grade requirement is 5.5. Please check the Examination Regulations page so that you are aware of the rules and regulations at RSM and for the MiM programme.

The primary objective of this course is for you to develop an in-depth understanding of the frameworks, concepts, models, and paradigms that collectively form the foundation for (strategic) marketing. Secondary objectives include developing skills in the application of this knowledge through analyzing and creating solutions for and approaches to marketing and business problems. Finally, the course should make you familiar with academic research in marketing (science).
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107848,2022,Marketing Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. A Genevsky'],,"Inhoud

Marketing strategy is a complex business function that requires a balance of analytical and synthetic skills. This course introduces a series of frameworks and tools that can be used to a) solve general business problems and b) develop specific marketing strategies and programs.

<span style=""color:black"">The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three Cs (customers, company, and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s), and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four Ps (product offering, pricing, promotion, and physical distribution).&nbsp

The synthesis of all these elements is achieved through case analysis. In addition to bringing together the different theoretical elements in the context of concrete business problems, active participation in case analyses will (1) allow students to enhance their problem-solving and decision-making abilities in various areas of marketing and (2) provide an opportunity to develop, present, and defend their own recommendations, and to examine and discuss the recommendations of others critically.
• Understand how marketing is a force for positive change by creating long-term value for customers, companies and society in general.
• Understand why and how marketing is a central part of an organizational strategy by seeking to create superior value
• Understand that organizations need to identify and monitor the relevant stakeholders, macro and micro environmental factors/trends to spot and create novel opportunities for value creation
• Develop a thorough understanding of the fundamental principles and practices in strategic marketing
• Develop a thorough understanding of the core tactical elements of marketing management
• Understand and identify consumer motivations, needs and decision journeys
• Identify concrete real-world examples illustrating marketing theory and identify organizational problems as being marketing problems
• Ability to develop and communicate a coherent marketing plan
• Ability to analyze a complex business case with a small group of colleagues
• The use of several analytical tools, including tools used in targeting, brand management and pricing
• The ability to discuss complex business cases in a large group setting

The minimum grade requirement is 5.5. Please check the Examination Regulations page so that you are aware of the rules and regulations at RSM and for the MiM-P programme.

The primary objective of this course is for you to develop an in-depth understanding of the frameworks, concepts, models, and paradigms that collectively form the foundation for (strategic) marketing. Secondary objectives include developing skills in the application of this knowledge through analyzing and creating solutions for and approaches to marketing and business problems. Finally, the course should make you familiar with academic research in marketing (science).

<body>In today’s world oversupplied with media and entertainment content, the task of marketing movies, TV shows &amp
column2: channels, music, video games and comparable products is increasingly challenging. In a highly competitive environment, go-to-market strategies determine the product’s success or failure. In this course fundamental theories and perspectives on how entertainment is being marketed today are addressed.&nbsp
column3: Why and how is marketing media and entertainment products different to marketing products from any other sector? How is targeting fans different from reaching “traditional” target groups? These are central questions in the course. Furthermore, course topics include ‘positioning an entertainment property as a brand’, ‘building creative brand-centric strategies’, ‘creating products’ synergies’, ‘ecosystems and partnerships’, and ‘understanding how the digital world has impacted marketing and distribution’. The course allows students not only gain theoretical knowledge about the key aspects of leading strategic approaches, but also to learn how to translate them into actionable plans.

Marketing is the interface between a firm and its environment. It is the managerial practices that ensure customer-oriented managerial actions, including product design, pricing, market communication and product distribution, generate value for “customers”. The basic tenet is that managers should be able to justify that intended value-creation actions lead to sufficient customer responses such that they surpass the costs of these actions. However, in practice, achieving such goal is challenging, because of the sheer number of uncontrollable factors that influence customer responses. To address these challenges, academics and practitioners have developed and adopted a selection of analytical tools in the form of “marketing models”, which are crystallized from disciplines such as economics, statistics and computer science.&nbsp

This course focuses on 1) how to translate managerial problems into analytical problems, and 2) how to solve these analytical problems with marketing models. In paricular, the course covers important marketing problems, such as how to successfully design and diffuse a new product, how to price a product or service to gain short-term profits and long-term equity, and how to build and manage heterogeneous and dynamic customer portfolios. The course adopts a hands-on approach, where you are expected to work on cases with actual data to solve real managerial problems. Overall, the course will show you how to understand, predict and influence customers using marketing models.
<li>To explain the principles of marketing modeling with real-world examples.&nbsp
• To implement core marketing models (brand choice and demand models, customer segmentation, conjoint analysis, new product diffusion, and pricing) to solve managerial problems.
<li>To differentiate the three basic functions of marketing models (i.e., prediction, evaluation and optimization).&nbsp
<li>To critically evaluate various marketing models, especially those new solutions.&nbsp
<li>To translate managerial problems into analytical problems, which can be solved by marketing models.&nbsp
<li>To develop solutions to managerial problems based on marketing models.&nbsp

Individuals or households can choose to respond or not to a direct mailing, or they can choose between various brands in the supermarket. This course deals with econometric models for these qualitative variables. Examples of these models are the logit and probit models for binomial data and multinomial logit models for multinomial data. Also, ordered data, like those evolving from questionnaires, and count data will be considered.
The focus of the course is on model representation, model interpretation, parameter estimation and diagnostics.
This course uses knowledge of FEB22008 Markov Processes, FEB22005 Econometrics 2 and FEB22018(X) Marketing, and is required for FEB23021 Seminar Econometrics for Health and Society.
• Analyze econometric models for continuous, binary, categorical, ordered, and censored outcome data.
• Understand the statistical properties of marketing models.
• Translate the estimation results of marketing models into economically relevant information.
• Implement an econometric model using statistical software.
• Formulate the correct model to apply to a new marketing dataset.
<body>The assignment will not count towards the resit examination grade.</body>

The emphasis on this course is to use marketing research to aid to managerial decision making. Hence, we will focus our attention on the interpretation of statistical results in the applied aspects of various research techniques unique to marketing data. This is not a course on statistics and hence no attempt will be made to prove statistical theorems or derive mathematical solutions to statistical problems. However, this course builds heavily on prior knowledge on statistical methods and extends this to methods that are frequently used in marketing research. In particular, we will focus on ANOVA, linear regression models, choice models and factor analysis.
After following this course you should be able to:
• Identify variables and variable types in a given marketing problem
• Select the appropriate statistical method for a given marketing problem.
• Apply statistical methods to real-life datasets with the help of SPSS.
• Interpret the statistical output of your analyses.
• Recommend marketing actions based on your interpretation of the results.
<body>“Statistics for Marketing and Consumer Research” book is not mandatory anymore. The weekly assignments will not have to be submitted, but will be discussed during the tutorials.</body>

column1: This course offers an overview of the econometric, statistical and behavioral foundations in the field of marketing science. It covers several substantive topics and discusses state-of-the-art methods that academic and industry marketers can use to make sense of ubiquitous market and consumer-level data (big data), as well as several state-of-the-art techniques for primary data collection (thick data).

This course introduces students to the field of marketing science which serves all those professionals – academics or practitioners – who answer important research questions in marketing using mathematical modeling. As such, marketing science draws upon solid econometric and statistical foundations that are common to other business data sciences. For example, we will discuss state-of-the-art econometric models and predictive analytics that firms can use to better understand their customers and optimize their marketing decisions.

Marketing science goes beyond purely predictive models with the goal of understanding customer and firm behavior. Students will find that this emphasis on cause-and-effect makes the field exciting and inherently interdisciplinary. For instance, we will be discussing how to draw upon theories from different fields (e.g., marketing, economics, psychology, and sociology) to build better mathematical models capable of generating more valuable customer and market insights.

Another related distinction between marketing science and other data sciences fields is that it goes beyond big data (i.e., data with high volume, velocity and variety) and also emphasizes thick data (i.e., in-depth data about customer and firm behavior, typically gathered through experiments, surveys or even qualitative methods), as well as the combination of both. Hence, in marketing science the ability to design and interpret primary research is a must. We will be discussing how to design, gather and use primary data to complement and enrich insights garnered through secondary data. Following these topics, students will familiarize themselves with (amongst others):
1. The use of aggregate level methods to quantify the market responses to marketing mix changes
2. Introduction into individual level choice models to measure consumer responses to marketing mix changes
3. The use of machine learning in market response models
4. Individual level choice model with Bayesian model of consumer learning and knowledge generalization
5. The use customer response and choice models in multichannel setting with timedimension and multiple touchpoints/customer contact mediums (Panel Probit and Logit)
6. Model based customer segmentation: Latent Class Clustering and Regression models
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
• Understand the theoretical underpinnings and methodological challenges related to different marketing topics
• Measure the impact of marketing strategies and activities for firms and consumers
• Evaluate the effectiveness of marketing expenditure, evaluate the appropriateness of a model
• Present the relevance of the problem, method and findings

column2: purpose of marketing strategy is to develop and deploy an organization’s resources in the way that creates the most value for customers and other stakeholders. This course will help you to develop an in-depth understanding of&nbsp
column3: key frameworks, concepts, and paradigms in marketing strategy and, just as important, to develop skills in the application of this knowledge.&nbsp
column4: Historically, it has always been the case that success in business depends on managing change successfully – or at least more successfully than the competition. And over decades of research and development, many useful marketing strategy frameworks have been developed to aid firms in navigating changing markets. This course will teach you all about innovating and navigating changing markets, introduce frameworks to help you determine the optimal way of positioning a business / brand, and teach you how to allocate resources between different activities and markets. At a general level, the basic goal of this course is to help you make the transition from student to marketing practitioner and thus support your own goal of becoming a successful marketing professional. During the course, you will train extensively your case solving skills both in class, during interactive case discussions, and individually, in the assignments and trial exams. Student participation during the interactive lectures and meaningful contributions to the case discussions are essential. Students will be tested by means of an exam and written case assignments (both individual and group).

column1: At the end of this course students will have learned the principles to achieve 4 key success factors for businesses to survive and thrive over time:
• Understand the basic principles of and difficulties in navigating changing markets
• Determining an optimal competitive position for the business in its market
• Optimally allocate the company’s limited resources between its various activities
• Innovating to keep up with the change and get ahead of the competition

Overall, the course intends to make you well-informed and critical users of quantitative marketing, by presenting the essential tools and processes that are needed to make data-driven decisions for marketing strategies. Specifically, this course introduces a set of quantitative marketing tools that are essential for marketing strategy research. Through the discussion and application of these tools, the course intends to develop your abilities to identify and apply the right methods to solve marketing strategy problems. During the course, you will be offered hands-on training in marketing analytics with real datasets. Moreover, with case discussion, you will learn how to identify opportunities to improve business performances with marketing analytics (i.e., “when to use”), and formulate unbiased understanding of analytical tools (i.e., “how to choose”).&nbsp
1. To understand the theories and practices of quantitative marketing&nbsp
2. To know how to formulate and evaluate marketing strategies with data-driven approach
3. To master a set of essential tools of marketing analytics
4. To develop a framework of evaluating and learning new analytical tools

column1: In tackling these challenges and building successful marketing strategies, many firms rely on big data and marketing analytics. In this age of data, being able to work with big data and sophisticated marketing analytics tools has become a vital part of the skill sets of successful marketing professionals.

The objective of this course is to show you the benefits of using a systematic and analytical approach to marketing decision-making and get you familiar with the insights and methods you can use to understand these marketing problems. The course discusses important marketing problems and covers a wide range of cutting-edge machine learning and data analytics techniques that should be part of the toolbox of modern data scientists.&nbsp
column2: You will learn how to pick the right solution for tackling analytics opportunities and challenges that exist in today’s big data era. The course uses an action-oriented, applied approach to managing marketing problems with data-driven tools.&nbsp
column3: Example applications allow you to experience the value of quantitative methods in marketing even if you have little (or no) coding background.&nbsp
column4: After completing this course, you will be able to solve marketing analytics problems in a scientific and process-driven manner.</body>

In het huidige economische klimaat leidt de sterk toegenomen concurrentie ertoe dat veel bedrijven het moeilijk hebben om te overleven. Ondanks deze onzekere tijden, zijn er enkele bedrijven die er keer op keer in slagen om succesvolle producten te lanceren en hun marktaandeel op systematische wijze te vergroten. Dit doet natuurlijk de volgende vraag rijzen: welke factoren zorgen ervoor dat het ene bedrijf succesvoller is dan het andere? In het vak Marketing Management bekijken we een van de belangrijkste redenen: veel van deze succesvolle bedrijven hande-len namelijk vanuit een strategisch marketingperspectief. Door op systematische wijze in te spelen op de behoeften van klanten, presenteren zij een klantgericht producten- en dienstenaanbod dat duidelijk te onderscheiden is van de concurrentie.

In plaats van marketing louter te bekijken als de verkoop van bestaande producten en diensten, benadrukt dit vak hoe marketing management veelal een geïntegreerde strategie is waarbij de behoeften van de klant centraal staan. Daarvoor bekijken we hoe bedrijven de uiteenlopende behoeften van de klant kunnen analyseren en hoe ze op basis hiervan een strategie kunnen ontwikkelen waardoor ze zich kunnen onderscheiden van de concurrentie. Hierbij is het niet alleen van belang om goed uitgekiende producten en diensten te ontwikkelen, maar ook om doordachte beslissingen te nemen met betrekking tot distributiekanalen, prijs en promotiecampagnes.
Na het met succes volgen van dit vak:

· Bent u in staat om te begrijpen en argumenteren hoe marketing een centraal deel is van de organisatiestra-tegie en hoe marketing een “force for positive change” kan zijn door het creëren van lange-termijn waarde voor klanten, bedrijven en de maatschappij in het algemeen
· Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de fundamentele principes binnen strategische marketing
· Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de centrale tactische elementen van marketing management
· Bent u in staat om voorbeelden te geven van de gangbare marketing theorieën, onderzoeksmethoden en problemen in marketing management, en aanbevelingen te maken op basis van relevante literatuur.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108848,2022,Marketing of New Products,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. YM van Everdingen'],,"Inhoud

New products, which are also called innovations, provide new ways to create value for customers, and moreover, it yields growth and profitability for firms. A huge percentage of a company’s sales and profit is generally earned by products that have been launched in the past five years. However, at the same time, many new products fail, and disappear from the market sooner or later after its launch. This is very problematic for companies, given the huge amount of money involved in the research and development of new products. The success or failure of a new product is determined by its ultimate acceptance in the market place. This raises the question which factors influence the acceptance and diffusion of new products in the market place? This question will be central in this course. The answer to this question provides marketing managers with information on how to effectively develop and launch new products.

During this course the students get acquainted with both conceptual and tacit knowledge of important methods in launching new products, and moreover in tracking the new product launch. Additionally, this course will provide a structured overview of the body of knowledge on adoption and diffusion of new products in the market place, and moreover, insights into how this knowledge can be incorporated in new product launch decisions. Attention will be paid to the consumer adoption decision process as well as to the new product adoption decisions by retailers, both in the domestic and the international market. The course challenges you to think critically about new products marketing. As such, routine learning of terms and concepts is not sufficient. You are prepared to take a marketing manager’s seat in managing new products across international markets.&nbsp
The learning objectives of the course are:
• To be able to develop an optimal launch strategy.
• To gain insights into the retailers’ adoption decision process.
• To gain insights in the consumers’ adoption process.
• To gain insights in the new product diffusion process.
• To be able to forecast the success of a new product.

This course is designed to provide students with advanced skills on the enforcement of law in the field of regulation of markets. In particular, students learn how to use economic arguments and economic evidence in real-life cases in courts and/or regulatory agencies. The course is organized in a moot court format. Students must take the role of plaintiffs, defendants, regulators or regulatees. They are supposed to base their arguments and decisions, both orally and in writing, on economic analysis of law. The topics, which are reviewed yearly, include inter alia competition law, product liability, mergers and acquisitions, financial and consumer law.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

With their master's thesis, students demonstrate that they are able to contribute to academic and sophisticated professional debates on a specific subject. Each student that achieved satisfactory results in his/her coursework will be appointed with a supervisor. Supervisors will provide personal advice on various occasions to ensure that students can make reliable progress. The master's thesis will fulfil the following criteria:

Het schrijven van de master thesis staat centraal tijdens de masteropleiding. In de master thesis laten studenten zien dat zij op basis van eigen, oorspronkelijk onderzoek een bijdrage kunnen leveren aan het wetenschappelijke debat over een bepaald onderwerp uit het eigen vakgebied.
Overige eisen die worden gesteld aan de master thesis zijn:
• het onderzoek is gebaseerd op een helder geformuleerde probleemstelling en daaruit afgeleide
• het onderzoek is gestoeld op theorieën en methoden uit het vakgebied, dan wel theorieën en methoden die voor dit specifieke onderwerp relevant zijn
• deze theorieën en methoden worden in de thesis besproken en beargumenteerd in relatie tot de probleemstelling
• eerder onderzoek rond het gekozen onderwerp wordt aangegeven, samengevat en besproken voorzover relevant voor het eigen onderzoek
• gebruikte literatuur, primaire en secundaire bronnen, overige gegevens en data worden systematisch gepresenteerd en aan elkaar gerelateerd
• de thesis bestaat uit een inleiding, diverse hoofdstukken waarin de bevindingen worden besproken, conclusie, literatuurlijst en (eventueel) bijlagen
• het onderzoek mondt uit in een heldere, bondig geschreven conclusie
• literatuur, bronnen en overige gegevens en data worden nauwkeurig opgegeven in voetnoten,
• de thesis is geschreven in verzorgd en accuraat Nederlands of Engels
• de thesis kent een omvang van 20.000 woorden (+/- 10 %), exclusief titelblad, inhoudsopgave,
• The student is able to set up an academic research project under supervision
• The student is able to formulate an elaborate research question which is the starting-point for their research project

• The student can find and critically interpret different types of primary sources and engage with relevant secondary literature to answer this research question and the student is also able to apply theoretical and methodological concepts in their research
• Finally, the student is able to report on their research findings to an adequate audience

<body>Writing a master's thesis is the central feature of the research master's programme. The master's thesis enables students, based on their own original research, to demonstrate their abilities to contribute to the academic debate of a specific subject in their field of study. The following are additional requirements that the master's thesis must satisfy:
<li>the research will based on a clearly formulated problem and subsequent research questions
<li>the research will be based on theories and methodologies relevant to the field of study and the specific theme
<li>the theories and methodologies will be discussed and argued in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem
<li>previous research concerning the chosen theme will be indicated, summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to one's own research
<li>the literature used, primary and secondary sources, other information and data will be systematically presented and interrelated
• the research will result in a clear, succinctly written conclusion.
The master's thesis should have the format of an article for an international peer-reviewed academic journal. As such it should meet the following requirements:
<li>the article will contain a clearly stated research problem and research question(s)
column2: a description of the scientific/ background and relevance of the research question(s)
column3: an outline of the methods of data collection and analysis
column4: a presentation and discussion of the findings, and a conclusion highlighting the scientific relevance of the findings and how these relate to the existent literature on the topic

column1: <li>the literature, sources and other information and data will be accurately listed in footnotes and the references, and, if necessary, in separate appendices
<li>the article will be preceded by an abstract (200-400 words) and five key words
• the article accords with the established formats of the relevant journal(s) within the disciplinary and thematic field that fits the research topic.
<li>the article will be written in polished, accurate English
• the article will consist of a maximum of 10.000 words, excluding footnotes and references, tables and figures, abstract and key words.
Students have developed the knowlegde and skills to:​
• Formulate an original and relevant scholarly problem in his or her field of study
• Draw up an appropriate research proposal, including a positioning of the thesis in currently scholarly discussion, a well-argued research strategy, and time plan
• Organize the research set-up (empirical and/or fieldwork research)
• Use current social-scientific methods and techniques to collect and analyze the required information and data
• Report on the results/findings in a coherent and reflexive way
• Evaluate the conclusions and choices made during the research process
• Write an academic article in English, to be submitted for publication to an international peer-reviewed academic journal

In this course, students decide on the topic and shape the outlines of their Master Thesis – an original and autonomously conducted academic study. Throughout, the emphasis is on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a
column2: well-structured research design. During the ‘thesis market’ the available supervisors of the programme will suggest themes and topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers, but may also consist of questions/requests for research that specific cultural organisations might have. After that, students will come up with a topic of their interest. They will then develop this into a suitable, feasible and well-argued research proposal, which will be the basis of the work on the actual Master Thesis.

column1: This course consists of two components. On the one hand, there is a personal trajectory in which students will develop a plan for their Master Thesis in the form of a research proposal. They will do so through consecutive assignments, where there is room for trial-and-error and individual feedback is provided in the various steps. On the other hand, regular meetings serve as collective checkpoints to streamline the process. In doing so, ample attention is paid to content-related matters and designing a suitable method, as well as the time planning and formal criteria, to make sure that the Master Thesis (and the Master Thesis proposal) is in line with the programme’s requirements. Therefore, we will consider (and in some cases freshen up) topics such as conceptualizing, searching for and integrating literature, various methodologies, and academic writing.

Students investing fully in this course will be able to write a clear, well-structured and feasible research proposal for their Master Thesis, including an introduction (research question and relevance), a literature review/theoretical framework and a data and methods section. In the process students will identify a topic, formulate a clear research question, search for, find and select relevant literature, operationalize theoretical concepts and come up with a suitable method of research.

We will study selected aspects of methodology (what is research?) and empirical research methods (how do we collect and analyze data?). ​During the course, we will discuss previous empirical findings and methodological tools available in our field. Students will have the chance to develop a research proposal to understand the relationship between the problem statement, the analysis of the data, and the concluding answer to the research question. The course will provide the discussion space to explore setting up a research project which, eventually, can become the actual MA thesis. At the end of the course, the student is expected to be able to apply the empirical methods of the discipline to develop a coherent and feasible research proposal.

<body>This workshop assists students in designing a motivated and detailed research proposal for their master thesis. Successful participants will be well prepared to discuss their project with their thesis supervisor and to start conducting their own research.</body>

First, we will explain all the content-related and formal criteria the Master Thesis and master thesis proposal have to fulfill as well as the time planning. Second, during the ‘thesis market’ the lecturers of the programme will present potential thesis topics which lie on the intersections between tourism, culture and society that students can – but do not have to – choose as their Master Thesis topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers or consist of questions specific cultural organisations might have. Third, we will elaborate on turning a relevant and feasible topic into a research question. During the last two meetings, students will start writing their master thesis proposal. Fourth, students learn to search, find and select relevant literature and make efficient use of various digital search tools. The emphasis, however, will be on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a well-structured and logical research design. Fifth, students will receive tips and tricks and practice their writing skills and learn to monitor and optimize the writing process.

Students investing fully in this course will be able to write a clear, well-structured and feasible research proposal for their Master Thesis, focusing on the intertwined relationship between tourism, culture and society. This includes an introduction (research question and relevance), a theoretical framework and a data and methods section. In the process students will be able to identify a topic, formulate a concise research question, search, find and select relevant literature, operationalize theoretical concepts and come up with a suitable methodology.
