In order to complete the Master of HEPL, with specialisation Health Economics, students are required to write a scientific Master thesis on a topic that is related to one of the subjects covered in the HEPL Master. The combined workload of the Thesis Plan and Thesis is 16 ECTS (or 448 hours) and thus constitutes a major part of the curriculum. Students write their Master thesis under supervision of a member of the HEPL staff. The evaluation of the thesis and defence for the final grade is conducted by the student's thesis reading committee, which includes the supervisor and one co-evaluator. The co-evaluator must be someone from the ESHPM or ESE staff.
More information regarding the HE thesis, the graduation procedure, and a link to the coursebook can be found at https://my.eur.nl/en/ese/master.
<body>The objective of the thesis is to show that the student is able to perform scientific research individually and to report the study and its conclusions in a clear way.</body>

The thesis is an individual assignment about a subject from your Master's specialisation. More information about thesis subjects, thesis supervisors and the writing process can be found on the Master thesis website.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which they can initiate and perform a literature review which is useful for their research project.

• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which methods and techniques of scientific research in the field of accounting, auditing, control or finance can be applied to their own research topic.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the application of up-to-date qualitative or quantitative research methods.

• Students are able to: formulate a clear research question based on relevant academic concepts and theories, and legitimized by up-to-date academic or social developments as well as to formulate hypotheses in a systematic and valid way.

• Students are able to: analyse and interpret data in an accurate, reliable, comprehensive and verifiable way and to formulate conclusions which sufficiently take into account presuppositions, basic principles and the limitations/opportunities of the selected methodology.

• Students are able to: report on research findings in a logical and consistent way and give a clear oral explanation of the research project as well as to answer critical questions about the research in a convincing manner.

Students need to write a MSc thesis on a behavioural economics topic. The thesis is an individual assignment about a subject from your Master's specialisation. The student can either choose a topic and supervisor from a list, or propose their own research topic.
In November, a topic pitch event is organized. Students can get to know the available supervisors and the topics they are interested in.
In December, students submit their topic and supervisor preferences.
In January, the matching of students and their supervisors is announced.
In January and February, students are developing their research question and writing their research proposal.
Between March and July, the student is conducting the research and writing the thesis.
More information about thesis subjects, thesis supervisors and the writing process can be found on the Behavioural Economics Master Thesis page on Canvas.
The final grade is based on the thesis and defence presentation. In order to defend the thesis, the research proposal has to be approved and uploaded in Sin Online.
• Students obtain in-depth knowledge about a topic of their choice. The topic is related to behavioral economics and may be related to their track.
• Students learn how to write a research proposal.
• Students obtain knowledge about the ethical aspects of conducting scientific research.
• Students learn how to conduct a scientific literature review.
• Students learn to formulate a research question and hypotheses.
• Students learn to set up an experiment and/or gather data (theoretical theses excluded)
• Students learn to test their hypotheses using a variety of statistical analysis methods (theoretical theses excluded)
• Students learn to critically assess their own work by writing a discussion and limitations section.
• Students learn how to construct a reference list following academic rules (e.g., APA).
• Students learn how to deal with feedback in a professional manner.
• Students learn to plan and complete a complicated long-term (6-month) project, comprised of different stages and tasks.
Earlier matching of students to supervisors (end of December rather than early January)
Workshop 'how to write a research proposal' to get students started.

• Students are able to: formulate a clear research question based on relevant academic concepts and theories, and legitimized by up-to-date academic or social developments.
• The student can select the correct data and appropriate analysis technique to answer the research question.
• The student shows he can work independently.

• Students are able to: analyze and interpret data in an accurate, reliable, comprehensive and verifiable way and to formulate conclusions which sufficiently take into account presuppositions, basic principles and the limitations/opportunities of the selected methodology.
• Students are able to: link their findings to existing (academic) literature on the topic. This applies to findings relating to both the methods used and the obtained management implications.

• Students are able to: report on research findings in a logical and consistent way and give a clear oral explanation of the research project as well as to answer critical questions about the research in a convincing manner.

The thesis is an individual assignment about a subject from your Master specialisation. More information about thesis subjects, thesis supervisors and the writing process can be found on the Master thesis website.
• The student shows that he can formulate a proper research question which can be analysed using his knowledge of econometrics and/or operations research.
• The student decides upon the correct data and appropriate model to answer the research question.
• The student decides upon a suitable method to solve the model.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104633,2022,Master's thesis,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. BE French', 'F de Haan', 'prof.dr. F Koster']",,"Inhoud

Your thesis is the ‘masterpiece’ of your master’s degree in Sociology. The master’s thesis is an empirical study demonstrating that you have all the necessary competences to independently formulate sociologically relevant research questions, to select and apply suitable theoretical frameworks and methodological approaches consistent with the disciplinary and legal norms relating to privacy and ethics, and to communicate your work in a scientific and professional manner.

<body>In the process of writing your master’s thesis proposal, conducting the research necessary to answer your research question(s), and reporting on the study conducted in your master’s thesis, you will learn:
<li>To formulate a suitable and sociologically relevant problem statement
<li>To provide an overview of the extant literature in the chosen research subfield, resulting in a detailed and specific research question(s)
<li>To differentiate between descriptive and explanatory research questions
<li>To use sociological theory and empirical findings to develop hypotheses and/or sub-questions, which constitute the basis for your theoretical framework
<li>To create an appropriate research design to answer your research question(s)
<li>To assess the feasibility of your research design
<li>To demonstrate and document the proper, careful consideration of the ethics and privacy implications of your study
<li>To reliably operationalize the core concepts of your study
<li>To independently conduct empirical research using secondary or primary (self-collected) data, using suitable analytical methods and techniques
<li>To discuss the theoretical and empirical value of your study and evaluate your study’s sociological and societal relevance
<body>A sufficient assessment of the thesis proposal is the condition for being able to start carrying out the thesis research.</body>

Students attending the Master Class will get familiarized with the complexity of the actual financial/insurance world and will be able to understand this and to form their own opinion. Lectures will be presented by specialists from Allianz Benelux and speakers from other leading organisations. This combination will guarantee quality and independency of the course. Each lecture contains a practical part in the form of a case or small assignment. Attending the Master Class will reward students with a certificate provided by the Erasmus School of Economics.

This extracurricular Master Class is organized in cooperation with Allianz. It is meant for students who want to know more about an interesting and dynamic discipline: actuarial sciences. Actuaries are experts in analysing the past, modelling the future, assessing the risk involved by using mathematical and statistical models and communicating what the result means in financial terms. In the Master Class the most important aspects of the actuarial profession will be presented by bringing together theory and practice.

Het vak Masterclasses wordt verzorgd door de partners die verbonden zijn aan Toga aan de Maas. Er wordt gewerkt met drie lijnen binnen het vak Masterclasses: (i) Togavaardigheden, (ii) Verdieping/inhoudelijk en (iii) Soft skills. Binnen de lijn Togavaardigheden leren de studenten een juridische procedure te doorlopen. Onder andere de volgende onderwerpen komen hier aan bod: het eerste contact met cliënten, het analyseren van een dossier en procesadvies, schriftelijke stukken opstellen, processtrategie, comparitie van partijen en pleiten, vonnis schrijven, hoger beroep en cassatie. Ook alternatieve geschilbeslechting komt binnen deze lijn aan bod. Binnen de lijn Verdieping/inhoudelijk worden belangrijke juridische leerstukken en actuele onderwerpen besproken. Tot slot, staat de lijn Soft skills in het teken van de persoonlijke ontwikkeling van studenten, met onderwerpen als legal English, personal branding, presenteren/pitchen, onderhandelen en stress management. De diverse masterclasses vinden plaats bij de partnerkantoren, bestaande uit advocatenkantoren, het Openbaar Ministerie en de rechtspraak.

oplossingen aandragen voor een juridisch complex probleem en kan binnen die samenwerking een eigen visie vormen en die motiveren.&nbsp

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106709,2022,Masterclass actualiteiten gezondheidsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr.dr. AP den Exter', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

In dit vak wordt het onderwijs primair verzorgd door gerenommeerde juristen (advocaten, ziekenhuisjuristen, etc.) werkzaam in de praktijk van het gezondheidsrecht. Zij laten de studenten kennismaken met actuele ontwikkelingen op de verschillende deelterreinen van dit rechtsgebied: het zorgverleningsrecht, het zorgverzekeringsrecht en het zorginkooprecht. Van de studenten wordt gevraagd hun eerder opgedane kennis van deze deelgebieden van het gezondheidsrecht toe te passen op actuele vraagstukken. De studenten krijgen van de gastdocenten casuïstiek voorgelegd, die zij moeten behandelen in wekelijks in te leveren werkstukken. De rechtsvragen die de studenten krijgen voorgelegd, zijn ontleend aan die van de rechtspraktijk van de gastdocenten. Het onderwijs vindt deels plaats ten kantore van de praktijkjuristen.

• De student heeft kennisgemaakt met de praktijk van het gezondheidsrecht en de laatste ontwikkelingen op alle deelterreinen van dit rechtsgebied. Hij heeft weet van de relevante rechtspraak en nieuwe ontwikkelingen op deze terreinen en is in staat om deze ontwikkelingen te kunnen plaatsen en op hun relevantie te kunnen beoordelen.

• De student beschikt over juridische en algemene academische vaardigheden, waarbij kennis van het gezondheidsrecht, inzicht en probleemoplossende vermogens kunnen worden toegepast in nieuwe of onbekende omstandigheden binnen de bredere (of multidisciplinaire) context van dit rechtsgebied.
• Dit betekent dat de student wet- en regelgeving op casuïstiek kan toepassen en een logisch antwoord kan formuleren op de rechtsvragen bij een casus.
<li style=""text-align:justify""><span style=""background-color:white""><span style=""color:#212529"">De student op basis van een actuele casus de rechtsvraag kan formuleren
• De student geeft bij het doen van de praktijkopdrachten blijk van creativiteit en zelfstandigheid.
• De student durft een eigen mening te uiten tijdens colleges, door middel van het doen van onderbouwde uitspraken met betrekking tot de behandelde stof.

Students are able to: analyse and interpret data in an accurate, reliable, comprehensive and verifiable way and to formulate conclusions which sufficiently take into account presuppositions, basic principles and the limitations/opportunities of the selected methodology.

Students are able to: report on research findings in a logical and consistent way and give a clear oral explanation of the research project as well as to answer critical questions about the research in a convincing manner.

<body>For the first thesis round, the deadline to submit the final version to the supervisor is July 7. Students must defend their thesis before August 31, 2023, to graduate within the academic year. If students request their defense before August 14, 2023, the defense can also take place within the first two weeks of September. A graduation ceremony will take place towards the end of the calendar year.</body>
<body>Students who do not finish their thesis by 1 May 2021 will have to restart the thesis with a new supervisor and a new topic.</body>

This Mathematics course presents the necessary Mathematical tools for analysing quantitative models that emerge from a variety of business and economic problems. The selection below reflects the scope of the studied Mathematical topics that will be useful for the analysis of economics and business problems. These topics are:
• Functions and equations of one and two variables

This course lays the foundation for the quantitative courses to follow in the IBA curriculum. The scientific description and analysis of complex practical business situations often requires an analytic approach. What is usually needed is the explicit description of the transition of a system when it moves from one state to the next. Mathematics is well equipped to assist in the difficult task of describing the essential elements of such transitions. The word ""model"" is often used for the quantitative description of the specific problem in which a system finds itself at any moment in time. Working with models is a recurring activity in business studies. The process of building and analysing business models requires a Mathematical way of thinking. Therefore, mathematical skills are essential for successfully handling these business models.

IMPORTANT NOTICE: The concepts, skills, and methods from the ‘Preparation course mathematics’ are a prerequisite for this course. You will not be able to understand the course without having successfully mastered the learning goals of the preparation course.

After completing this course, students will be able to apply the mathematical techniques covered in this course and to build, analyze and solve mathematical models emerging from business problems using mathematical techniques from the course and interpret the solutions in terms of the original problem. A detailed list of learning goals per learning unit is available in the document ‘Material overview’ in the ‘Course Information’ on Canvas.

The course is based on online modules, which provide the theory and practice exercises. Each week, optional question hours are scheduled where you can ask questions about the material. There is a midterm and final exam. This set-up offers a high flexibility (no lectures or tutorials), and relies primarily on self-study. This version of the course is intended for students that have a considerable proficiency in mathematics.
<body>At the end of the course, students will
• Have acquired mathematical skills that support more quantitative courses in EUC

• Be able to deal with mathematics in such a way that in later years a student will be able to recognize which subject from mathematics is used and – if necessary – to study more advanced topics by her/himself.

The course is based on weekly mandatory tutorials with in-class exercises. This version of the course is intended for students who think they will benefit from guided weekly tutorials and who enjoy solving mathematical problems in groups.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107439,2022,Measurement of Patient Preferences using Discrete Choice Experiments,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. J Veldwijk', 'dr. LE Pilli', 'dr. MF Jonker', 'dr. WK van Deen, MD', 'NVR Smeele, MSc', 'prof.dr. EW de Bekker - Grob']",,"Inhoud

Traditionally, HTA researchers and health economists have concentrated on health outcomes expressed in QALYs when attempting to measure the benefits from health care products or programs. There is growing recognition, however, that patient preferences for health care products and programs are also shaped by non-health outcomes (such as amount of information) and process attributes (such as treatment location, or route of drug administration). Studies into these outcomes beyond health are an emerging trend in HTA and health economics. Discrete choice experiments (DCEs) are typically used for this purpose. DCE allows investigation of many types of research questions, as it is an attribute-based measure of benefit, which gives this method the flexibility to include any concern deemed of relevance. This course provides a resource for students in the health sector who want to familiarize themselves with assessment of patient preferences using DCEs. We present the fundamental principles and theory underlying DCEs, demonstrate the process of carrying out a choice study, and discuss the policy implications of the results.

Course materials will be studied in lectures and work groups, but students will also be actively involved in a DCE study with the aim to increase understanding of what is taught. Small groups will carry out a DCE study on a topic that is theirs to choose. Part of the work will be done during the work groups, and feedback will be provided continuously. The groups complete their work step by step over several weeks. The group's work will be evaluated on the basis of a short report about the DCE
column2: individual members of the group may receive different grades based on their contributions.

column1: The written examination is 70% of the final grade (minimum grade 5.0 or higher). The remainder derives from the group project (30%).
The re-sit is composed as a written examination (70%, minimum grade 5.0 or higher) and a group project (30%).
<body>After completing the course, students will be able to:
• recognize the importance of patient preference measurements in health care
• describe the theoretical foundation(s) of discrete choice experiments (DCEs)
• develop their own DCE using state-of-the-art (publishable) methods
• understand recent articles in the DCE literature and assess the validity of the presented conclusions

<body>Understanding ‘the audience’ has long been a central concern in the fields of communication and media studies. This course offers a critical survey of academic research exploring the relationships between audiences and media technologies/texts. A variety of interdisciplinary perspectives will be addressed including active audience theory, spectatorship, media effects, uses and gratifications, critical/cultural studies, and fans/fandom. The literature used in this course applies these perspectives to a variety of media content/forms including television, cinema, videogames, and streaming video.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106525,2022,Media Economics and Media Management,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

<body>In media studies, research tends to focus on the output of media industries. In this course, we take another perspective by investigating the economic characteristics of media markets and the strategic behavior of media firms on them. How did Facebook come to dominate the social media market? How are incumbent TV broadcasters responding to the challenges posed by Youtube and Netflix? In order to study these and other questions, we will address key media economic theoretical traditions, learn how to define markets, discuss the particular characteristics of media products and investigate the fast changes in media. After this, we will use media management literature to understand how media firms are responding to economic structures, product characteristics and market changes. &nbsp
column2: We will take an explicit international perspective, using case studies from many different parts of the world. In these case studies, we will study how the specific economic characteristics of the media product and societal and economic context within it is offered, affected the strategic management decisions that were made. Students are also required to conduct a case study themselves of a media firm’s behavior in its defined market.

column1: • Major theoretical perspectives and key concepts in media economics.

column2: pressures (market, regulation, globalization etc.) on media firms' strategies.

• Take an international perspective on media economic research.
• Conduct case study research on media firms and their products.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106566,2022,Media Entrepreneurship,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['FKS Robinson'],,"Inhoud

The phenomenon of entrepreneurship is closely connected with a growing mediatization of organizations and society. In this way, media facilitate various creative processes and enables individuals and organizations to develop new ideas, facilitate new processes and build new ventures. At the same time, media entrepreneurship is a very young, but rapidly growing research area with a variety of backgrounds, concepts and methodological opportunities.

Therefore, the aims of this course are threefold. First, we aim to provide an overview of the field of media entrepreneurship and intend to spark critical investigations and shared discussions around its meaning. What is media entrepreneurship? What kind of styles, habits and practices can we see in different empirical settings? Second, we will explore current practices of entrepreneurship in the media and creative industries. How can we use media in creative manner to generate new opportunities and create sustainable organizational responses to the challenges we face? Third: These questions will be explored dialogically and creatively around different empirical phenomena in media entrepreneurship, for example through small research activities such as conducting market research or qualitative interviews with practitioners and analyzing these in class for further reflection.</body>
Students will gain knowledge and understanding of:
• Comprehend current concepts, approaches and theories of entrepreneurship for working in media organizations
<li><span style=""color:black"">Discuss and evaluate the importance of entrepreneurship around media and media organizations
• Analyze how media organizations and practitioners manage entrepreneurship and behave in entrepreneurial manner.
• Identify needs, opportunities and challenges for entrepreneurial actions in media and creative
<li><span style=""color:black"">Construct and develop responses for tackling issues in creative entrepreneurial manner
<li><span style=""color:black"">Synthesize and evaluate entrepreneurial actions in relations to current theoretical frameworks
• Demonstrate the conduct of a qualitative interview with an entrepreneur.

This course introduces students to the major theoretical approaches in the study of mass mediated communication, drawing on research examples that cover various media (e.g. radio, television, film, newspapers, magazines, and the internet) and different countries. The course provides a historical and critical overview of theory and research on processes of media production, media contents, and media reception. The impact media have on culture and society is explored as well as debates that circulate about the media and media influences.
Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussion of student assignments and coursework.
Note:You can not take this course combined with Media Industries and Audiences: CM0004 (the content is the same)

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106485,2022,Media Industries: Trends and Strategies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

Media industries have experienced radical changes in recent years as a result of new digital technologies and distribution platforms (e.g. gaming, the internet, mobile platforms etc.). For companies, workers and policymakers operating within media industries, these changes have severely impacted their operations: previously separated media markets have converged, new media products and business models have been developed, and users are no longer passive consumers but are actively peer producing content (so called user generated content). This seemingly chaotic period media industries find themselves in is the starting point of this course.

During the course, students will familiarize themselves with the latest trends and developments in the media industries. We will start with theoretical foundations that are crucial for understanding and researching media industries and media innovation. We will then turn our attention to trends in the media industries, and discuss how these trends impact the strategic behavior of industry actors (companies, audiences, policymakers). In addition to discussing literature, we will also use guest lectures and online material (e.g. videos) to discuss trends and strategies within the media sector.

column5: trends, problems and governance in theory and empirics of media industries and media innovation,

column1: • Key analytical tools to define and study media innovation

column5: theoretical viewpoints and research materials presented in class

column2: reflect upon developments in media industries and assess their impact and newness.
current developments and strategies in the media industries using theories and concepts covered in the course

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106561,2022,Media Policies and Markets,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

Governments have always had a special interest in media markets. Their policies and regulation can have a great impact on the boundaries within which media organizations can operate. Governmental scrutiny of media is often justified by societal expectations that countries have of their media sector. The fast-paced changes in the media industry have forced governments around the world to reassess their media policy. For instance, the scandal around Cambridge Analytica’s usage of Facebook users’ data has forced many governments to rethink their privacy regulations.

During this course, we will use models from (media) economics and institutional economics to conceptualize the interplay between government policy and media markets. In addition, we will focus on theories and developments around policy and regulation that allow us to analyze, critically assess and contextualize media policy.

The seminar connects relevant issues within media policy to relevant theoretical concepts. From examples on fake news to hate speech and violation of data privacy. We will discuss these and other developments in media policy using practical and international examples. Furthermore, we will try to formulate alternative policy options that governments could have taken. The seminar is participative in nature, which means that students are required to prepare the lecture, participate in discussions, debate and give presentations.
• The interplay between media markets, media firms and governmental policy
• The most important international developments in media policy for media markets (e.g. privacy, copyrights, market power, freedom of speech)
• Reflect critically on relevant theory and developments in media policy
• Analyse and critically evaluate different policy options
• Assess the impact of governmental policy on media markets

<body>This course introduces students with major theoretical perspectives and methodological approaches in the comparative study of media systems and media industries. The course offers a wide-ranging survey of media systems across different regions of the world. Students will be familiarized with comparative research, addressing the economic, social, political, regulatory and cultural aspects of media systems. Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussions of student assignments and coursework.</body>
<li>The main theoretical perspectives, approaches, and issues in the comparative study of media systems and media industries
• Principal dimensions of variation in media systems and the complex of forces shaping their evolution.

• Formulate their own viewpoints and research questions, using relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings

DRS Ongenaert', 'dr. FGR De Keyzer', 'dr. JF Ferreira Goncalves', 'dr. JF Pereira Campos', 'PM Leendertse, MA', 'prof.dr. M van Selm', 'TAP Oomen, MSc']",,"Inhoud

A decade ago, a travel agent was a legitimate job. Today, this line of employment has become redundant with online sites such as kayak, priceline and expedia that allow customers to shop virtually for competitive pricing. This new platform economy creates new questions regarding how algorithms shape the competitiveness of the travel and tourism industry and to what extent does this allow for a level playing field for companies in this sector. Further, the rise of the middle class in countries like India and China are producing new user groups that pushes tourism-related companies to rethink their advertising, city branding and packaging strategies that can best tailor to these new demographics.

In fact, across industries we see disruptions taking place with the rise of digital media, novel technologies and platforms, new data policies, governance measures, and new user groups. These trends demand that we reflect and rethink the ways in which these industries are being transformed and the repercussions on the future of work and wellbeing for our societies. This captures not just a shift in the nature of employment, but possibly the&nbsp
column2: birth of a new worldview, corporate ideology, management, and customer relations strategy where certain intermediaries have become digital.

column1: This course consists of a series of expert lectures provided by various EUR staff. These lectures focus on various themes including (1) the effects of digitalization for media businesses, (2) the state of and trends within global media industries, (3) implications of digitalization for organizations, work and people, and (4) the processes of surveillance, mobilization and personalization, and this through specific case studies from diverse sectors.

Students will explore the global and political infrastructures at play as technology companies, laborers, user groups, and governance structures span across nations, complicating our understandings of a typical business today. We will jointly explore urgent ethical challenges, serious sustainability concerns, and dominant global trends in user behaviors, company practices, and national policies that pushes for a design thinking approach to “good” organizational practice.
Overall, the intent of this course is to gain a more critical perspective on the role of digital media and datafication in different industries &nbsp
column2: in order to shape more inclusive, ethical and sustainable business models and practices in this digital and global age.

• How digital media, artificial intelligence, and the internet of things are transform contemporary business processes.
• The rise of new user groups and their impact on the design of global platforms, AI-enabled systems, and smart infrastructures.
<li>The legal, socio-cultural, economic, political, technical and moral challenges for global data governance that arise with the&nbsp
<li>Companies' public responsibilities and new discourses on ethics in this data driven economy.&nbsp

• Analyze existing research relating organizations, digital cultures and new media forms.
• Create an argumentation on contemporary concerns, issues, and challenges on datafication and digitization pertaining to a specific industry.

This course introduces students to the major theoretical approaches in the study of mass mediated communication, drawing on research examples that cover various media (e.g. radio, television, film, newspapers, magazines, and the internet) and different countries. The course provides a historical and critical overview of theory and research on processes of media production, media contents, and media reception. The impact media have on culture and society is explored as well as debates that circulate about the media and media influences.
Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussion of student assignments and coursework.
Note:You can not take this course combined with Media Industries and Audiences: CM1012 (the content is the same)

column4: global and local processes of media production,distribution and reception

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106488,2022,Media and Consumer Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. SJ Opree'],,"Inhoud

Advertising, materialism, and consumption are central aspects of modern societies across the globe. Contemporary societies are intertwined with consumer culture and marked by peoples continuously growing wants and needs, as well as the conspicuous consumption of mass produced and marketed goods. This course provides a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and advertising and branded space in particular. We examine the history of advertising, the commercial and social aspects of the messages conveyed by ads, and the advertising industry's influence on social relations and institutions such as politics. Furthermore, we discuss the various ways in marketing to classify consumers, such as the Values and Lifestyle Typology – and learn that individuals differ greatly in their (susceptibility to) consumer values.
· Current theoretical perspectives and research methods in the field of consumer culture
· The history and commercial and social aspects of advertising
· Integrate knowledge gained from specific topics and integrate this in a focus written report
· Apply a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and critically reflect on the advertising industry’s influence on society
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104819,2022,Media and Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. L Ripoll Gonzalez'],,Inhoud

Complex governance processes in networks are constantly influenced by the outside world. This is especially happening through the media attention and the dynamics this generates in networks. Media have become a separate institution with its own logic (the media logic) and its own rules how to bring news and package it. Media logic is concerned with the content of the news provided as well as the formats in which news is created and processed. The format of an item on the television news bulletin for instance, has to meet certain criteria: the slot allocated for the story is only a few minutes long, it has to have news value and it should attract or keep the attention of the viewers. These criteria influence how reality is constructed in the news story.

Many authors claim that media have profound influence on our daily social life, how policy problems are shaped and on various other institutions in society. And this becomes visible when media pay attention to governance processes. Not only does the visibility of these processes enhance but also the decision dynamics change considerably as agenda forming theories have been arguing for some time.

The mediatized world asks for public leaders who can communicate their messages in clear “sound bites,” who can adapt swiftly to new developments and “media hypes,” and who can create attractive brands which arouse positive associations with citizens and voters. But in this public leaders in modern network society are faced with a growing gap between the front stage of a mediatized political world on the one hand and the daily practical life of complexity of governance processes in networks on the other hand (the backstage).

In this course we explore the media as a separate institution, their influence on policy processes and the requirements it posed on public managers. But we also explore managerial strategies that public managers have to influence media attention, like (political) public relations, and public branding.
The goal of the course deals with
Being able to explain the most important theories on mass communication and the functioning of the media, also in relation to branding
Explaining what relevant developments are in the relation between media, public administration and society
Analyzing different aspects of these developments by using concrete examples.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106543,2022,Media and Migration,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. A Paz Alencar'],,"Inhoud

<div>Migration has been a characteristic of societies for centuries. Humans have always migrated to either escape harsh lives, search for better ones, or both. Continuing immigration flows and increasing diversity in many societies have led to more complex processes of integration and the emergence of so-called&nbsp
column2: transnationalism, a phenomenon characterized by cross-border engagements of migrants, organizations and institutions, as well as multiple embeddings of migrants in their (new) homelands. In this course,
column12: different levels of the transnational condition of migration, ranging from mass media representations of migrants and refugees to the mediated communication exchanges conducted in digital spaces, from interactions between relevant stakeholders in the field of NGOs and policy-making through the political and economic side of migrants’ lives to the role played by hands-on intercultural mediation projects.

column1: This course aims to offer a platform for students to develop their research skills for making sense of the intricate relationships between media and migration across different sociopolitical and cultural contexts (Western and non-Western) and drivers of migration (e.g., economic, political, cultural, humanitarian, environmental). In eight weeks, students will work on their own research project, covering topics related to migration, media and technology. Research projects involve building a theoretical argument pertaining to media and migration theories, contacting migration actors and developing digital proficiencies for producing a video essay paper in this field. Throughout this process, students will gain conceptual, empirical and practical knowledge for their master thesis projects.

The research workshop Media and Migration is oriented towards MA students who are interested in developing theoretical, empirical and practical (applied) projects in the field of media and migration, and intercultural communication. This course aims to offer conceptual, empirical and practical tools for building students’ knowledge about current (research) topics and trends in this interdisciplinary field that can also be used in the development of students' master thesis projects.
• Current theoretical perspectives and key concepts in the study of media and migration.
• Video production in research on media and migration.
• Ethical issues and procedures in research involving migrant populations.
• The experiences of migrants in relation to communication practices and networks that involve digital media.
• Produce a video essay project on the topic of migrants and the media.
<li>Report and present their preliminary and conclusive findings in oral and written form.&nbsp
• Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106476,2022,Media and Politics,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. M Avraamidou'],,"Inhoud

This course analyzes the close and multifaceted relationship between media and politics. It is largely through the media that citizens develop an idea of what the world of politics looks like and how it operates. All media are influential in this respect: not just broadcast news, newspapers, and current event magazines, but also (fictional) films and novels, and, increasingly, blogs and social media. Traditional media enable politicians, government officials, and other political actors to simultaneously reach millions of people. New technologies, in turn, intensify the possibilities of citizens themselves to engage politically with one another and to directly challenge politicians and authorities. Fictional media, finally, play an important role in letting us re-live, criticize and imagine politics beyond our everyday experiences. With this encompassing view of the relationship between media and politics in mind, we will pay special attention to politicians, journalists, and citizens/audiences, their interactions and the ways in which these interactions impact democracy. We will discuss different strategies through which politicians and other public figures try to turn the media into their allies, even at the expense of democratic values. We will also analyze journalistic practices and products, approaching them as responses to sometimes diverging interests, including those of politicians, audiences, and media organizations. Finally, we will ponder on political communication's alleged contributions to citizens' re- and/or de-politicization.
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
• Key normative claims about the media in democratic societies.
• The relationships between media institutions and political institutions in international perspective.
• The roles of political reporters and other media professionals, politicians, and citizens in political communication processes.
• The forces and processes that shape political media content in specific ways.
• The effects of media coverage on citizen political attitudes and behavior, as well as the possibilities of citizens in shaping these effects.
• Recognize and articulate political communication concepts as they relate to different media content they encounter.
• Read, critique, and apply major political communication concepts to questions about media and society.
• Build arguments that synthesize and integrate knowledge about the relationship between media and politics.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106539,2022,Media and Social-Cultural Change,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. I Awad Cherit'],,"Inhoud

The idea that the media (can) have the power to change society and culture is at least as old as propaganda and censorship. And yet, questions about the relationship between media and socio-cultural change continue to be at the core of much communication and media research today. How does this relationship look like? (When) Do the media simply reflect social-change? (When) Can they also facilitate change? Do certain media genres, platforms, or media production models lend themselves to more conservative or revolutionary goals than others? What roles can people - activists, producers, and members of the audience, for example - play in this? How has the power of the media changed, especially in the last decades and with new technologies?

This course uncovers the complexities behind these questions. It looks for answers in the academic literature, as well as in students' own identification and observation of contemporary cases. Theoretically, the course relies on communication and media studies, as well as social theory more generally. Special attention is paid, for example, to ideology and hegemony, (journalistic) objectivity, mediatization, media/technological determinism, structure and agency.
Since the relationship between the media and socio-cultural change is not only complicated, but also fluid and context-specific, the course adopts a historical and cross-national perspective.&nbsp
• Different ways in which media stimulate or hinder socio-cultural change.
<li>Diverse academic perspectives towards media and social-cultural change and key theoretical&nbsp
<li>How current socio-political and technological developments are affecting the media’s role in&nbsp
• Contemporary strategies used and related challenges faced by actors using the media for and against social change.
• Critically reflect upon, compare and articulate the strengths and weaknesses of different perspectives on the topic.
<li>Independently apply academic concepts and theories covered in the course to contemporary case studies&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109513,2022,Media contacts for researchers,Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['F.P. Balvert'],,Inhoud

Scientific research cannot do without the media. Media attention contributes to public and political support which are vital, while funders of research expect researchers to communicate with the general public through the media.&nbsp
Successful media attention starts with good preparation. A scientist who is well prepared for contact with the media will succeed in getting her message across to the public.&nbsp

This workshop introduces researchers in media contacts. It gives an overview of different types of media contacts and explains the roles of the researcher, the press officer of the research institute and the journalist in media contacts. It gives practical pointers to prepare for media contacts. And it shows what a researcher can expect from journalists at different times, and which pitfalls to avoid.&nbsp
The workshop consists of theoretical introduction followed by practical exercises.&nbsp
are able to write a popular text about their research that can serve as a basis for a press release
are familiar with the roles of the researcher, press officer and journalist in media contacts
understand different types of media and media channels
feel confident about giving interviews to the media
This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.&nbsp
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.&nbsp
Evaluation – The evaluation is mandatory for this course

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. We have made the evaluation a mandatory part of the course in order to avoid selection bias in the outcomes, and to make sure every student is heard.   &nbsp

On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.&nbsp
Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the <a href=""mailto:graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl"" style=""color:#0563c1

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106565,2022,Media en Ondernemerschap,Nederlands,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. CE Aalberts'],,"Inhoud

In deze module staat ondernemerschap in de mediasector in het algemeen en in de journalistiek in het bijzonder centraal. We kijken naar bestaande en nieuwe businessmodellen, van zowel grote bedrijven, van jonge startups als van individuele professionals. Tijdens de module lezen studenten literatuur over deze businessmodellen, verdiepen zich in onderzoek op dit terrein en gaan in discussie met gastsprekers over inzichten uit de praktijk. Thema’s als platformisering freelance journalistiek, content marketing en crowdfunding passeren de revue. De module heeft als doel inzichten uit de theorie te verbinden met de actuele praktijk. Via deze weg leren we over de mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen voor bedrijven en professionals. Tevens komen de maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen aan bod, zoals de toenemende vervaging van grenzen tussen journalistiek, amusement, voorlichting en PR.
<body>Studenten hebben kennis van en inzicht in:
• Actuele voorbeelden van ondernemerschap in de mediasector.
<li>De verschillen tussen theoretische en praktische kennis op dit terrein
<li>De mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen

<body>This course will examine key issues across Latin American Media. It strives to provide with a panorama of what is happening across the continent and examine the role of media in politics, and its relationship to national identity and state building. The sessions will discuss on a country basis
column2: the build-up of national media production and the flow of media, into, across and out of Latin America
column3: as well as the evolution of key genres, like the telenovela, that have come to be identified with Latin America. Theoretically, we will examine approaches that have originated in Latin America: hybridity, dependency, imperialism, globalization, as well as, the development of geo-cultural and cultural- linguistic regions. An element of this course will include watching and discussing media from the region, as well as evaluations made in and outside the region. Specialists from different areas of the region will provide lectures in order to explore more closely the link among the media formats, contents and the changing social realities in the Latin-American region.</body>

column1: <body>This course will examine key issues across Latin American Media, including the role it plays in politics and its relationship to national identity and state building. It will cover the build-up of national media production and the flow of media into, across and out of Latin America
column2: the evolution of key genres, like the telenovela, that have come to be identified with Latin America.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106538,2022,Media, Culture and Globalisation",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AM Diallo'],,"Inhoud

This course focuses on the key role of the media and cultural industries in the international spread of culture. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past decades witnessed a significant intensification of international cultural flows. Among other reasons, this is a consequence of the introduction of new media technologies and the rise of multinational conglomerates in the media and cultural industries.

We will explore different theoretical approaches to examine the relationship between globalisation in the media and cultural industries, and the symbolic meaning of media products. Furthermore, during the weekly sessions of this course, we will discuss themes such as global cities, multiculturalism, global media events and cosmopolitanism. Both the meetings and the assignments will pay ample attention to the future of globalisation. We will use scenario-building techniques to explore the future connections between media, culture and globalisation. In these activities, theories about globalisation will be applied to societal and organisational problems.
• Key developments in the global spread of culture and the role of media therein.
• Different perspectives in the scholarly and public debate on the nature and impact of cultural globalisation.
• Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of globalisation processes and their social consequences.
• Critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108228,2022,Media, Games, and Creative Industry",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. LA Borges Lima'],,"Inhoud

“But do you play games all day for work?” is a question faced by many academics in the realm of play, game, and videogame studies. Indeed, playing, and notably meaningful play, is a major component of such area, but not all there is to it. In this seminar, we invite you to explore the object of games – digital or not – in the encounter of media studies and the creative industry. The course is divided into three parts - production, content, and consumption – that aim to encompass the main characteristics of these different media and their central role in the creative industries. In production, we look at game developers and publishers, independent creators and groundbreaking game auteurs such as Shigeru Miyamoto (father of Mario and Luigi), and Hideo Kojima (Metal Gear Solid
column2: Death Stranding), among others. You will learn the complex inner workings of the games industries and its employees. In the content part, we delve deep into matters of social, political and cultural contexts within games, present in their narratives and mechanics. We discuss examples such as the representation of War in board games and digital games
column4: and fantasy and mental health. Lastly, in the consumption part, we turn our attention to players and their myriad of playful experiences. We explore matters related to fandom

column1: The course, although academic in nature, is an opportunity to engage both with the application of concepts into everyday media production, and the workers of games industry. As such, students will deliver assignments that include production of vlogging and gameplay, and an in-depth journalistic review of a videogame in either written or audiovisual form. Due to the nature of the topic, the course is comprised of both academic readings, popularly produced content (e.g. gameplays, journalistic reviews/game analysis, podcasts), and in-class/off-class play and game activities.</body>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
• A range of theories and concepts to analyze the complex interactions games, society, and the creative industries
• The configurative interdependence of production, content, and consumption in the analysis of digital and non-digital games.
• The production of theory-based game analysis for a non-academic audience
Students have developed the proficiency/skills to:
• Critically reflect upon the differing approaches to game studies and the creative industries
• Reflect on our relationship to games and other playful activities.
• Reflect on the societal, cultural and political roles of games
• Specific learning objectives in terms of academic skills
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106793,2022,Mediation advocacy: theory and practice,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. RW Jagtenberg']",,"Inhoud

In Western society, law students are led to believe that in-court adjudication is the self-evident and thus the method for settling disputes. This conception, however, is far away from everyday reality. Apart from the fact that many disputes do not lend themselves to authoritative yes-or-no decisions, disputants may experience a series of problems when they choose to assert their rights in court, such as costs, delays, proof proceedings, uncertainty and unpredictability. Where bilateral negotiations are deadlocked and the resourcefulness of a third party is sought, other methods of dispute settlement than adjudication are therefore increasingly considered by disputants, particularly in areas such as construction, employment and family disputes.
column2: Mediation and other modes of dispute resolution such as conciliation, Med.Arb., mini trial, fact finding, all belong to the A(lternative) D(ispute) R(esolution)-family. These methods tend to focus on the parties’ real interests and their future relationships. Possible legal problems relating to ADR are discussed such as the compatibility of ADR with the Right of Access to Court, and the legal status of mediated settlements inter alia in light of the Singapore Convention on Mediation, formally referred to as the United Nations Convention on International Settlement Agreements Resulting from Mediation, which was adopted on 20 December 2018. The main purpose of this convention is to (better) facilitate international trade.

column1: In addition, national and European developments on court-annexed mediation shall be highlighted. In this context, the outcomes of inter alia the Dutch and other national mediation projects shall be discussed. Practical training is provided through role plays and other practical exercises, which are essential for a proper and profound understanding of the working of mediation (advocacy) – certainly for those who pursue a career in law practice.
Over the last decades, mediation has become one of the typical services provided by law practitioners. Obviously, law graduates should be abreast of this development, which is here to stay.

<body>The aim of this course is to give the participating student an understanding of the wide variety of dispute settlement processes, with an emphasis on mediation advocacy. After completion of the course the student should be able to distinguish the various modes of dispute resolution, from the perspective of a lawyer assisting client-disputants.&nbsp
The student shall be assessed on area related knowledge and analytical skills.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109937,2022,Mediation, Moderation, and Conditional Process Modeling",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. I Evangelidis'],,"Inhoud

Mediation topics include: 1) simple mediation with any type of independent and dependent variables (i.e., continuous, dichotomous, multicategorical), 2) mediation with multiple parallel mediators, 3) mediation with multiple serial mediators. Moderation topics include: 1) moderation models with up to 2 moderators (3-way interactions) using any type of independent and dependent variables, 2) analysis of unconditional versus conditional effects, 3) Model estimation and interpretation, 4) Visualization. I will also discuss how to analyze conditional process models (i.e., models that include both mediation and moderation). Depending on the pace of the course I will also try to cover some specialized topics such as mediation analysis in within-participants designs and mediation analysis using a binary mediator. The course will be focused on teaching you how to conduct the appropriate analysis and interpret your results. We will be using PROCESS (Hayes, 2018) for the purposes of this course. Attendants should have a recent version of SPSS or R installed on their computer.

column2: Dr Ioannis Evangelidis (ESADE Business School, Ramon Llull University).</body>

column1: In this course you will learn how to conduct and interpret the results of mediation, moderation, and conditional process analyses. Mediation describes the case where an independent variable X influences another variable M (mediator), which in turn influences the dependent variable Y. Moderation describes the case where the effect of the independent variable X on the dependent variable Y changes across different levels of another variable M (moderator). Conditional process models combine mediation with moderation. This is an applied course: knowledge of algebra is not required. However, a basic understanding of OLS regression is necessary. This course is targeted to any person doing social science research that wants to learn how to test for mediation and moderation in his or her data.

<body>Is euthanasia of demented patients in a progressed state morally permissible? When should doctors refuse requests for new technologies of assisted reproduction, such as in vitro fertilisation (IVF)? Do we have a moral duty to fund orphan drugs? What should government, industry and individuals do in order to tackle problems like obesity or organ donation? Are new technologies to enhance the capabilities of human beings (such as cognition, social behaviour and mood, or physical appearance) morally desirable? Are patients with diverse cultural and ethnical background treated equally in the clinic?&nbsp
column2: Medical ethics and public health ethics are interesting and complex fields of study. In this course, we study pressing ethical issues and how theoretical approaches, concepts and methods may help us to deal with these issues. In the first part of the course, the most important theoretical approaches (utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics) and concepts in ethics and medical ethics (e.g. autonomy, paternalism, informed consent) will be introduced. In the second part of the course, the obtained knowledge will be applied to issues in medicine and public health care and critically reflect on central arguments including the influence of hidden assumptions and technological developments.</body>

mood, or physical appearance) morally desirable? Medical ethics and public health ethics are interesting and complex fields of study. In this module we study pressing ethical issues and how theoretical approaches, concepts and methods may help us to deal with these issues. The first couple of meetings are devoted to the most important theoretical approaches (utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics) and concepts in ethics and medical ethics (e.g. autonomy, paternalism, informed consent). Next, we will focus on issues in medicine and public health care and critically reflect on central arguments including the influence of hidden assumptions and technological developments.

column1: Upon completion of this course students will have the ability to:

identify and analyse moral problems in medical and public health ethics, notably on issues concerning medically assisted reproduction, end-of-life decisions, organ donation, enhancement technologies, public health measures, and justice in health care
analyse, criticize and relate core concepts (e.g. autonomy, competence, informed consent, paternalism, justice, responsibility for health etc) to practical debates
to explain how (anthropological) assumptions play a role in the moral debate
argue for particular points of view in concrete problem cases and to acknowledge the strength and weakness of relevant arguments
evaluate their own ethical beliefs and justify their recommended courses of action.

This course deals with the vast and important area of memory. Memory forms the basis for much of human cognition and behavior. We use our memory not only to remember the groceries we have to buy at the supermarket or to remember where and when to meet a friend, we also need our memory to engage in a conversation, to make calculations, to recognize loved ones, and even to ski downhill. In other words, memory plays an essential role in our daily lives. This becomes even more evident when we consider patients who have severe memory disorders caused by an accident or disease.
At the end of the course, students have
<span style=""color:black"">- knowledge and understanding of the most important theories and empirical findings of short-term memory (at an intermediate level)
- knowledge and understanding of the most important theories and empirical findings of long-term memory, including semantic and implicit memory tasks and skill learning (at an intermediate level)
- knowledge and understanding of the biological basis of human memory and memory disorders (at an introductory level)
- knowledge and understanding of some important mathematical models of human memory (at an introductory level)
- basic skills needed to critically evaluate claims in research papers.

This course introduces framing theory and discusses its relevance for media and communication studies. The seminars focus on framing theory and discuss practical challenges in message framing and persuasion.
This course teaches students how organisations (private and public), the news media, and audiences interact through public relations and how communication professionals strategically&nbsp
column3: their messages. This has a theoretical and a practical dimension. In the theoretical part, students learn what framing in the media is: The modern public sphere builds on dynamic media technologies and complex networks of media- and communication organisations. Audiences learn about current issues and important developments in business, culture, and society through different types of media. Modern communications and PR professionals need to understand the complex interplay of content (language and visuals), technology (channels and formats) and relationships between relevant stakeholders (the target audience, key media outlets, and other organisations) that underlie and shape framing processes. A successful combination of content, technology, and relationships with media organisations can make a profound impact on how audiences perceive a particular message, i.e., pick up on its framing.

column1: Understanding this process eventually enables communication experts to design and execute effective campaigns that build up, reinforce, enhance, or repair an organization’s public reputation. Practical use cases include e.g., product/campaign launches, policy implementations, or crisis management. In the practice-oriented part of the course, students learn how to frame issues through strategic communication in written and spoken word, using modern technology (mainly via a press kit and press conference).

Public and private organisations are often at the center of news reporting in diverse contexts. It is essential for communication professionals to have in-depth knowledge about how public communication and framing in the media work in a digital society, so that they can represent their organisation strategically and result oriented.</body>
Students have developed a critical understanding of
<li>Framing theory, framing in everyday life, and framing in media and business
• How framing occurs in practice while preparing messages
• Key challenges in message framing and persuasion.
• Deal with case studies and prepare persuasive messages in clear and purposeful way while keeping the context and the audience in mind.
• Organize a creative and successful press conference.
• Critically reflect on cases and learn from experience.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107981,2022,Metafysica en Predicatenlogica,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. S Wintein', 'dr. TKAM de Mey']",,"Inhoud
De cursus omvat twee luiken die op elkaar afgestemd worden: een logisch luik en een systematisch luik.

In het logische luik bestuderen we de predicatenlogica. We beschouwen dan ook redeneringen waarvan de correctheid niet alleen steunt op de betekenis van de voegtekens maar ook op de betekenis van de kwantoren “voor alle"" en “er is minstens één"". We onderscheiden het semantische begrip “geldig gevolg van” en het syntactische begrip “afleidbaar uit” en bestuderen de relatie tussen deze twee begrippen.

In het systematische luik worden de centrale problemen uit formele ontologie en de analytische metafysica aan de orde gesteld: universalia, substanties, tijd, compositie, persistentie, causaliteit, responsafhankelijkheid en wereldbeelden.

1.. De student is vertrouwd met de formele taal van de predicaten logica (welke naast de logische voegtekens de kwantoren “voor alle"" en “er is minstens één"" bevat), bekend met de (beperkte) uitdrukkingskracht van deze formele taal en in staat om alledaagse deductieve argumenten te vertalen naar de taal van de predicaten logica.

2. De student is vertrouwd met Tarski’s waarheidsdefinitie voor de taal van de predicaten logica en gerelateerde noties zoals model, vervulbaarheid, vrije en gebonden variabele en in staat om, gebruik makend van deze noties, (alledaagse) argumenten op hun geldigheid te beoordelen.

column3: De student is vertrouwd met een tableau (afleidings-) systeem voor de predicatenlogica en in staat om dit systeem &nbsp
column4: te gebruiken om na te gaan of een argument (on)geldig is en, indien een argument ongeldig is, een tegenvoorbeeld te construeren.

column1: 4. De student is vertrouwd met enkele toepassingen van (het modelbegrip uit) de predicaten logica in de analytische filosofie, met name in de analytische metafysica, en in staat om zich hier kritisch tot te verhouden.
5. De student kan standpunten formuleren en onderbouwen betreffende ontische, ontologische en metafysische onderwerpen

6. De student kan zelf aspecten van wereldbeelden ontrafelen, uitwerken, in relatie brengen tot klassieke, ontische, ontologische en metafysische denkbeelden en teksten, en er zich kritisch toe verhouden
7. De student kan de belangrijkste auteurs, begrippen, distincties, en theorieën uit de metafysica identificeren, omschrijven, vergelijken en toepassen.</body>

<body>Het vak Inleiding methoden en technieken biedt een eerste kennismaking met de belangrijkste manieren van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek die in de criminologie worden gebruikt. Tijdens de onderwijsgroepen en de hoorcolleges wordt aandacht besteed aan onderwerpen en begrippen die van belang zijn om goed sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek te kunnen herkennen en zelf uit te kunnen voeren. Gedacht kan worden aan het formuleren van de probleemstelling, het bepalen van het onderzoeksontwerp (ook wel design genoemd), het kiezen van de methoden van data verzamelen, het operationaliseren van concepten, het kiezen van de technieken om de data te analyseren, de interpretatie van de bevindingen en het doen van uitspraken ten behoeve van de beantwoording van de probleemstelling. Zowel kwantitatief als kwalitatief onderzoek komen bij het vak aan de orde. Tijdens de practica gaan de studenten zelf oefenen met het uitvoeren van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek. Tijdens de kwantitatieve practica wordt met verschillende kwantitatieve analysetechnieken in SPSS geoefend. Ook zijn er kwalitatieve practicumbijeenkomsten waarin de studenten (in kleine groepen) zullen gaan oefenen met interviewvaardigheden.</body>
<li>de basisbegrippen van methoden en technieken van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek omschrijven en uitleggen
<li>design en kwaliteit van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek herkennen, indelen en uitleggen
<li>de kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve onderzoekscyclus beschrijven en uitleggen
<li>uitleggen waarom en wanneer kwantitatief onderzoek en kwalitatief onderzoek wordt gebruikt binnen de criminologie
<li>uitleggen wanneer je op basis van onderzoek generaliserende uitspraken kunt doen en bijbehorende kernbegrippen omschrijven en uitleggen
<li>verschillende methoden van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve dataverzameling herkennen en omschrijven
<li>omschrijven en uitleggen wat beschrijvende analyse en verklarende analyse inhoudt
<li>de basisbegrippen van statistische analyse omschrijven, uitleggen en toepassen bij het maken van statistieksommen en het interpreteren van SPSS output
<li>zelfstandig met SPSS werken: variabelen definiëren en construeren, en enkele beschrijvende analysetechnieken en verklarende analysetechnieken uitvoeren
<li>verschillende soorten interviewvragen kunnen herkennen, beoordelen en zelf formuleren (in een gegeven situatie)
• verschillende interviewtechnieken, houdings- en communicatieaspecten kunnen herkennen, beoordelen en toepassen (in een gegeven situatie).

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106902,2022,Methoden en technieken II,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['A Haspel, LLM', 'BJ van Delft, MSc', 'CE Weeda, MSc', 'dr. A Bouabid']",,"Inhoud
<body>In dit tweede methodevak van de opleiding Criminologie wordt de kennis uit Methoden en Technieken I verdiept. Er wordt een verscheidenheid aan methodes en toepassingen daarvan aangeleerd&nbsp
column2: met betrekking tot het verzamelen en analyseren van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve gegevens. Na afloop van dit vak is de student er klaar voor om zijn eerste eigen onderzoek te gaan uitvoeren.

column1: Er wordt in dit vak een mixed methods-onderzoek uitgevoerd, waarbij met zowel kwantitatieve als kwalitatieve methoden grootstedelijke problematiek (criminaliteit, sociale veiligheid, armoede en inclusiviteit) in (gemarginaliseerde) wijken wordt onderzocht.

In het kwantitatieve gedeelte van het vak ligt de focus op het analyseren van cijfermatige data. Na de beschrijvende analyses die in Methoden en Technieken I zijn behandeld, worden nu methoden geleerd om (complexe) samenhang tussen variabelen te analyseren. Daarbij gaan we uitgebreid in op situaties waarbij meer dan twee kenmerken onderling samenhangen (multivariate analyse).

In het kwalitatieve gedeelte van het vak ligt gaan we kwalitatieve data verzamelen via diepte-interviews en (participerende) observaties en deze vervolgens op kwalitatieve wijze analyseren in Atlas.ti. Tevens zullen we kritisch en systematisch reflecteren op de manier waarop we kwalitatieve data verzamelen en analyseren (methodologische en ethische reflectie).</body>

Studenten zijn na dit vak in staat een gefundeerde keuze te maken uit dataverzamelings- en analysemethoden, voor exploratief, beschrijvend, verklarend en toetsend onderzoek. Daartoe hebben zij naast de kennis uit Methoden en Technieken I nu ook inzicht in de basiskenmerken en principes van kwalitatieve dataverzamelingsmethoden als interviewen en observeren en van belangrijke bestaande kwantitatieve databronnen. Studenten kunnen bovendien de gegevens die voortkomen uit kwalitatief onderzoek coderen en analyseren en weten welke methodologische en ethische problemen er kleven aan kwalitatief onderzoek.

Wat betreft kwantitatieve analysemethoden kunnen studenten bivariate en multivariate analyses uitvoeren met variabelen van verschillende meetniveaus en de uitkomsten daarvan interpreteren en daarover rapporteren. Ook zijn studenten in staat methoden en resultatenbeschrijvingen in wetenschappelijke literatuur te begrijpen en kritisch na te gaan of de uitspraken die worden gedaan terecht zijn, gegeven de gebruikte onderzoeksmethoden.
Tot slot kunnen zij hun reflecties en kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve bevindingen integreren en presenteren in één wetenschappelijk eindverslag.</body>

column1: <li>kennisgemaakt met de rol van risicotaxatie in het forensisch veld
<li>kennisgemaakt met de rol van risicotaxatie in het forensisch veld

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107973,2022,Methodology of Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. CJ Clarke'],,Inhoud
The course will introduce students to key concepts and arguments surrounding:

A) Theoretical modelling: explanation, understanding, idealization and abstraction, causal tendencies, modal hypotheses, the distinction between the practice of theoretical model building and applied models.

B) Causal inference: the Causal Markov assumption, exogeneity, heterogeneity, choosing an appropriate set of control variables, background causal knowledge, Bayesian methods, and hypothetico-deductive approaches in economics, especially Friedman’s instrumentalism.
C) Econometrics: the Lucas critique / microfoundations debates, structural models, the assumptions of regression analyses, representative agent models, methodological individualism
By the end of this course, students can:

1) Clarify the aims of idealized modelling in economics, and critically assess whether these models meet these aims, drawing on the debate between Cartwright, Alexandrova, Sugden, Reiss, Maki, Hausman and Till Grune Yanoff.
2) Examine the extent to which economics is value-laden, and evaluate whether this is desirable or undesirable

3) Explain and distinguish the main obstacles to causal inference in economics, both for observational studies using regression analysis or instrumental variables techniques, or for social experiments.

4) Relate these general obstacles to causal inferences in economics to particular issues arising in econometrics, including the debate over microfoundations for macroeconomic models, influential critiques of macroeconomics by Leamer and Roemer.
