LA Borges Lima', 'dr. RA Harder', 'dr. S Nguyen', 'dr. W Sanders', 'prof.dr. JC van Sterkenburg']",,"Inhoud

This course deepens the methodological expertise that students have gained in previous studies or preparatory trainings. While the course covers the basic features and applicability of various research methods, the emphasis is on students’ own usage of these methods.

The focus is on some of the most commonly used methods of data gathering and data analysis in the social sciences in general, and the field of media and communication in particular. Half of the course will therefore focus on quantitative research methods (such as surveys, experiments, and quantitative content analysis) and how to analyse data (using T-tests, Anova, factor, and regression analysis). The other half will focus on qualitative methods (such as interviews, documents, media content, observations) and how to analyse these data (using thematic analysis, discourse analysis, and visual analysis). Questions regarding validity and reliability of research will be addressed throughout the course.

In the weekly seminars time is spent on practicing methods, while weekly lectures cover the methodological steps more in-depth and from a theoretical perspective. Students will apply some of the methods they practiced with during the course to complete a qualitative- and a quantitative-methods assignment.

The course thus contributes to students’ ability to conduct research independently and strengthens the skills needed in the research workshops and the MA thesis, which follow later in the program. For each MA specialisation, the assignments in the course will be designed to connect to specific foci of the specialisation.
Students have knowledge and understanding of:
• Common research methods in the field of media and communication.
• Key differences in how specific research methods are used and the kinds of data they convey.
• Strengths and weaknesses of each discussed research method.
• ethical issues in media and communication research.

column2: Students have developed the skills to:

column1: • Evaluate research designs, measuring instruments, and sampling strategies (for the methods concerned).
• Develop their own research designs, measuring instruments, and sampling strategies in relation to concrete research questions about media production, content and usage.
• Reflect on the ethical issues important to the research design and methods proposed.
• Reflect on their use of different research methods.
• Report their analyses in oral and written form.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106338,2022,Methods of Qualitative Research,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['B Swartjes', 'DR Geveke, MA', 'dr. N Oosterman', 'I Vitola']",,"Inhoud

This course focuses on qualitative research methods employed in the social sciences, particularly when studying phenomena in culture, media, and history. Whilst various qualitative research methods are contextualized and students are familiarized with their specific characteristics and uses in scientific research, the course is primarily a hands-on course. Students learn how to formulate fitting research questions, design research, and operationalize theoretical concepts. They gain practical experience in various methods of data collection and analysis. The primary focus of this course is on interviewing, but ample consideration will be given to ethnographic field research, narrative analysis, qualitative content analysis, and emerging methods within visual sociology.

<body>After completing the course, students have knowledge and understanding of the characteristics and applicability of a range of qualitative research methods. They will be able to apply particular methods such as participant observation and (semi) structured interviews, and will be able to argue for and against the use of qualitative data analysis methods like grounded theory and (critical) discourse analysis. Apart from a cognitive approach to qualitative research methods, students will learn how to design and execute a research project from proposal to report. The practical application of qualitative research methods is the focal point of this course.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106063,2022,MiM Master Thesis,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. BAS Koene'],,"Inhoud

The Master thesis - including the thesis proposal – constitutes an important piece of academic work you engage with during the spring semester of the MScBA - Master in Management. The Master thesis requires students to conduct independent, individual research in one of the functional domains (‘profile’) in business administration addressing key managerial issues. The thesis is perceived as a proof of academic level thinking and intellectual and analytical craftsmanship. During the thesis trajectory MiM students study a field in business administration in more depth.

The thesis provides students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of an area of interest, as they need to critically explore a concrete managerial problem in the chosen domain and come to well-argued and managerially relevant conclusions. It allows them to improve their skills in practical scientific business and management research, and also to develop a personal profile.

While following the regular structure of an academic thesis at RSM, MiM students pay special attention to the impact of their results for business and their managerial relevance. The thesis topics cover the main domains in business administration, e.g., marketing, strategy, finance, supply chain etc. but the research objective must be put in the bigger context of business administration. The title of the thesis will be mentioned on your grade list. Therefore, it is recommended to choose a title clearly indicating the business relevance.
• Acquire deep knowledge on a specific domain in business administration
• Design and execute a complete research project autonomously
• Define a relevant research question in the current business context
• Collect, process, and interpret data in an ethically responsible way
• Evaluate the findings and relate them to business
• Reflect on the potential implications for implementation

The Master thesis including the thesis proposal constitutes the heart of the master programme MScBA - Master in Management. The Master thesis requires students to conduct independent, individual research in one of the functional domains (‘profiles’) in business administration and relate and link their insights with managerial insights and relevance. The thesis is perceived as a proof of their academic level of thinking, especially a proof of analytical craftsmanship combined with problem-solving and critical reflection. During the thesis trajectory MiM students study a field in business administration in more depth. The thesis provides students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of an area of interest, train their capabilities in analysis and problem solving, improve their skills in practical scientific business and management research, and develop a personal profile.

By choosing a research topic in a profile students express their special interest and affinity towards a future employer. The thesis trajectory is considered as the main opportunity to bring in a focus in the program and express one’s affinity towards managerial challenges in a field in business administration. The topics as offered for a thesis cover the main domains in business administration, e.g. marketing, strategy, finance, supply chain etc. MiM students are always required to consider and discuss elaborately the relevance and implications for management.

Preferences and utility functions, Consumer choice, WARP, Classical demand theory, Elements of production theory, General Equilibrium approach, Expected Utility theory, Non-expected Utility Theories.</body>

The course is an important step towards advanced graduate courses in economics.&nbsp

This course forms an introduction to the fascinating domain of microbes, i.e. the organisms (or entities', such as viruses and prions) that cannot be observed with the naked eye, but have a profound influence on the existence of life on Earth. You will get acquainted with the vast and varied microbiological world and will learn that life can appear in many shapes and forms, and can sometimes tolerate the harshest conditions. Clearly, the saying 'everything is everywhere, but the environment selects' by Dutch botanist and microbiologist Baas Becking (1895-1963) is one of the crucial take-home messages of this course. Apart from the general concepts of microbiology, the course will also zoom in on the world of pathogens: the microorganism that can cause disease. General concepts of infectious diseases will be discussed, and pandemics (worldwide epidemics) from the past will be taken as examples of the devastating outcome that certain infections can have on a population. In addition to studying microorganisms, a major part of this course will be devoted to the human immune system, i.e. the molecular and cellular 'system' that is aimed at recognizing and eliminating harmful microbiological intruders in our body. The different constituents of the immune system will be studied, and their role in the battle between pathogens and host will be explained. Finally, we will discuss the therapeutic options that exist in case the immune system fails to eliminate a pathogen from the human body. The mechanisms of action of the various groups of antibacterial (antibiotics) and antiviral drugs will be studied, as well as the role of vaccination in reducing disease burden.
<body>After taking this course, you will be able to:
<li>Identify and describe the general characteristics of prions, viruses, bacteria, fungi and unicellular (eukaryotic) parasites
<li>Understand the evolution of life and the role of photosynthetic bacteria in creating the Earth's atmosphere
• Explain bacterial metabolism and recognize what is an autotroph or an heterotroph
<li>Recognize human pathogens: prions, viruses, bacteria, fungi and protozoan parasites
<li>Understand the innate immune system, the adaptive immune system and immune disorders
<li>Recognize (emerging) infectious diseases and the interplay between pathogen and host
<li>Identify and characterize sexually transmitted diseases (chlamydia, gonorrhea, syfilis, genital herpes and human papilloma viruses)
<li>Explain zoonoses and pandemics (Yersinia pestis (black death), influenza (Spanish flu) and AIDS)
• Explain antiviral and -bacterial drugs and vaccination, and the mechanism of antiviral and -bacterial resistance.

Na een algemene inleiding in de micro-economie zal de aandacht uitgaan naar de keuzetheorie. Uitgangspunt is dat economische handelingen doelgericht zijn: de beperkte middelen die een subject voorhanden heeft worden zodanig gebruikt dat een bepaalde doelstelling bereikt wordt. Dit algemene uitgangspunt wordt op de handelingen van de consument en producent toegepast. Vervolgens komt het functioneren van markten aan de orde. Ook wordt een begin gemaakt met het analyseren van strategische interactie met behulp van de speltheorie.

• Reproduceren en interpreteren van concepten in sleutelgebieden in de micro-economie reproduceren en interpreteren: keuze en beslissingskunde, informatie en onzekerheid, huishouden- en bedrijfsgedrag, organisaties en markten, allocatie en welvaart en gedragseconomie.
• Reproduceren en interpreteren van concepten in sleutelgebieden in de meso-economie: marktstructuren en -functioneren, bedrijfsstrategie, bedrijfsdoelstellingen en -functioneren.
• Het kunnen gebruiken van standaard wiskundige methoden die veel in micro-economie toegepast worden.
<body>Het vak wordt gegeven door een andere docent, met gelijkaardige inhoud.</body>

This course will provide the basic tools and training in microeconomics. It begins with the study of consumer behaviour and how their choices form the basis of demand in an economy. Firm behaviour is studied next to understand the input-output decisions of firms and to see where supply comes from. The third part brings together both sides of the economy and different market structures are discussed. Finally, strategic interaction between economic agents is the topic of the last part. Throughout, applications are provided to help understand why economic theory can be used to study behaviour in the real world.
<body>At the end of the course students will be able to:
• To understand how consumer choice forms the basis for individual demand, and how individual demand translates into market demand.
• To understand the role of information in decision making.
• To understand how firms decide what and how much (output) to produce, and how they decide which resources (inputs) to use for production.
• To understand the concept of a perfectly competitive market.
• To understand what it means for a firm to have extreme market power.
• To understand that in the real world a whole spectrum of market structures exists between the extremes of perfect competition and monopoly.
<li>The first part of the course deals with the theory of the consumer. Topics covered include consumer choice under certainty and uncertainty, and individual and market demand
<li>The second part focuses on the theory of the firm, and includes the topics of firm production and firm cost

• The last part of the course turns to market structures (monopoly, imperfect competition and perfect competition),and to the joint analysis of firm and consumer behavior within a market (general equilibrium theory).
Reproduce and interpret concepts in key areas of microeconomics:
<li>allocative efficiency and welfare under different markets and firm strategies
Learn to use economic logic to solve problems
Learn to use basic, standard mathematical methods commonly employed in microeconomics.
• The first part of the course deals with the theory of the consumer. Topics covered include consumer choice under certainty and uncertainty, and individual and market demand.
• The second part focuses on the theory of the firm, and includes the topics of firm production and firm cost.

• The last part of the course turns to market structures (monopoly, imperfect competition and perfect competition), to the joint analysis of firm and consumer behavior within a market (general equilibrium theory) and to factor markets.

This course uses knowledge of FEB21017X Introduction to Analysis, and is required for FEB21022X Macro-economics, FEB21010X Mathematical Methods, FEB22016X Mathematical Economics and FEB22017X Finance.
<li>Reproduce and interpret concepts in key areas of microeconomics: choice and decision-making
<li>Reproduce and interpret concepts in key areas of meso-economics: market structure and performance
• Being able to use standard mathematical methods that are widely used in microeconomics.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107347,2022,Microeconomics I (Individual Decision Making and General Equilibrium),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. V Karamychev'],,Inhoud
Instructors: Dr V. Karamychev (EUR) and Prof. C.M. van veelen (UvA)

The course is the fundamental microeconomics course which studies individual decision-making and its relation to market clearing price formation. It builds on classical consumer choice theory. Then, individual behaviors are further integrated into a closed and interrelated system in which the equilibrium values of all variables are simultaneously determined. This is in contrast to the partial equilibrium approach, where all variables, which are not directly related to the problem at hand, are taking to be given. The course develops a theory that attempts to predict the complete vector of individual final consumptions and individual productions from the fundamentals of the economy.

column1: Economics is about the creation of value through markets, organizations and other institutions. Asymmetric information and bounded rationality may get in the way of value creation. This course presents a number of insights from contract theory for dealing with these twin problems. It starts with moral hazard and adverse selection in elementary settings, then it turns to multidimensional incentive problems, contracts for teams, relational contracts, incomplete contracts, decision rights and authority, and asset ownership. It also includes a discussion of cheap talk and communication. These topics are approached by applying contract theory to problems in labour economics, organizational economics, and corporate finance.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107350,2022,Microeconomics IV (Behavioral Economics),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. PP Wakker'],,Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. P.P. Wakker (EUR) and Prof. T.J.S. Offerman (UvA)

This course consists of two parts. One part deals with the behavioral revolution in economics, where differences between homo sapiens and homo economicus require a remodeling of risk behavior, intertemporal behavior, social behavior, individual utility, and, thus, of virtually all economic models. The other part considers the path-breaking insights of behavioral economics into interactive decision making. Special attention will be paid to how behavioral economics changed our thinking about learning, equilibrium, social preferences, strategic communication, and markets. The course gives a broad perspective, showing how behavioral ideas impact virtually every field in economics.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105559,2022,Microscopic Image Analysis: From Theory to Practice,Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['dr. J.A. Slotman', 'dr. W.A. van Cappellen', 'G. Kremers', 'H.M. de Gruiter']",,"Inhoud

Microscopic images contain much more information than normally is retrieved. Especially time-lapse image data contains a wealth of information. Extracting this information by visual inspection and manual measurement is not only cumbersome but also subjective. Automation of image analysis tasks by using a computer and the right software tools allows for higher efficiency, accuracy, objectivity, reproducibility, and completeness.&nbsp

Participants should bring their own (!) laptop computer to the course for the practical exercises. Software and sample image data will be provided during the course (USB stick). No prior knowledge of image processing is required.&nbsp
<li>Obtain a deeper theoretical understanding of image analysis methods&nbsp
<li>Obtain practical experience with image analysis software tools (in particular ImageJ) and learn how to use them intelligently, on their own computer.&nbsp
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.
This is a two-day course with theory and practical exercises interleaved throughout.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course
This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107997,2022,Middeleeuwen en Renaissance,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. HA Krop', 'prof.dr. L van Bunge']",,"Inhoud
De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten.

De middeleeuwen beginnen wanneer West-Europa in economisch en cultureel opzicht tot een primitief stadium terugvalt. Eerst rond 800 trad in de kloosterscholen een voorzichtig herstel van de wetenschappen en de wijsbegeerte op. Daar doceerde men een neoplatonisme, dat men onder meer via Augustinus kende. In de twaalfde eeuw ontstaan de eerste universiteiten, waar de wijsbegeerte van Aristoteles de grondslag van het onderwijs vormt. Dit was mogelijk doordat de hele Aristoteles onder meer door vertalingen vanuit het Arabisch wordt herontdekt. Vanaf dat moment oefent zij bijna een half millennium een ‘despotisch’ gezag uit over de geesten. In de cursus zal worden stilgestaan bij de vernieuwingen met name in de metafysica en de kentheorie, die ondanks de conserverende werking van het ‘schoolse’ onderwijs aan de universiteiten plaatsvonden.

De Renaissance wordt - de naam zegt het al - gekenmerkt door de wedergeboorte van de klassieke cultuur. Deze werd mogelijk door het humanisme: het ontstaan van het hermeneutisch probleem. In de filosofie betekende dat de aandacht voor andere vormen van klassiek denken dan Aristoteles. Uit de herleving van het platonisme en het scepticisme komt ook iets nieuws voort: de moderne natuurwetenschap, die in Francis Bacon haar eerste programmatische pleitbezorger vindt. Bijzondere aandacht gaat uit naar de zogenaamde ‘pyrrhonistische crisis’ die in de tweede helft van de zestiende eeuw haar eerste woordvoerder vindt in Montaigne.

<body>Overzicht van de verdere ontwikkeling van de filosofie vanaf de oudheid. Na deze cursus is de student in staat het verband te leggen tussen religieuze en wetenschappelijke ontwikkelingen aan de ene en de wijsgerige ontwikkelingen aan de andere kant. Verder heeft de student een praktische vaardigheid opgedaan in het interpreteren van een filosofische tekst uit de middeleeuwen en zich vertrouwd gemaakt met de historische wijsgerige terminologie.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/103815,2022,Middle East Politics,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['AK Fretz', 'B Hesseling, MA', 'JC Dispa']",,"Inhoud

Over the course of the past decade, the region known as the Middle East has been undergoing a revolutionary moment, causing monumental political shifts and disruption, and captivating observers across the world. Yet, for all the attention, it remains subject to widespread misconceptions and is often viewed as if suffering from unique, intractable problems.
In order to grasp political change of this nature, this course introduces you to the comparative politics of the Middle East. We will ask questions such as
column2: which structures and practices define politics? How do state and society relate to one another? Why does authoritarianism seemingly hold sway in the region? What have the uprisings changed in the region’s politics? What is the role of identity and ideology? It will also invite you to look critically at the modes and production of knowledge, combining empirical and critical traditions in Political Science.

column1: The state, a key object of inquiry in Political Science, represents a major theme in the course. Beginning with its historical formation at the end of World War I, we will continue to examine the ideological and coercive apparatuses that underpin postcolonial states as well as the forces that challenge their legitimacy. At the heart of the region’s politics is an ongoing struggle between citizens demanding more democratic institutions and the so-called counter-revolution of regimes defending the status quo. Yet contentious politics manifests itself not only as uprisings against state repression but also in myriad other forms of resistance and the politics of the everyday.

Although grounded in Comparative Politics, this course adopts an interdisciplinary perspective, incorporating Area Studies, Postcolonial Theory, International Relations, Political Economy, and History.</body>
<body>Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
• identify and comprehend major themes in Middle East Politics
• demonstrate insight in historical dynamics and current developments
• locate and explain sources of tension and conflict in the region

AM Kanas', 'dr. FG Snel', 'dr. M van der Linden', 'dr. M van Houte, MSc', 'dr. MMAC van Ostaijen', 'J Klok']",,"Inhoud

Nederland en de meeste andere landen in Europa en Noord-Amerika zijn door doorgaande processen van internationale migratie in toenemende mate etnisch en cultureel diverse samenlevingen geworden. In de literatuur wordt zelfs gesproken van “superdiversiteit” waarmee niet alleen bedoeld wordt dat een steeds groter wordend deel van de bevolking van de westerse landen een migratieachtergrond heeft, maar ook dat daarbij steeds meer verschillende landen betrokken zijn. De minor Migratie en Diversiteit biedt verdiepend inzicht in al zulke vraagstukken van migratie en diversiteit en het op deze gebieden gevoerde overheidsbeleid, zowel in de Nederlandse samenleving als internationaal. De minor maakt vanuit sociologisch en bestuurskundig perspectief een analyse van de aard en omvang van internationale migratie, dominante verklaringen voor migratie, en de betekenis van migratie en diversiteit voor de ontvangende samenlevingen in het algemeen. Daarnaast is er in deze minor veel aandacht voor beleidsvraagstukken op al deze gebieden en voor het ter zake gevoerde beleid (migratiebeleid, integratiebeleid, stedelijk beleid, enz.). De minor vertrekt vanuit sociologisch en bestuurskundig perspectief, maar stelt studenten vanuit andere opleidingen ook in staat om een verbinding te maken tussen de eigen bachelor en de thema’s migratie en diversiteit.
Centrale thema’s in de minor zijn:
• Historische en geografische schets van de voornaamste migratiepatronen wereldwijd, in West-Europa en in Nederland.
• Verklaringen van internationale migratie en integratie vanuit diverse sociaalwetenschappelijke disciplines.
• Het ‘management’ van gewenste en ongewenste migratiestromen: visabeleid, grenscontroles, detentie, uitzetting, ‘zelfstandige terugkeer’.
• Theoretische modellen van integratie en integratiebeleid (multiculturalisme, differentialisme, assimilationisme, universalisme en interculturalisme)
• Vraagstukken van vooroordelen en discriminatie, inclusief het gevoerde beleid om dit tegen te gaan
<li>De betekenis van migratie voor de samenleving
column2: hoe hebben deze migrantengroepen de Nederlandse samenleving veranderd?

column1: • De gevolgen van diversiteit of “superdiversiteit” voor steden en het beleid dat steden daarop voeren
• Beleid t.a.v. migranten en diversiteit op verschillende bestuursniveaus: lokaal, nationaal, Europees, internationaal.

De minor vertrekt vanuit sociologisch en bestuurskundig perspectief, maar stelt studenten vanuit andere opleidingen ook in staat om een verbinding te maken tussen de eigen bachelor en de thema’s migratie en diversiteit.
<body>Na afronding van de minor heeft/kan de student

<li style=""text-align:justify""><span style=""background-color:white""><span style=""color:black"">kennis van migratiepatronen van nu en uit het verleden, en begrip van de oorzaken en gevolgen van internationale migratie
• kennis van en inzicht in diverse theoretische verklaringen van internationale migratieprocessen
• kennis van het gevoerde migratiebeleid (d.w.z. het gevoerde beleid om “gewenste” migranten te verwelkomen en “ongewenste” migranten te ontmoedigen), zowel landelijk als in Europa
• kennis van en inzicht in diverse theoretische opvattingen van “integratie” en integratiebeleid (multiculturalisme, differentialisme, assimilationisme, universalisme en interculturalisme)

<li style=""text-align:justify""><span style=""background-color:white""><span style=""color:black"">inzicht in governance vraagstukken omtrent integratie en migratie waaronder verschillen in beleid tussen landen en tussen diverse beleidsniveaus (Europees, nationaal, lokaal)
• inzicht in vraagstukken van vooroordelen en discriminatie
• samen met andere studenten een wetenschappelijke literatuurstudie of kleine beleidsanalyse kunnen verrichten op één van de thema’s die in deze minor aan de orde komen.

Deze minor valt uiteen in twee verschillende delen. In het eerste deel zijn er in week 1 t/m 6 tweemaal per week hoor- en responsiecolleges van de docenten en soms van gastdocenten. Per college worden studenten gevraagd zelfstandig relevante literatuur te bestuderen. Elke tweede week is er een responsiecollege waarin de student de bestudeerde literatuur kan bespreken met de betreffende docent. Daarnaast bieden de responsiecolleges de mogelijkheid om vooruit te kijken naar de wetenschappelijke literatuurstudie of beleidsanalyse die studenten moeten doen in het tweede deel van het programma.
Dit eerste deel van de minor wordt in week 7 afgesloten met een “mid term” tentamen over verplichte literatuur en hoorcolleges.

In het tweede deel van de minor (week 8 t/m 10) schrijven studenten in paren of drietallen (afhankelijk van het aantal studenten) een wetenschappelijke literatuurstudie of kleine beleidsanalyse over één van de eerder in de minor besproken migratie- en/of diversiteits vraagstukken of het ter zake gevoerde beleid. Studenten kunnen het onderwerp van hun afsluitende werkstuk zelf kiezen. Indien gewenst, kunnen ze ook voor een ander onderwerp kiezen als ze daarmee een verbinding kunnen leggen tussen de eigen bachelor en vraagstukken van migratie en diversiteit. Begeleiding vindt plaats door wekelijks bijeenkomsten in kleine groepjes (afhankelijk van studentenaantal 10-15 studenten) o.l.v. één van de drie docenten
3 bijeenkomsten in kleine groepjes ter voorbereiding van het eindpaper (literatuurstudie of beleidsanalyse)
Individueel schriftelijk tentamen (open vragen) over verplichte literatuur en hoorcolleges (“mid term exam”) (60% van het eindcijfer)
In groepjes van drie studenten: wetenschappelijke literatuurstudie of kleinschalige empirische of beleidsanalyse over een migratie- of diversiteitsvraagstuk (40% van het eindcijfer)
Er wordt een inzagemoment met de docenten georganiseerd voor het tentamen.

Gedurende week 8/10 wordt gewerkt met peer-reviews en algemene feedback van de docent bij het schrijven van het paper. Voor de beoordeling van het paper wordt gebruik gemaakt van een beoordelingsformulier. Dit formulier wordt van te voren gepubliceerd op canvas.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106913,2022,Migratie, diversiteit en criminaliteit",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['drs. SL van den Kieboom', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen', 'prof.dr. RHJM Staring']",,"Inhoud

Internationale migratie gaat van oudsher samen met regulering, uitsluiting en restricties. Het zijn processen die zich vooral, maar niet uitsluitend in urbane gebieden manifesteren. Ook wordt migratie al heel lang met criminaliteit in verband gebracht. Door diverse vormen van migratie en de positie en integratie van migranten in m.n. Nederland en Europa centraal te stellen, willen wij in dit vak criminologische en juridische kennis toepassen op een actueel maatschappelijk onderwerp. Thema’s die hierbij aan de orde komen zijn het criminologische taboe op etniciteit
column2: (ir)reguliere migratie en het toezicht op en de beheersing van migratiebewegingen
column3: migratie gerelateerde criminaliteit als mensensmokkel en mensenhandel
column7: de constructie van het ‘illegalenprobleem’, bestaansstrategieën van onrechtmatig verblijvende vreemdelingen, vreemdelingenbewaring, uitzetting en terugkeer. Je verwerft tijdens het vak niet alleen inhoudelijke kennis op deze terreinen, maar maakt ook kennis met de bedoelde en onbedoelde effecten van het Nederlandse en Europese beleid op deze terreinen waardoor je na afloop kunt reflecteren op deze actuele migratie gerelateerde vraagstukken.

column1: • op genuanceerde wijze de geschiedenis en de hedendaagse werkelijkheid van immigratie, integratie en migratie gerelateerde criminaliteit begrijpen en duiden en ben je met deze kennis in staat om op genuanceerde wijze te reflecteren op actuele migratie relateerde vraagstukken.
• op basis van de kennis en inzichten die je in dit vak hebt verworven grootstedelijke alledaagse problemen van de multiculturele samenleving op een afgewogen wijze beoordelen en becommentariëren.
• de gelaagdheid en complexiteit van migratieprocessen duiden in relatie tot mogelijke onbedoelde effecten van restrictiever beleid op deze migratieprocessen.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105786,2022,Migration and Development: Global Entanglements, Livelihoods and Intersectionality",Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,"['dr. SWS Winters', 'dr. Z Kasli', 'prof.dr. AI Chib']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104847,2022,Migration in a Globalized world,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. TWC Swerts'],,"Inhoud

Globalization, understood as the massive increase in flows of goods, services, ideas and people across borders and the widening and deepening of global interconnectedness and interdependence between places, is without a doubt among the most profound societal transformations of the last centuries. By definition, globalization is a transnational, boundary-crossing process that depends on the mobility of not only capital, but also labor. Technological and technical advances have created communication and transportation networks that allow for unprecedented levels of human mobility for transnational elites. Yet, paradoxically, the situation of refugees and ‘undesirable’ migrants is characterized by immobility despite these advances. We will therefore investigate how (im-)mobility is produced, experienced and governed in a globalized world.

In this course, we explore the intricate and complex relationship between globalization and migration in further detail. We draw on insights from the sociological literature on globalization to grasp how global migration brings about changes in various spheres of social life. First, we review sociological theories on the meaning of ‘globalization’ as a process of societal transformation. Next, we investigate the effects globalization has had on the scale, composition and dynamics of migration patterns and, vice versa, how migration has facilitated global change. In the remaining sessions, we further dissect and examine the relationship between globalization and migration by zooming in on its economic, cultural, political and social dimensions.

Throughout, we learn to consider how globalization at times operates as a force of universalization and homogenization and, at other times, as a force of polarization and heterogenization. Globalization can lead to the formation of integrated labour markets, cosmopolitan cultures and transnational social ties, but it can also give rise to global inequality, localism and right-wing populism. Both the ‘winners’ and ‘losers’ of globalization are considered in this course, ranging from hyper-mobile transnational elites to immobilized undocumented workers. Rather than solely conceiving of globalization in trans- and supranational terms, we will also explicitly investigate how globalization manifests itself at the local level.</body>
After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Discuss theories and empirical research on globalization and migration
• Analyse the impact of globalization on global migration patterns and vice versa
• Summarize and present theories and the results of scientific studies on the economic, cultural, political and social aspects of globalization
• Apply theoretical insights from the globalization literature to a case study on or ongoing debate around migration
• Research and write a paper about a subdimension of globalization and its impact on migration
<body>For foreign students, English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106412,2022,Migration, Citizenship and Identity in a Globalizing World",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. I Gusc', 'dr. L Green', 'JA Seijbel, MSC MA', 'prof.dr. G Oonk']",,"Inhoud
<div>Which passport is the most accepted passport around the world and why is this (un)fair? How many generations does it take for a settler and his family&nbsp
column3: 'native'? What is the potential of global citizenship in relation to patriotic realities? These are just some of the pressing questions which are fully explored in this course on Global Migration, Citizenship and Identity. Migration and ethnic minorities have always challenged the ‘nation’ in the Nation State. In this series of lectures we will discuss the development of cosmopolitan citizenship and its discontents. We will take examples from Europe, the US as well South Africa, Japan, Brazil and India. We discuss issues as slavery and citizenship, birth right lottery, paper citizens, multiple passports and loyalties. Global migration has forced us to re-think the construction of the nation state. States increasingly compete with each other for international prestige and economic development. They wish to attract skilled laborers (including sportsmen and women and scientist) and investors or rich consumers. In addition, however, especially western welfare states wish to restrict migration from poor countries to protect the welfare levels of its citizens. Cosmopolitism may be seen as an asset, a challenge and a burden.

column1: Students study three different perspectives on migration and citizenship
column2: (1) Egalitarian liberalism, (2) Communitarian and (3) libertarian perspectives. With these three perspectives in mind they learn how to debate national self-determination, migration and multiculturalism and global distributive justice and migration. By the end of the course they are able to write a critical review of an academic monograph on migration, citizenship and identity.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107579,2022,Mobility and constructing identities in the context of globalization,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. CLA Willemse', 'J Beocanin']",,"Inhoud

In this course, we explore the complexities of identities – and why do they matter to begin with – from the multilayered context of globalization since the twentieth century, dubbed the ‘Age of Mobility.’ The contact, exchange and dissemination of cultures as a result of the migration of ideas, goods and people have resulted in diverse and geographically distributed human identities, particularly in the so-called ‘global cities.’ These phenomena have affected virtually all social groups, home and away from home, albeit in different ways. They also have resulted in the integration, co-existence and contestation of diversities. Among those to be discussed include ethnicity, race, class, gender, and religion, as well as the concepts of national belonging, authenticity, materiality, collectivity and other less-conventional identities. Through topics such as language, sports, food, and music, this course aims to sensitize students to the ways in which various actors continuously negotiate the impact of globalization processes on their identities. In addition, students are invited to develop and apply creative and critical skills to their research, including the incorporation of non-written sources and more inclusive historiography.
Upon completing the course, students will learn:
• to critically analyze the complexities and issues involved in identity studies and why they matter
• to identify and contextualize the actors and processes related to mobility that construct, transform or oppress identities
• to produce academic presentations and papers of relevant topics in an analytical, creative and inclusive manner.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/103710,2022,Modernity: From Enlightenment to Rationalisation,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['AC van der Zaag'],,"Inhoud

'Modernity’, the French poet and angry young man Baudelaire once wrote, ‘is the transient, the fleeting, the contingent (….)’, a formulation that has become as famous for its heuristic power as it has become infamous for its interpretative flexibility. In this course we will discuss this elegant, yet slippery statement on the “essence” of modernity by looking into at least two of its many levels of interpretation, i.e. Modernity’s social structures and its structures of experience.

Modernity, conceived as a historical period, is often sharply distinguished from so-called traditional societies by way of the manifold structural changes that occurred in the nineteenth and eighteenth century (and some would even point to the seventeenth century).

We will discuss this radical break or gradual transformation by means of several key witnesses that have been living through (and sometimes even actively shaped) the developments that have come to define modernity. We will pay particular attention to the Enlightenment and the industrialisation process. By reading texts from Enlightenment thinkers such as Immanuel Kant and Georg W. F. Hegel and critical thinkers such as Karl Marx, Hannah Arendt and Michel Foucault you will gain an understanding of the social situation in which they wrote and the historical moment they tried to grasp in words.

While reading and discussing texts from disciplines such as History, Philosophy and the Philosophy of History, we will focus on four interrelated questions that all circle around the notion of ‘Timely Reflections.’ What is the historical context of some of the most canonical thinkers on modernity? What can these thinkers teach us about their historical context? Why did all of these thinkers reflect on History (with a capital ‘H’) and the relation between the past, present and future? And why are their texts still relevant today?
<body>After the course students are able to
<li>Describe and explain in which ways Modernity is rooted in the Enlightenment
<li>Describe and explain the emergence of typically modern institutions, such as the state, civil society, the family, and the market
<li>Describe and explain the industrial revolution and the industrialization of society
<li>Describe and explain the ways in which industrialization is related to wider developments such as the emergence of capitalism and urbanization
• Describe and explain the ways in which modern institutions produce docile bodies by means of disciplinary techniques.
• Describe and explain the ways in which modern institutions are mobilized and have dissolved with the emergence of totalitarian movements and regimes.
<li>Describe and explain in which ways Enlightenment Reason has been incorporated and criticized in the dominant tradition of modern (continental) philosophy
• Describe and explain the ways in which canonical thinkers – i.e. Kant, Hegel, Marx, Foucault and Arendt – have reflected on their own times and the concept of History.
<li>have an understanding of the continuities and discontinuities in the rise of the natural sciences in the 16th to 18th Century
<li>have an understanding of the rise of the social sciences and humanities in the 19th Century
<li>have knowledge about the ways in which scientists and others (i.e. non-scientists) engage in engage in discussions on ‘objective knowledge’
• have a understanding of the consequences of the democratization of science
• have a clear understanding of the relations between science, policy and practice.
• can explain how science and technology are as much the products of the societies in which they are embedded as that the give shape to those societies

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107768,2022,Module Knowledge,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. M de Mul', 'dr. M Heerings', 'dr. MJ Poleij', 'dr. SPF van Haperen', 'EM Linthorst, LL.M', 'JEM van de Beek', 'K Trujillo Jara', 'LGM Bremmers', 'PPM Mos, LLM', 'RE Michels', 'S Kaddem', 'SE Howe, MSc']",,"Inhoud
This module is part of Blok 9, together with GW309AVV and GW309I.
This module is exclusively for students Gezondheidswetenschappen, BMG.

Many decisions that you will make as a health care manager or policy maker have an ethical component. Think for instance about decisions concerning national vaccination policies, organizational policies that encourage healthy behavior from staff and government and organizational policies emphasizing the autonomy of patients. Different values are at stake in policies such as these which can conflict with each other. This makes it crucially important for you, as a future healthcare manager or policy maker, to be able to recognize the values at stake and to weigh such values in your decision-making. In the course choices and dilemmas we will provide you with the necessary knowledge and skills to do so.

In this course we use insights from the different disciplines of ESHPM, building on the knowledge you gained in previous courses. In addition we use insights from ethical theory to deepen your knowledge about ethical choices and dilemmas. We also provide you with different tools, such as moral deliberation, for ethical reflection.

In the first part of the course we introduce different ethical values (autonomy, nonmaleficence, beneficence and justice) and different ethical theories. In the working groups we practice with several methods of ethical reflection. In the second part of the course we go into more detail on specific ethical dilemmas stakeholders experience in practice. In the working groups we reflect on ethical questions you identify in your internship organizations. In the third and final part of the course you write an individual essay on an ethical question or dilemma of your choosing.
After completion of this module, you can:
• Analyze the origin of choices and dilemmas in healthcare using ethical theory.
<li>Analyze cases concerning choices and dilemmas in healthcare from different points of view (including different stakeholders, disciplines, and ethical theories).&nbsp
• Reflect on your own role as a healthcare manager or policy maker with regards to choices and dilemmas in healthcare.
• Use reflective tools such as moral deliberation when analyzing cases concerning choices and dilemmas in healthcare.

This course will introduce you to the fundamental principles of 'life', with a focus on molecular and cellular biology. Cell biology studies the structure, function, and behaviour of cells, whereas molecular biology describes the molecular basis of biological activity between various biomolecules (like DNA, RNA and proteins). The course begins with an overview of the main features of bacterial, plant and mammalian cells and goes on to introduce the key molecular players in the cells, i.e. proteins. Techniques that enable characterisation, isolation, and manipulation of cells and biomolecules are central in molecular and cellular biology, and these techniques therefore also play a principal role in this course. Specifically, we will take a close look at microscopy, cell culture, DNA cloning and the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) technology. We will then move on to study the regulation of gene expression and the eukaryotic cell cycle. We will see how cells are organised in tissues and how intra- and intercellular signalling pathways are involved in controlling cell division, differentiation, and maintenance of the stem cell state. The final part of the course will focus on how DNA can be damaged and repaired, and which molecular events are involved in the generation of cancer.
After taking this course the student will be able to:
• Understand the principles of biological systematics, taxonomy and the classification of ‘life’
• Identify and describe the structure of bacterial, animal and plant cells (similarities and differences)
• Recognize the vital compartments and organelles of eukaryotic cells and describe their particular function
• Explain intracellular sorting and transport of molecules (in animal cells) and how this is related to the cytoskeleton and cell movement
• Recognize excitable animal cells, understanding membrane and action potentials and the cellular interactions within neural pathways
• Describe the cell cycle: DNA replication, cell growth and division (mitosis and meiosis)
• Explain molecular genetics and epigenetics: the organisation of genomes (emphasis on the human genome)
• Characterize signal transduction pathways: from an extracellular ligand to transcription activation
• Understand the regulation of gene expression: the function of promoters, enhancers, transcription factors and small RNAs
• Describe the various steps involved molecular carcinogenesis
• Explain the concepts of DNA modification and cloning, including transgenesis
• Understand the principles of DNA and (whole-) genome sequencing.

In this practical course, you will become acquainted with microscopy as well as a variety of microbiological and molecular biological techniques. The preparation, planning and execution of the experiments, and the use of specific laboratory materials and equipment, will provide a solid introduction to many aspects of lab work. As a part of the microbiological experiments, you will focus on basic techniques such as the production of culture medium, plating, staining and quantification of bacteria. The molecular biological techniques that you will perform include the isolation of plasmid DNA and determination of the purity of the DNA by spectrophotometry. The length of the isolated plasmid DNA will be determined by both restriction enzyme digestion analysis and PCR. This course provides both practical training, theoretical understanding of the selected methods and the organisational skills required in the biological lab.
At the end of the course the students will:
• Be able to accurately work with a variable micropipette
• Work according to the general safety rules and the current safe microbial techniques (SMT
column2: in Dutch 'veilige microbiologische technieken' or VMT) rules

column1: • Be able to prepare culture media
• Estimate the quantity of micro-organisms (colony-forming unit)
• Be able to make a DNA UV spectrum and interpret it
• Be able to isolate plasmid DNA from a bacterial culture&nbsp
• Be able to execute electrophoresis using agarose&nbsp
• Be able to determine the size of an unknown DNA fragment by means of the electrophoresis data
• Be able to execute a simple PCR experiment and interpret the results
• Be able to operate the light microscope quickly and correctly
• Be able to make various microscopic preparations
• Be able to keep the labjournal in an organised fashion and write lab reports
• Be able to do the calculations involved in these experiments

<body>This course provides an in-depth coverage of the fascinating field of molecular genetics. We will question how many genes it takes to make a human, how these genes are being regulated at the molecular level, and how genome variation contributes to our individuality. Also, we will discuss the clinical manifestation of the patterns of single-gene inheritance and the complex inheritance of common multifactorial disorders. Using this knowledge, we will see how genetics is being used in a clinical setting for risk assessment, genetic screening and counselling. Furthermore, we will study how (defective) genes can be modified both in humans, animals, and plants through gene editing technologies, with the aim of providing gene therapy, or developing transgenic animals and plants. At the end of this course, you will understand that having an exact count of the necessary number of genes will not be nearly as important as understanding the functions of each gene and how they interact to build the living organism.</body>
<body>After this course you will be able to:
• Understanding the functional differences between genes, pesudogenes and non-coding RNA's
• Ecplain how genes are organized on chromosomes and how they are expressed, i.e. transcribed and translated

• Describe the molecular techniques, such as comparative genomic hybridization (CHG), fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH), quantitative PCR (qPCR), gene expression profiling (array technology), DNA/RNA sequencing using next generation sequencing technology (NGS), which enabl chromosome and genome analysis that are commonly being used for gene mapping and identification, clinical and prenatal diagnosis and cancer cytogenetics
• Understand the relationship between the genome and proteome, and how proteogenomics can provide valuable additional information on the composition of the genome

• Understand the typical Mendelia pattern of inheritance, or the pattern of transmission of single-gene disorders. You will be able to describe the molecular and genetic mechanisms by which mutations in genes result in recessice, dominant, X-linked and mitochondrial inheritance patterns
• Understand the genetics of common diseases with compex, non-Mendelian, inheritancem and how this relates to disease-predisposing alleles
• Explain the difference between genetic and epigenetic inheritance and the difference between and the molecular mechanisms of X-inactivation and the histone code
• Understand how determination of the recurrence risk is an important aspect of genetic counseling
• Explain the difference and underlying mechanisms of genome, chromosome and gene mutations, and be able to interpret the mutation nomenclature
• Understand how genetic polymorphisms - or single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) determine genetic diversity
• Understand the Hardy-Weinberg law in population genetics and how it's used in genetic counseling
• Understand the principles of linkage and genome-wide association studies (GWAS)
• Explain how susceptibility traits can have high or low risk allele frequency and what the impact of risk allele frequency is on clinical phenotype
• Understand what gene knock-out is and how molecual techniques, such as the Cre-lox and Crispr/Cas systems, enable gene modification in transgenic animals and plants
• Explain how and what type of viruses are being used for enabling gene therapy, and which diseases can be targeted
• Recognize and understand the ethical issues that are connected to prenatal and diagnostic screening, genetically modified organisms (GMO's), and gene therapy

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105230,2022,Monetary Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. IJM Arnold'],,"Inhoud

Monetary economics is a very broad topic area that deals with the effects of money, monetary institutions, and monetary policy on macroeconomic variables such as output, inflation, interest rates, and exchange rates. In this course we focus on monetary policy in the euro area. We discuss the costs and benefits of monetary union, how monetary policy is implemented by the ECB and how the incompleteness of the monetary union may lead to financial instability.
• What is money and what does it do?
• The various transmission channels of monetary policy.
• Understand key principles behind modern monetary policy.
• Learn practical issues of monetary policy implementation.
• Learn the transmission channels of monetary policy to macroeconomic outcomes.
• Understand specific issues relating to monetary policy in the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU), such as the costs and benefits or monetary union and the fragility of incomplete monetary unions.
• Work with the economic data and use econometric techniques in order to empirically test key relationships between monetary and macroeconomic variables.
The course uses a different textbook and now focuses on issues relating to monetary integration in Europe.
Instead of quizzes, a group assignment is included in the assessment (in addition to a final written exam).</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107886,2022,Money and banking,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. RJ Dottling, MSc']",,"Inhoud

The goal of this minor is to provide students with the key concepts that are critical to understanding how the financial system, the banking system, the money supply process and monetary policy work. Some of the questions addressed in this course are:
<li>What is money and how is it created in the financial system?&nbsp
<li>How do capital and money markets work?&nbsp
<li>How are interest rates on different bonds determined?&nbsp
<li>What is the role of commercial banks and central banks?&nbsp
<li>Why can financial crises have such devastating consequences for the real economy?&nbsp
<li>How do central banks implement conventional and unconventional monetary policy?&nbsp
<li>How does monetary policy transmit to the real economy?&nbsp

All these questions will be discussed in the context of current developments in financial markets and economic policies. A special emphasis will be put on recent academic and policy debates. For example,
<li>What are the pros and cons of very low interest rates for the banking system and the economy as a whole?&nbsp
<li>How do unconventional measures such as quantitative easing work?&nbsp
<li>Can cryptocurrencies take over the role of traditional fiat money?&nbsp
<li>Why has inflation been increasing, and what can central banks do about it?&nbsp
Following this course, students are able to…
<li>Compare the financial system of different countries&nbsp
<li>Illustrate the functions of money, financial intermediaries and the money supply process&nbsp
<li>Analyze moral hazard and adverse selection problems in financial markets using a formal model, and demonstrate how these frictions can be overcome by financial intermediaries&nbsp
<li>Discuss the inherent instability of banking in a formal model and how it is addressed by financial regulation&nbsp
<li>Investigate the build-up, the evolution and amplification mechanisms of financial crises throughout history using different models of financial crises&nbsp

<li>Discuss the function of central banks and how monetary policy affects the real economic outcomes (such as inflation and growth) through different channels in a domestic and international context&nbsp

<li>Calculate relevant concepts around interest rates including present value, yield to maturity, expected return, the risk- and term-structure of interest rates, as well as the difference between nominal and real interest rates&nbsp
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106393,2022,Money and the Fine Arts,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. FRR Vermeylen'],,"Inhoud

column6: width:466px"">In this course, students will analyze the tension between fine arts and money, and the problems of commercializing artistic processes. The course will be divided into two parts: in seminars 2 to 4 we will discuss different exchange models for art goods illustrated by historical and contemporary case studies, and in seminars 5 to 8 the focus will be on the specifics of contemporary art markets (prices, values, indices, rules and conventions, and actors).

column1: - gain an understanding of - and be able to explain the different exchange models for art goods
- picture the main characteristics and actors of the market for fine arts
- understand, explain and compare the exchange dynamics within contemporary art markets
- become familiar with tools (datasets and methods) available to assess prices in contemporary art markets.
- The maximum number of participants is 20
- Due to the subject matter of the course, students are required to have a good knowledge of art history
<body>The aim of this course is twofold: to gain insight into the economic dimensions of the art world
column2: and to alert students with a variety of interests (like business or society) to the intricate and often problematic interaction between the art world on one hand and the world of money and finance on the other.

column1: Having completed the minor, students will have gained a cultural-economic perspective. They should have a wide-ranging knowledge and critical understanding of the cultural economic perspective and of the structures and dynamics of art markets.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105106,2022,Money, Credit and Banking",Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,"['dr. CS Pfeil', 'prof.dr. S van Bekkum']",,"Inhoud

The 2007/8 global financial crisis and 2011 Euro crisis demonstrate the importance of well functioning financial markets and organizations. In addition, banks play a crucial role in the allocation of capital and credit in the economy. This course teaches you to recognize the common mechanisms behind current and past crises.

First, you will conceptually understand how money and credit are created. These processes help shape a financial system that can inherently lead to crisis periods. We will then use these concepts to better understand how the 21-st century financial system actually works.

The second half of this course will zoom in on banks, and in particular on the relationship between a bank, a borrower and a depositor. We will discuss the influence of asymmetric information on the functioning of a bank. We will deal with the theory concerning bank runs, deposit insurance, credit rationing and pooling of interest and maturity. We describe how banks came to existence and how they manage the risks involved in supplying credit. The last lecture is destined for discussion of the current financial crisis.
• The reason of existence of banks and their characteristics:
• The relationship between a borrower and a bank (adverse selection, moral hazard, limited liability, credit rationing and risk management):
• The relationship between a depositor or a stockholder and a bank (bank run, deposit insurance and bank regulation).

• At the end of this course, students should understand the mechanisms through which money and credit markets work, what central banks can do to manage these markets, and roles and functions of banks.
• Students know how these characteristics have contributed to recent crises, and may contribute to future crises.
• Students understand why banks are organized in the way they are.
<body>The Lecturer of the second, Banking, part is now dr. Sebastian Pfeil</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105000,2022,Moot Court Legal Psychology,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. I Boskovic', 'dr. JDM van Dongen', 'MS de Roos', 'prof.dr. EGC Rassin']",,"Inhoud

<body>This course can best be described as a practical internship in legal psychology. Students are assigned an investigative assignment by the moot court. To fulfill the assignment, an expert witness report has to be produced. First, a strategy has to be determined and an initial draft of the report has to be written. Students will receive peer review of their concept expert witness report. Once the report is complete, students will be questioned orally about the report. During the course, several lectures will be given, in which topics regarding expert witness reporting are targeted.</body>

<li>Writing a legal psychological expert witness report, including searching, selecting and interpreting the relevant literature, conducting a tailor-made experiment if necessary for producing the report, and writing in a clear and flawless style for lawyers. &nbsp
• Undergoing and providing peer review of expert witness reports.
• Providing verbal expert witness testimony in court.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107972,2022,Moral Philosophy,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. KME Bauer'],,Inhoud

What is right and wrong, virtue or vice? What ought we to do? What is the (Highest) Good? The course considers normative ethics and discusses four major moral theories that attempt to formulate basic principles of morality: virtue ethics, deontology, utilitarianism and contractualism. We will also turn to meta-ethics and moral psychology to discuss more foundational issues: What are the background assumptions of the theories? Where do they show their limits? And what about their applicability to concrete moral problems in different fields of moral agency? We will discuss so called “moral dilemma cases”. In such cases, agents seem to be condemned to moral failure, they have a choice between plague and cholera. In which way and to what extent can each of the four theories help to evaluate and / or (re-)solve such dilemmatic situations?
The course is accompanied by a training of philosophical debating skills.

As a student of the introductory course into Moral Philosophy you will learn how to argue in a critical philosophical debate about major theories of moral philosophy and their application to so called “moral dilemma cases”.
To reach this aim we will proceed in the following steps:
1. You will understand the four major moral theories: virtue ethics, deontology, utilitarianism and contractualism.
2. You will learn to compare the four theories as well as different theories of “moral dilemmas” by reference to a meta-ethical perspective.
3. You will reflect about the criteria of a sound philosophical debate.
4. You will critically evaluate the scope and limits of the four theories by means of applying them to “moral dilemma cases”.
You are expected to read the mandatory literature thoroughly and to participate actively in fair and objective discussions.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104973,2022,Motivatie, zelfregulatie & prestaties",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. M Twemlow'],,"Inhoud

Why do some people perform better than others on work or study related tasks? Why does one person manage to faithfully adhere to an exercise regimen or a healthy diet while others succumb to the temptation of fast-food? Why is it sometimes difficult to put forth the effort to take on a task? Why do you sometimes postpone tasks even though you know you will regret this later? Why are some good intentions doomed to fail from the start? What is the purpose of planning ahead and setting goals? How can people be properly motivated to reach their potential and reach their objectives? These are just some of the central questions within the domain of motivation, self-regulation, and performance that will be addressed in this course. In addition to a short overview of the major theoretical frameworks, you will read empirical research on these topics. Emphasis is put on critical reading of the literature. The theoretical frameworks or topics that will be addressed are emotion regulation, control theory, social cognitive theory, achievement goal theory, self-determination theory, regulatory focus, procrastination, and the possible limitation of willpower.
At the end of the course:

• Students are able to differentiate between and compare the different theoretical frameworks on motivation and self-regulation (e.g., achievement goal theory, self-determination theory, regulatory focus, ego-depletion).
• Students are able to apply these theories on situations in daily life.
• Students can give examples of self-regulatory mechanisms and are able to describe these mechanisms.
• Students can describe the relationship between motivation, self-regulation, and behavioral outcomes (e.g., performance, learning outcomes, health).
• Students can give examples and explain situations of self-regulatory failure (e.g., procrastination).
<body>The language during the tutorial groups will be English, unless it is possible to create full Dutch and international groups</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108687,2022,Motivation and Coordination in Enterprises,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. GWJ Hendrikse'],,"Inhoud

Organizations are not only part of markets, but also an alternative them. They tend to have characteristics that set them apart from markets, such as employees supplying a subset of their liberties to management, specific human capital, and various possibilities to do more (make better decisions) than any single individual. These features raise issues regarding the determinants of value-creating organizations, such as ‘Who decides?’ (the allocation of authority, formal versus real authority, access, ratification and monitoring in decision control, and initiation and implementation in decision management, task design, conflict resolution, enforcement mechanisms, talent allocation across hierarchical positions, …) and the structure of ‘Benefits and Costs’ (payment schemes
column3: …). The handling of an issue depends to a large extent on whether it is characterized as a conflicting interests / motivation question, a joint interests / alignment challenge, or a cognitive limitation problem. The insights are aimed at helping managers to take effective and efficient decisions.

column1: The goal of this elective is to make you familiar with the topics at the frontier of the field Organizational Change and HRM. The aim is to achieve three goals:

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107895,2022,Multi Methods for Social Development Research,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,"['dr. S Tankha', 'prof.dr. IP van Staveren']",,"Inhoud

This course introduces students to basic qualitative and quantitative research methodologies for designing and conducting development-oriented research. It covers research problem formulation, collection of information and data, and presentation and interpretation of both qualitative and numerical data. Students are introduced to a variety of qualitative and quantitative data collection techniques, with an emphasis on mixing of qualitative and quantitative methods and its impact on the analysis of data. Ethical considerations will also be examined. The course is problem-oriented in that students are guided and asked from the very beginning to develop their own solutions to challenges involved in doing research. After its completion, students will be prepared to work on their research paper and to conduct a research project based on secondary and/or primary data.

All students must have an ECDL score for Excel of at least 70%. Students without any background in statistics may want to take the remedial class in quantitative skills (9103) but this is not a necessary requirement.
O’Leary, Zina (2017) The Essential Guide to Doing Your Research Project. 3rd Edition. London: Sage.
Bryman, A. (2016) Social Research Methods. (5th Edition) Oxford: Oxford University Press.

column2: Inge Hutter and Ajay Bailey (2011) Qualitative Research Methods. London: Sage.

column1: Laws, S., C. Harper and R. Marcus (2003) Research for Development: A Practical Guide. London: Sage in co-operation with Save the Children. Available as e- book at EUR library.
Morgan, D.L. (2014) Integrating Qualitative and Quantitative Methods: A Pragmatic Approach. Thousand Oaks
column2: London: Sage. Available as e-book at EUR library.

column1: Plano Clark, V.L. and N. V. Ivankova (2016) Mixed Methods Research: A Guide to the Field. Thousand Oaks

column1: The overall objective of the course is for students to acquire key skills and knowledge for conducting and using development-oriented social science research, both for MA work at the ISS and for professional work later, as an investigator, or client, or study evaluator.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104908,2022,Multicultureel Ontwikkeling en Onderwijs,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. WWP Smets'],,Inhoud

<div>Tot voor kort was de pedagogische en onderwijskundige wetenschap vooral gericht op wetenschappelijke studies op het gebied van westerse populaties en culturen. Dit heeft voor een westers vooroordeel in kennis en theorie gezorgd. Door mondialisering en migratie ontwikkelingen kan deze kennis over pedagogische en onderwijskundige zaken niet automatisch meer toegepast worden op andere culturen of etnische minderheidsgroepen in Nederland. In de afgelopen jaren is echter veel onderzoek verricht en zijn theorieën ontwikkeld die fenomenen op het gebied van opvoeding en onderwijs in multicultureel perspectief kunnen beschrijven en verklaren. Dit onderzoek en deze theorieën staan centraal in dit blok. Enerzijds worden de basistheorieën behandeld zoals acculturatie theorieën. Anderzijds komen theorieën aan bod die op ontwikkeling en opvoeding betrekking hebben en theorieën die over het onderwijs gaan.&nbsp

Daarnaast leren de studenten niet alleen over methodologische en theoretische zaken met betrekking tot de wetenschappelijke studie van multiculturele gemeenschappen, maar zij worden ook aangemoedigd om een kritische en beschouwende blik en een ethische en onbevooroordeelde houding te ontwikkelen in de studie naar de ontwikkeling en onderwijs van kinderen vanuit een multicultureel perspectief.
<div>Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110574,2022,Multilevel Models,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. DR Schley'],,"Inhoud

One core assumption of traditional OLS regression is that residuals are independently, and identically distributed (iid). This assumption is often violated in data where, for example, two data points were generated by the same person (e.g., within-participant experimental designs, longitudinal data collection). There are many cases where data is nested. As such, a class of mixed (sometimes called multilevel, hierarchical, or nested) models have been developed to analyze data when the iid assumption is violated.

The first pillar of this course is data wrangling. Nested data can be structured in a variety of ways. Understanding how the data in your dataframe is structured is important, both for the types of analyses you can conduct on the data, and its interpretation. Students will learn how to evaluate the structure of their data and how to change the data structure to test different hypotheses.
The second pillar of this course is data analysis. We will cover a variety of multilevel models. All of the models covered will involve frequentist estimation (i.e., non-Bayesian) and be linear
column2: though the insights covered in this brief course will be applicable to Bayesian and non-linear models. Most analysis examples will involve within-participant experimental designs, but there will be a few longitudinal cases.

column1: An intermediate proficiency in a programming language (preferably R) is strongly encouraged for this class.
Students should have proficiency in (at least) multiple regression models.</body>
<body>The goal of this course is to learn how to structure and analyze nested data (e.g., within-participant experiments, longitudinal data).</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/103744,2022,Multiple Modernities: Historical Perspectives from the Global South,Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,Inhoud

The ‘global South’ can be considered the birthplace of many of the intersecting ideas on resistance, solidarity and social justice that today resonate across the world—think of Black Lives Matter and calls to decolonise educational systems, for instance. This course is an invitation to explore such entangled histories with the global South at its centre, and seeks to highlight voices and perspectives that have traditionally been un(der)-represented in traditional curricula.

Through a combination of texts and audio-visual materials, we will think through global history from a non-Western perspective. The starting point is the idea of ‘multiple modernities’: differing experiences departing from the notion of ‘modernity’ as standing in for Western civilisation. We will study the global South as a politically, economically, and culturally imagined space by adopting the Global History approach within the study of history.

By critically engaging with the histories rooted in the production of knowledge that has generated binary oppositions in geographies (‘North/South’, ‘East/West’, ‘developed/developing’, ‘First/Third World’) and relations (insider/outsider, inclusion/exclusion, us/them, coloniser/colonised, rich/poor), we will look at the power dynamics inherent in such binaries and connections that transcend them.

An online project will have you build an archive as both a method as well as a tool to reframe and reconstruct ‘forgotten’ or ‘silenced’ histories. Topics covered in the course include revolution, (colonial) violence, and the struggles of decolonisation, including attempts to forge transcontinental solidarities. Finally, we will look at our own historical moment and think through the present-day reverberations of colonialism and racism, as well as the promise of potential history.
<body>After this course, students will be able to:
• Understand and describe the scholarly debate on the roots of ‘Western Civilization’.
• Formulate a personal position within the scholarly debate.
• Trace the evolution of ‘the Other’ in ‘Western’ and ‘Eastern’ societies from Ancient times to the present.
• Compare concepts of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Trace the current-day iconography of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Discuss the link between Ancient Greek, Muslim and ‘Western’ thinking on the relationship between the spiritual and the temporal.
• Explain the decolonization process in the African continent.
• Critically analyze (political) debates on the role of China in the African continent.
• Explain the basic history of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Discuss the current day cultural, economic and political effects of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Explain Samuel Huntington’s theory of the Clash of Civilizations.
• Position a historically and theoretically underpinned view within the discursive debate on ‘East’ and ‘West’.
